entries.contentPreview: The Twilight Forest teems with creatures that have evolved—or been twisted—to thrive in magical darkness: - Shadow-stalkers that move unseen even by those with supernatural sight - Eyeless predators that hunt by sound and tremor - Void-touched beasts bleeding darkness from open wounds - Things that were once other creatures before the dark changed them

entries.name: Ural of the Third Moon
entries.contentPreview: The dragon Ural of the Third Moon dwells somewhere in or near the Twilight Forest, though its exact lair remains unknown. This creature of darkness drove the Spindral ancestors underground and continues to cast its shadow over the region. The Spindral believe Ural will one day return in force, and they prepare endlessly for that reckoning. See [Ural of the Third Moon](Ural%20of%20the%20Third%20Moon.md) for more information.

entries.name: Ural of the Third Moon
entries.contentPreview: A dragon of legendary menace that haunts the Twilight Forest in southeastern Frostmarch Peninsula. Ural is a creature of darkness and shadow, and its presence has shaped the history of this region for centuries.

entries.name: The Spindral Exodus
entries.contentPreview: Generations ago, when the ancestors of the Spindral still lived above ground in the Twilight Forest, Ural descended upon them with devastating fury. Unable to face the dragon's power in open battle, the elves fled underground, abandoning their surface settlements and carving out a new existence in the caverns beneath the forest floor. The Spindral have never forgiven this displacement. They maintain an eternal vigil, watching for signs of Ural's movements, preparing for the day when they might h

entries.name: Nature and Appearance
entries.contentPreview: Little is confirmed about Ural's true form. The darkness of the Twilight Forest and the dragon's apparent mastery of shadow make reliable accounts scarce. What survivors describe: - Scales that seem to drink in light rather than reflect it - Eyes that glow with a cold, moonlike luminescence - An ability to move through the darkness as if it were water The epithet "of the Third Moon" remains unexplained. Some scholars theorize it refers to an ancient calendar, a cosmic alignment, or perhaps somet

entries.name: Current Status
entries.contentPreview: Ural's exact lair and current activities are unknown. The dragon has not been seen in force for decades, though the Spindral report periodic signs of its presence—strange darkness even by Twilight Forest standards, the distant sound of massive wings, prey animals found drained of something more than blood. Whether Ural sleeps, schemes, or simply waits is a question that keeps the Spindral ever-watchful.

entries.name: Valley of Thagrund
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Boundaries and Position
entries.contentPreview: - **North**: Bordered by the Ocean of Azeros; mountains dot the coastline - **South**: The Kharvorn Mountains form the southern boundary, their diagonal line running from northwest to southeast - **West**: Transitions into the Northlands where the Nysanna Range and Kharvorn Mountains meet - **East**: Extends to the Ocean of Azeros and transitions into the Frostmarch Peninsula

entries.name: Terrain
entries.contentPreview: The plains are distinctly flat and open—frozen steppe rather than glaciated terrain. Endless white expanses stretch to every horizon, broken only by the occasional rocky outcrop or wind-carved snow drift. Nothing stands to break the howling winds that sweep across the expanse.

entries.name: Notable Forests
entries.contentPreview: Two significant forests cling to the southwestern margins of the plains, where they transition toward the Kharvorn Mountains: - **Winterwood Forest**: Located in the southwestern portion of the plains, directly north of Argysis (one of the Kharvorn sub-ranges) - **Plutochranes Forest**: Positioned north of Myorna (another Kharvorn sub-range), south of the main plains expanse, and west of the Frostmarch Peninsula

entries.name: Dreamplains
entries.contentPreview: The Dreamplains occupy the northwestern reaches of the Celedrim Plains, a vast expanse of frozen steppe notable for its strange atmosphere and the cluster of impact craters that scar its surface. The name comes from the unsettling quality of travel here—distances seem wrong, the horizon plays tricks, and travelers report dreams of vivid intensity during any sleep taken on the plains.

entries.name: Character
entries.contentPreview: The Dreamplains are flatter and more featureless than the rest of the Celedrim Plains, which is saying something. The snow here has a peculiar blue-white quality, and sounds carry strangely—sometimes voices from miles away arrive as whispers, while nearby speech vanishes into silence. The Neth who pass through this region say the boundary between the Material Plane and Celestia grows thin here, though not as dramatically as at Top of the World. The spirits of the dead sometimes wander the Dreamp

entries.name: The Impact Craters
entries.contentPreview: Three massive craters punctuate the Dreamplains, remnants of an ancient cataclysm when objects fell from the sky in the distant past. Whether these were meteors, fragments of the Astral Plane, or something else entirely remains debated by scholars.

entries.name: Predatak
entries.contentPreview: The largest of the three craters, Predatak holds a deep lake of startlingly blue water that never freezes despite the temperatures. The crater walls rise steeply around the lake, creating a natural amphitheater. Something lives in the depths—the Zwaeron refuse to camp within sight of Predatak, and their stories speak of shapes moving beneath the surface on moonless nights. The lake water has unusual properties. Those who drink it report their dreams becoming prophetic for several nights afterwar

entries.name: Nisk
entries.contentPreview: The smallest crater, Nisk, is dry—its bowl filled with frost-shattered stone rather than water. The crater floor is littered with fragments of a dark metalite that doesn't match any known ore. Some of these fragments are warm to the touch regardless of temperature, and a few have been recovered and traded south where artificers pay handsomely for them. The Neth say Nisk is where a star fell and died. They leave offerings at the crater's rim—small carvings, braided grass, tokens of remembrance—th

entries.name: Emtus
entries.contentPreview: Emtus is the strangest of the three. The crater exists, unmistakably, but something about it resists perception. Travelers who approach find themselves walking past it, around it, their attention sliding away. Mapping expeditions have tried to chart its interior and returned with contradictory results—some claiming it's shallow and empty, others insisting it contains ruins, still others unable to remember reaching it at all. Whatever fell at Emtus didn't just impact the ground. It may have impac

entries.name: Hills of the Lost
entries.contentPreview: South of the craters, where the Dreamplains begin transitioning toward the Winterwood, a range of low hills breaks the flatness. The Hills of the Lost earned their name honestly—travelers who enter them often emerge days later, miles from where they expected, with hazy memories of the intervening time. The hills are not inherently malevolent, but something about their geography defies normal navigation. Compasses spin, the sun seems to move wrong, and familiar landmarks rearrange themselves. The

entries.name: Wolfspine
entries.contentPreview: At the southern edge of the Dreamplains, the Wolfspine rises—a small mountain range that marks the boundary between the open steppe and the forested regions to the south. The peaks are jagged and bare, resembling (as the name suggests) the spine of some enormous creature. The Zwaeron use the Wolfspine as a landmark and waystation, and several semi-permanent camps exist in the sheltered valleys between peaks. Dire wolves den in the Wolfspine in unusual numbers, which is why the Zwaeron favor it—t

entries.name: Emtus
entries.contentPreview: A crater lake in the Celedrim Plains. TODO

entries.name: Ennros Lake
entries.contentPreview: Filled with Rusalka. Also home to the Sennites.

entries.name: Promise of Mythras
entries.contentPreview: A massive stone object, permanently trapping the Sennites within Ennros Lake. Named after Mythras, the great dwarven family and king of Argysis before it fell to the dragon. When they got revenge, they placed a powerful enchantment on lake, barring the Sennites from ever leaving the lake. The Sennites would pay very handsomely for its removal. On it is engraved, "A promise, once broken, can be no better reforged than a sword of diamond". If a sword of diamond is brought to the site and broken, t

entries.name: Hills of Starfire
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Hills of the Lost
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Jotunhills
entries.contentPreview: The Jotunhills are a range of rolling highlands southwest of Konai Mora, home to the Jotun—smaller frost giants with cold attunement and remarkable regenerative abilities. The Jotun are cunning, carnivorous, and view frozen humans as both food and status symbols.

entries.name: The Giants
entries.contentPreview: Jotun stand roughly twelve to fourteen feet tall—smaller than their cousins elsewhere in Alaria but no less dangerous. Their cold attunement allows them to survive and even thrive in temperatures that would kill most creatures, and they regenerate from wounds with disturbing speed as long as they remain in freezing conditions. Only fire or removal from cold slows their healing. The Jotun love the taste of flesh, particularly human flesh. They will hoard frozen humans as proof of their wealth, di

entries.name: Clan Structure
entries.contentPreview: The Jotunhills are not a unified territory but rather a collection of clan holdings, each dominated by a patriarch or matriarch who maintains their position through strength, cunning, and accumulated wealth (measured in frozen corpses). The clans raid each other as readily as they raid outsiders, and Jotun politics revolves around blood feuds, marriage alliances, and the endless competition for prestige. Clan boundaries shift constantly as patriarchs rise and fall. A successful raid that capture

entries.name: Relations with Neighbors
entries.contentPreview: The Winterwood's northern edge provides some barrier between the Jotunhills and the lands to the south—the giants do not enter the deep forest, fearing whatever ancient things dwell beneath the canopy. But Jotun hunting parties still sweep around the forest's edges, and the Zwaeron have learned which routes are safer than others. Those taken alive are kept frozen in Jotun larders until needed—a fate the Neth consider worse than death. The giants prefer their meat preserved; a human might be kept

entries.name: Shamayok Hills
entries.contentPreview: The eastern reaches of the Jotunhills, overlooking Ennros Lake and the approaches to Sennos, are called the Shamayok Hills. This region is claimed by a particularly aggressive clan whose hunting parties regularly descend toward the lake settlements, making the eastern trade routes treacherous. The Sennosi have fortified their northern approaches specifically because of Shamayok raids, and caravans traveling to or from the lake city hire guards who know the giants' patterns. Some Shamayok Jotun h

entries.name: Kona Morai
entries.contentPreview: A massive, white expanse—freezing cold, miserable, and incredibly dangerous. Home to Mythandrulve, similar to the chulpe, but all white, and similar to wolves. No heirarchy of control like with chulpe—just a pack. All of them are roughly same size—smaller than Terragones, but bigger than chulpe. Huge paws, can run on top of the snow. Think "vampire wolf gnolls" for vibe.

entries.name: Blistering Mountains
entries.contentPreview: A mountain range north of Konai Mora, marking the northern boundary of the icy tundra.

entries.name: Solhalven
entries.contentPreview: A city-state north of the Blistering Mountains, home to the valkyries. This remote settlement serves as the guardians of one of the most extraordinary structures in all of Alaria.

entries.name: Starreach
entries.contentPreview: A tower that extends all the way from the ground to the Astral plane itself. The valkyries of Solhalven have been cursed to guard Starreach from the angels Sarakiel and Xaphkiel, and they are bound to permit only certain chosen individuals to ascend the tower. The curse has transformed what might have been an honor into an eternal duty, and the valkyries stand watch over this bridge between worlds, never knowing rest.

entries.name: Yukum's Wall
entries.contentPreview: Although not actually a wall, this mountain range is rife with giants, wyverns, snow spirits, and an eternal blizzard, making passing through so treacherous that it has almost never been done. Located on the east side of Konai Mora (basin plains surrounded by mountains in northeast all the way to southwest). Yukum's Wall is coastal mountains, separating Celedrim Plains from the Northern Isles. To its north are the Blistering Mountains (contiguous with Yukum's Wall, volcanoes).

entries.name: Forbidden Coast
entries.contentPreview: The eastern shore of Konai Mora, where Yukum's Wall meets the Ocean of Azuros, is known as the Forbidden Coast. The name is not metaphorical—the Valkyries of Solhalven have declared this stretch of coastline off-limits to all travelers, and they enforce the prohibition with lethal force. The reasons for this restriction are not publicly discussed. Some believe the coast hides an entrance to something the Valkyries guard besides Starreach. Others suggest that things emerge from the water here—thi

entries.name: Gümloskos
entries.contentPreview: The northwestern peninsula of Konai Mora, jutting into the Ocean of Azuros north of Solhalven. Gümloskos is mountainous and wind-scoured, its peaks lower than the Blistering Mountains to the south but no less treacherous. This is the domain of Zosuun, the albino ice-fire dragon who has claimed the region since before recorded history. The Valkyries maintain a careful neutrality with Zosuun. The dragon's hunting grounds overlap with their patrol routes, but neither party seems interested in confl

entries.name: Shargon
entries.contentPreview: The southern reaches of Konai Mora, where the frozen basin begins climbing toward the mountain ranges that ring the region. Shargon is marginally more hospitable than the central expanse—rocky outcrops provide some shelter from the wind, and the Mythandrulve rarely hunt this far from their preferred terrain. Small bands of Neth make seasonal camps in Shargon, fishing the ice-locked lakes and hunting the hardier game that survives on the fringes. These camps are temporary—the Neth know better tha

entries.name: Bitterlands
entries.contentPreview: South of Shargon, the terrain rises into a desolate expanse of rocky highlands, ice fields, and howling wind—the Bitterlands. This wasteland stretches between the frozen Konai Mora basin to the north and the Plutachranes forest to the south, with the Gorthe Hills marking its eastern edge. The name is earned. Nothing grows here; nothing shelters here; nothing survives here for long except things adapted to the absolute worst conditions Alaria can offer. The Mythandrulve rarely venture this far so

entries.name: Soya Grei
entries.contentPreview: East of the Bitterlands, where the mountains curve toward the coast, lies Soya Grei—a peninsula of rocky highlands overlooking Soothesong Sound. The name means "grey fortress" in an old Neth dialect, though no fortress stands there now. If one ever did, it has been scoured away by the elements. Soya Grei is notable for the unusual acoustic properties of its cliffs. The wind through the rock formations produces sounds that the Neth say are the voices of the dead singing to each other across the w

entries.name: Jotunhills
entries.contentPreview: Southwest of Konai Mora, the mountains give way to a range of rolling highlands home to the Jotun—smaller frost giants with cold attunement and remarkable regenerative abilities. The Jotun are cunning, carnivorous, and view frozen humans as both food and status symbols. The Jotunhills are not a unified territory but rather a collection of clan holdings, each dominated by a patriarch or matriarch who maintains their position through a combination of strength, cunning, and accumulated wealth (meas

entries.name: Nalvrayukuk
entries.contentPreview: An icy bay in the Celedrim Plains. TODO

entries.name: Nisk
entries.contentPreview: A crater lake in the Celedrim Plains. TODO

entries.name: Pelmar Mountains
entries.contentPreview: The Pelmar Mountains form the northeastern spur of the greater Kharvorn range, rising where the Celedrim Plains give way to the frozen approaches of the Nysanna Range. They serve as a transitional zone between the windswept grasslands to the south and the true arctic to the north—still bitterly cold, but not yet the killing ground of the higher peaks.

entries.name: Character
entries.contentPreview: The Pelmars are lower and more weathered than either the Kharvorn proper or the Nysanna Range, their peaks rounded by millennia of wind and ice. Snow covers them year-round, but the passes remain navigable for most of the year—making them one of the few routes between the Celedrim Plains and the Northlands proper. The mountains are honeycombed with caves, some natural and some carved by unknown hands in ages past. The Zwaeron use these caves as winter shelters during their migrations, and severa

entries.name: The Wind Gap
entries.contentPreview: The primary pass through the Pelmar Mountains is known simply as the Wind Gap—a brutal corridor where the winds from the Northlands funnel through with enough force to knock a rider from their mount. Crossing the Gap requires timing; the Zwaeron know the wind patterns well enough to predict the brief lulls when passage is possible. Outsiders who attempt the crossing without local guidance often die, their bodies found frozen in the snow days or weeks later.

entries.name: Strategic Position
entries.contentPreview: The Pelmars mark the boundary between the civilized reaches of the Celedrim Plains and the lawless frozen north. No nation claims them, though several have tried. The mountains are too harsh to hold, too remote to garrison, and anyone foolish enough to build a fortress there would find themselves fighting the weather more than any enemy. This makes the Pelmars a natural refuge for those who don't want to be found—exiles, criminals, hermits, and those fleeing wars or debts in the south. Small com

entries.name: Plutachranes
entries.contentPreview: A vast forest in the Celedrim Plains. TODO

entries.name: Predatak
entries.contentPreview: A crater lake in the Celedrim Plains. TODO

entries.name: Sennos
entries.contentPreview: A city-state in the Celedrim Plains. TODO

entries.name: Shardspires
entries.contentPreview: Mountain range in the Celedrim Plains. TODO

entries.name: Soya Grei
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: The Watchtower
entries.contentPreview: A grim settlement clinging to a sheltered valley at the western edge of the Pelmar Mountains, visible from the approaches to Wind Gap. The Watchtower is not a place people choose to live—it is where the unwanted are sent to serve a sentence that never ends.

entries.name: Origins
entries.contentPreview: Centuries ago, the lowland kingdoms faced a problem: criminals too dangerous to imprison, too politically inconvenient to execute, and too useful to simply kill. The solution was the Pelmar Sentence—exile to the frozen edge of the world, where escape meant death by exposure and survival meant a lifetime of suffering. The first prisoners arrived in chains, dumped at the foot of the mountains with minimal supplies and a single instruction: *Watch the caves. Report anything that moves.* No one told

entries.name: The Condemned
entries.contentPreview: Over generations, the prisoners had children. The children had children. Now the Watchtower holds several thousand souls—the descendants of murderers, traitors, heretics, and political enemies—who have never known anywhere else. They call themselves the **Condemned**, and they have transformed their prison into something between a monastery and a fortress. The Condemned do not consider themselves criminals. They are **Watchers**. Their ancestors' sins have been washed away by centuries of vigil.

entries.name: What They Guard
entries.contentPreview: The deep caves beneath the Watchtower are sealed. Opening them is the one absolute law—the only crime still punishable by death (exposure in the wastes, technically, but the result is the same). The elders speak of fragments: - **The Breach**: Something opened here, long ago. Not a door exactly—more like a wound in the world. The first wardens sealed it, but seals weaken. - **The Sleeper**: Something came through before the seal closed. It did not die. It is not alive. It waits. - **The Anchor**

entries.name: Daily Life
entries.contentPreview: Life in the Watchtower is brutal, austere, and rigidly structured. Every adult takes shifts on the watch—four hours staring into the dark of the sealed cave entrances, four hours on the walls scanning the wastes, four hours of labor, four hours of rest. Children are raised communally and assigned to roles based on aptitude: Watchers, Keepers (who maintain the settlement), Seekers (who venture out for supplies), and Speakers (who preserve the fragmentary lore). The Condemned trade with Zwaeron ca

entries.name: The Bells
entries.contentPreview: Seven great bells hang in the central tower, each with a different tone and meaning. Most have not been rung in living memory. The Condemned still know the codes: - One bell: Caravan approaching - Two bells: Storm warning - Three bells: Outsiders at the gate - Four bells: Breach in the walls

entries.name: Relations
entries.contentPreview: The lowland kingdoms have largely forgotten the Watchtower exists. The original crime records were lost centuries ago. Occasionally a scholar or treasure-hunter arrives seeking entrance to the caves; they are turned away, forcibly if necessary. The Zwaeron treat the Condemned with wary respect. They know the Watchtower guards something, even if they don't know what. Their oral histories include warnings about the place that predate the penal colony. Hephake officially claims sovereignty over the

entries.name: For Adventurers
entries.contentPreview: The Watchtower offers grim hospitality to travelers crossing Wind Gap—shelter, food, and guidance through the pass in exchange for labor or trade goods. The Condemned ask few questions about visitors' pasts. They understand the value of not asking. But they will not open the caves. For any price. For any reason. And they watch very carefully to ensure visitors don't try.

entries.name: Winterwood
entries.contentPreview: The Winterwood is the largest forest in the Celedrim Plains region, a vast expanse of ancient conifers that clings to the northern foothills of the Kharvorn Mountains. It marks the transition between the frozen steppe and the mountain ranges to the south—a belt of dark evergreens that provides shelter, resources, and danger in roughly equal measure.

entries.name: Character
entries.contentPreview: The trees of the Winterwood are old. Some of the oldest are thousands of years old, their trunks wide enough that a dozen people linking arms couldn't encircle them. The forest floor is a maze of fallen giants, their rotting bodies hosting entire ecosystems of fungi, insects, and small mammals. Snow filters through the canopy, but the interior is sheltered from the worst of the plains' winds. The forest is dark. The dense canopy blocks most light even in summer, and in winter the perpetual twili

entries.name: Inhabitants
entries.contentPreview: The Winterwood is not empty. Wolves, bears, elk, and countless smaller creatures make their homes here. But the forest also shelters things that prefer darkness—creatures that have lived in these woods since before the first humans crossed the frozen plains. The Neth do not enter the deep Winterwood. Their ancestors learned that lesson long ago. The Zwaeron skirt its edges, hunting the game that ventures out onto the tree line, but they too avoid the interior. Whatever bargains humans have struc

entries.name: The Jotunhills Border
entries.contentPreview: The northern edge of the Winterwood brushes against the Jotunhills, and here the forest takes on a different character. The trees grow stunted and twisted, bent by winds that carry the cold breath of the Jotun highlands. The giants do not enter the deep forest—something there even they fear—but they hunt along the tree line, and woe to any traveler caught between the Jotun hunting parties and whatever lurks beneath the ancient canopy.

entries.name: Relation to Argysis
entries.contentPreview: The southern edge of the Winterwood overlooks Argysis, one of the Kharvorn sub-ranges where the lake dwarves of Sennos once lived before their exile. The dwarves have no love for the forest—they remember, even after thousands of years, that the Winterwood offered no shelter during their flight northward. Some say the forest itself turned them away, its ancient intelligence recognizing that the dwarves had brought doom upon themselves and refusing to share in it.

entries.name: Withepest
entries.contentPreview: Withepest is a vast, featureless expanse of frozen steppe west of the Dreamplains and east of the Northlands transition. The name is old—older than any current language spoken on the plains—and its meaning has been lost. The Neth translate it loosely as "where breath freezes" or "the white death," depending on which clan you ask.

entries.name: Character
entries.contentPreview: If the Dreamplains are unsettling, Withepest is simply brutal. There is nothing mystical about this region's danger—just endless cold, endless wind, and endless white. The terrain offers no shelter, no landmarks, no mercy. Travelers who attempt to cross Withepest without proper preparation simply die, their bodies preserved in the permafrost until spring thaws briefly expose them before burying them again. The Zwaeron cross Withepest only when absolutely necessary, and only in large groups with

entries.name: Hills of Starfire
entries.contentPreview: On the eastern edge of Withepest, where it meets the approaches to the Dreamplains, a range of low hills breaks the flatness. The Hills of Starfire earned their name from a phenomenon that occurs on clear winter nights—the snow and ice on their slopes sometimes ignites with pale, cold flames that cast no heat but burn with eerie beauty. The flames are not true fire. They appear to be a manifestation of light magic interacting with some mineral composition in the hills' bedrock. Mages who have st

entries.name: Ethundra
entries.contentPreview: South of Withepest, where the steppe begins to transition toward the forested foothills of the Kharvorn Mountains, lies the region called Ethundra—a borderland of scrubby vegetation, frozen marshes, and the first scattered stands of hardy conifers that eventually thicken into the Winterwood. Ethundra is marginally more hospitable than Withepest proper. Small game survives here—arctic hares, foxes, ptarmigan—and the Zwaeron sometimes establish temporary camps in the more sheltered valleys. But th

entries.name: Wolfspine
entries.contentPreview: A small mountain range in the Celedrim Plains. TODO

entries.name: Boundaries and Position
entries.contentPreview: - **North**: The Nysanna Range forms the northern boundary, an east-west mountain chain that marks the edge of habitable land - **East**: Transitions into the Celedrim Plains; the two regions meet at approximately where the Nysanna Range and Kharvorn Mountains join at their 120-degree angle - **South/Southwest**: Grades into the Westwilds, a transitional zone of arid scrubland - **West**: Reaches the coast overlooking distant waters

entries.name: Terrain
entries.contentPreview: The terrain consists primarily of frozen tundra: permafrost beneath shallow snow, occasional rocky outcrops, and rare patches of hardy lichen. Howling winds sweep across featureless white expanses for hundreds of miles. The coast is treacherous, with ice shelves that calve into the frigid sea and pack ice that shifts with the seasons.

entries.name: Titanwurm Mountains
entries.contentPreview: Scattered throughout the Northlands are several Titanwurm mountain ranges—isolated peaks and ridges that break the otherwise flat tundra. These are not traditional geological formations but the colossal remains of titanwurms, ancient creatures whose bones now form mountain ranges: - Melrin Mountains - Gwyndolsong Mountains - Wurmling Mountains - Sotori Mountains (south of Wurmling and Jemco, just north of the eastern Krenglelan Range)—composed of the colossal vertebrae of a titanwurm

entries.name: The Northern Plains
entries.contentPreview: The vast frozen grasslands that stretch between the Titanwurm mountain ranges, west of the Wurmling Mountains and south of the Gwyndolsong Mountains. The Beathamuir River cuts horizontally through the entire Northern Plains, one of the few sources of unfrozen water in this frozen realm. The river is massive—wide enough that in some stretches the far bank is barely visible—and fed by glacial melt from the Nysanna Range.

entries.name: Circle of Stone
entries.contentPreview: Like Stonehenge but far more imposing—colossal stones arranged in an ancient circle, each stone unbreakable and emanating massive magical power. The site sits at a convergence of Earth and Force leylines, allowing for extraordinarily powerful geomancy and force magic. The stones predate all known civilizations in the Northlands, and their creators remain a mystery. The Circle has become a pilgrimage site for geomancers and force-attuned mages seeking to study or harness the immense power concent

entries.name: Tower of Azül
entries.contentPreview: Where the Beathamuir River crosses a water leyline, the Tower of Azül rises from an island in the river's center. The tower is ancient—built of blue-black stone that seems to drink in light—and has served many masters over the millennia. Currently it stands empty, its last occupant having departed (or died) within living memory. The tower's position on the water leyline makes it valuable to any mage with water attunement. The river itself behaves strangely near the tower: it never freezes regard

entries.name: Nysanna Range
entries.contentPreview: The massive east-west mountain chain that forms the northern boundary of the Northlands, marking the edge of habitable territory before the polar wastes. The tallest mountains in the world, home to two white dragons, the Wydling ice goblins, and countless glaciers. See the dedicated [Nysanna Range](./Nysanna%20Range.md) entry for details.

entries.name: Wurmling Mountains
entries.contentPreview: One of the Titanwurm mountain ranges scattered throughout the Northlands, the Wurmling Mountains divide the frozen plains.

entries.name: Temple of Zicadia
entries.contentPreview: At the northern tip of the Wurmling Mountains, where force and air leylines intersect, stands the Temple of Zicadia. This remote institution is dedicated to elemental protection magic—specifically, the art of turning air into solid structures that can deflect attacks. The temple is run by Master Felwana, a reclusive woman who lost her husband in a distant war and came to the Northlands to learn. She became a master of the art and now teaches others, though the temple is brutal and miserable. Lif

entries.name: Anu'Itiklik
entries.contentPreview: A frozen, windblasted wasteland in the northwestern Northlands, Anu'Itiklik stretches from the foothills of the Senaveer Mountains in the west to the edges of the Northern Plains in the east. Hundred-mile-per-hour winds are nearly constant across these wastes, and the temperature rarely rises above freezing even in summer.

entries.name: The Atowatowa
entries.contentPreview: Anu'Itiklik is home to the Atowatowa, a confederation of caribou-herding clans who have adapted to this brutal environment over countless generations. Many Atowatowa are born with natural air attunements, allowing them to create pockets of still air around themselves and their herds—the only way to survive in a land where an unshielded face can be flayed raw in minutes. The Atowatowa are fiercely territorial and deeply suspicious of outsiders. This xenophobia is not mere cultural isolationism—th

entries.name: The Wind-Roads
entries.contentPreview: Despite the chaos of the surface winds, the Atowatowa have mapped what they call the Wind-Roads: channels of relatively predictable airflow that snake across Anu'Itiklik. Travelers who know these roads can move faster and more safely than those who fight against the wind. The Wind-Roads shift with the seasons, and keeping track of their current positions is a specialized knowledge passed down within certain families. Outsiders who enter Anu'Itiklik without guides usually die within days—either f

entries.name: Gwyndolsong Mountains
entries.contentPreview: Not mountains at all, but composed of the collosal vertabrae of a titanwurm.  Gwndolmere the Great discovered an infamous Gaeic melody here.

entries.name: Melrin Mountains
entries.contentPreview: Not mountains at all, but composed of the collosal vertabrae of a titanwurm.

entries.name: Niquous
entries.contentPreview: A dragon of the Northlands. TODO

entries.name: Northern Plains
entries.contentPreview: The Northern Plains of the Northlands region. TODO

entries.name: Nysanna Range
entries.contentPreview: The Nysanna Range is one of the most inhospitable places on Alaria—and by some measures, the most dramatic. These are the tallest mountains in the world, their peaks rising so high that the air becomes too thin to breathe. The entire range is plagued with constant blizzards, high winds, and freezing temperatures. It is rare for the temperature to climb above -20°F, and the high altitudes cause confusion, hallucination, and poor judgment in those who venture too high without magical protection. W

entries.name: The Glaciers
entries.contentPreview: Massive glaciers fill the valleys and passes of the Nysanna Range, some of them miles thick and constantly grinding forward. These rivers of ice are not static; they calve enormous icebergs into the North Sea, reshape the landscape over centuries, and occasionally release ancient things frozen within them. The glaciers are also riddled with tunnels—some carved by meltwater, others by creatures that call the ice home. The largest glaciers have names among those who know the range: the Breath of N

entries.name: Dragon Territories
entries.contentPreview: Two white dragons claim the Nysanna Range as their hunting ground, dividing the mountains between them in a cold détente. **Shananae** holds the western reaches, from the approaches to the Anderegnons to roughly the midpoint of the range. She is ancient and indifferent—not actively cruel, but utterly unconcerned with the lives of smaller creatures. The Atowatowa have learned to read the wind patterns that signal her hunts and adjust their movements accordingly. **Niquous** claims the central ran

entries.name: Western Peaks
entries.contentPreview: The western arm of the Nysanna Range curves northward toward the Senaveer Mountains and the Anderegnons, approaching the border between the Material Plane and Celestia. Here the mountains grow taller and stranger, their peaks often wreathed in aurora-light even during the day.

entries.name: Top of the World
entries.contentPreview: The highest peak in the western Nysanna Range, and by some measures the highest point in all of Clueanda. Top of the World rises where the planar membrane between Material and Celestia grows gossamer-thin—so thin that on clear nights, observers claim to see the faint shapes of spirits moving on the other side. The Atowatowa consider this peak sacred ground. When their greatest leaders die, their bodies are carried up the treacherous slopes by a procession of wind-callers who still the lethal gal

entries.name: Bjorin's Lookout
entries.contentPreview: A weathered outcropping on the northwestern slope of the Nysanna Range, overlooking the Anderegnons and the approaches to Anu'Itiklik. Named for Bjorin Wolfseye, a Zwaeron pathfinder who lived three centuries ago. Bjorin earned his name not from keen vision but from what he witnessed. According to Zwaeron legend, he was camped at this outlook when the aurora twisted into unnatural shapes and something emerged from the thinning planar border—a creature of light and memory that had no business exi

entries.name: Witvein
entries.contentPreview: The eastern Nysanna Range, on its northern slopes facing the polar wastes, is dominated by the region known as Witvein—a maze of tunnel-laden glaciers that serves as home to the Wydlings, the ice goblins of the far north. The Wydlings have carved an entire civilization into these glaciers, creating networks of passages, chambers, and hunting blinds that only they can navigate safely. The ice shifts constantly, and the Wydlings have learned to read its movements—knowing which tunnels will collaps

entries.name: Pyoa Noi
entries.contentPreview: Within the eastern Nysanna Range stands one of the most bizarre landmarks in the Northlands: Pyoa Noi, a hundred-mile-long stone serpent that twists through the mountains, its petrified body diving in and out of the peaks like a sea serpent frozen mid-leap. The serpent was once a living creature of unimaginable size, turned to stone by an incredibly powerful gorgon in an ancient battle. Over centuries, the Wydlings have hollowed out the serpent's interior, creating a network of tunnels and chamb

entries.name: Last Chance
entries.contentPreview: High on the northern face of the Nysanna Range, where the peaks give way to the polar wastes beyond, stands the ruined fortress of Last Chance. The name is grimly literal: this was the final point where skyships traveling the northern astral current could safely dock before being swept further into the storms and ice of the world's edge. The astral currents that flow through Alaria's skies follow paths as fixed as ocean currents, and one of the major northern routes sweeps along the Nysanna Rang

entries.name: Inthikrilix Dungeon
entries.contentPreview: On the northern side of the Nysanna Range, where water and force leylines intersect, lies the Inthikrilix Dungeon—a massive fortress carved into the mountainside. This network of ice-encrusted tunnels delves deep into the mountain, leading eventually to the crypt of Inthikrilix, an ancient mage who mastered both ice and force magic. The dungeon is guarded by spirits of ice and force—ethereal beings created by the leyline convergence or bound by Inthikrilix himself. These spirits manifest as crys

entries.name: Senaveer Mountains
entries.contentPreview: The Senaveer Mountains rise northwest of Anu'Itiklik, a rugged barrier between the frozen wastes and the polar approaches. They are home to a large population of northern rocs—massive predatory birds that hunt the caribou herds in the eastern foothills. The mountains are rich with the lichen that feeds the caribou, so the Atowatowa herders journey there every spring, timing their arrival to avoid the rocs' nesting season. The Senaveer range is notable for its unusual geology: veins of a dark cry

entries.name: Anderegnons
entries.contentPreview: The Anderegnons are a miserable, cold, windy range of mountains north and west of the Senaveer, sitting directly on the border between the Material Plane and Celestia. The planar membrane here is so thin that the mountains themselves seem to exist in both worlds at once—their peaks occasionally visible from Celestia as faint gray shadows, and the aurora of the spirit world bleeding down to paint the snow in colors that have no names in mortal tongues.

entries.name: The Ash
entries.contentPreview: The Anderegnons are rich with malstaric ash, a substance that by all rights should not exist here. Malstaris is the shadow plane, the mirror of Celestia across the cosmic divide. Yet the ash is abundant—found in seams throughout the mountains, coating exposed surfaces after storms, accumulating in drifts in sheltered valleys. The Atowatowa have an explanation. They believe that when a spirit crosses from the Material Plane into Celestia at Top of the World, the crossing strips away its shadow. S

entries.name: The Bollinger Mining Company
entries.contentPreview: The Bollinger Mining Company discovered the ash deposits two decades ago and has since established a precarious extraction operation. Malstaric ash is extraordinarily valuable—essential for certain shadow-magic rituals, useful in alchemical processes, and prized by artificers working with darkness-infused materials. The operation is expensive and dangerous. Food must be shipped in; ash must be shipped out. The supply route skirts the eastern edge of the Senaveer Mountains, threading a needle bet

entries.name: Shananae
entries.contentPreview: A dragon of the Northlands. TODO

entries.name: The Plumes
entries.contentPreview: The Plumes are a small region with frequent, intense geysers of fire and steam. Crabs live around the edge of the holes in the ground, feeding off the archea that grow in the hot vents. Docile Magma Snails are throughout.

entries.name: Wurmling Mountains
entries.contentPreview: Not mountains at all, but composed of the collosal vertabrae of a titanwurm. This was the first of the titanwurm mountains to be discovered.

entries.name: Position and Extent
entries.contentPreview: - **West**: The Frostmarch Peninsula forms the mainland anchor, transitioning from continental land into the island chain - **South**: The Ocean of Azeros separates the isles from the Celedrim Plains coastline - **North**: The Ocean of Azeros extends beyond the islands toward the polar ice - **East**: Open ocean The Ocean of Azeros surrounds and permeates the archipelago, stretching from north of the Celedrim Plains across the entire top of this region.

entries.name: Climate
entries.contentPreview: The islands are uniformly icy, though conditions worsen progressively toward the north. Even the southernmost islands remain frozen year-round, with ice floes clogging the channels between them. Navigation is treacherous—shifting pack ice, sudden storms, and the ever-present cold claim many ships.

entries.name: Major Islands
entries.contentPreview: - **Pherezi Imnuttut**: The massive eastern landmass, roughly 1000 miles long, containing Blizrynthine, Giantfell, the Hills of Insanity, and the Timeless Wastes - **Aknimchuk**: Northwestern volcanic island with the Ashy Mountains, Scheyolonae, and the only ice-free harbor in the archipelago - **Potalaptuk**: Central island where Bzulakar's Keep dominates the landscape - **Soki**: Island south of Potalaptuk - **Friursus**: Northern island in the Iceberg Isles chain

entries.name: Seas and Straits
entries.contentPreview: The Northern Isles are threaded with named bodies of water: - **Whispering Sea**: The central waters of the archipelago, named for the unnatural quiet that Bzulakar's power has imposed—waves lap silently, and even storms seem muted here - **Bruthweur Sea**: Eastern waters between the central islands and Pherezi Imnuttut - **Iron Strait**: Southern passage connecting the Northern Isles to the Frostmarch Peninsula's northeastern waters - **Lightning Strait**: Eastern passage near Zemkachi, known f

entries.name: The Iceberg Isles
entries.contentPreview: A chain of smaller, heavily glaciated islands stretching across the northern archipelago. These islands are essentially floating mountains of ice with rocky cores, calving massive icebergs into the surrounding waters. Navigation through the Iceberg Isles is nearly impossible—the shifting ice, hidden rocks, and freezing temperatures destroy most vessels that attempt it.

entries.name: Bzulakar's Keep
entries.contentPreview: In the very center of the Northern Isles stands [Bzulakar's](../../dramatis_personae/Bzulakar.md) domain—a 2-mile-high tower of permanently frozen ice where the ancient lich resides. His power has frozen the surrounding thousand-mile area and stilled the nearby seas to whispers. The tower is visible from much of the archipelago, a landmark and a warning.

entries.name: Foggy Isles
entries.contentPreview: The most densely foggy islands in this half of the world. Home to an old Tuktuk named Gelnor who is paragon attuned to fog and water. Lives here eternally to atone for his sins (he's a lich, immortal). On shore are giant hermit crabs that eat the algae off the rocks.

entries.name: Amber Coast
entries.contentPreview: Located in Pherezi Imnuttut, the Amber Coast is a beach where beautiful amber minerals frequently wash ashore. These minerals possess magical properties, making them highly prized by mages and collectors. The constant flow of enchanted amber from the frozen depths creates a dangerous attraction—both for treasure seekers and the predators that hunt them along the icy shoreline.

entries.name: Blyzrynthine
entries.contentPreview: A canyonland region in the north of Pherezi Imnuttut, bordered by the Hills of Insanity to the north and east, and the mountainous region of Giantfell to the south. A fire leyline passes through Blyzrynthine, superheating the canyons below.

entries.name: Thermarift
entries.contentPreview: Deep within the canyons of Crevakus in Blyzrynthine, huge fiery rifts tear through the ground. These Thermarifts are caused by the fire leyline running beneath the canyonlands, creating massive fissures that belch flame and superheated air. The ground far below in the canyon depths is covered with these fiery tears in the earth, making the deep canyons effectively impassable without magical protection from heat and flame.

entries.name: Timeless Wastes
entries.contentPreview: Southwest of Blyzrynthine and west of Giantfell lie the Timeless Wastes—a frozen desert where time itself behaves strangely. Travelers cannot keep track of time accurately here; hours feel like days, days feel like hours, and aging progresses at unpredictable rates. Some emerge having aged decades in what felt like a day, while others spend what seems like weeks only to find mere hours have passed in the outside world. Everything about the Wastes feels wrong and disorienting, as if time itself h

entries.name: Giantfell
entries.contentPreview: The southern reaches of Pherezi Imnuttut are dominated by Giantfell—a mountainous region that earns its name. Giants dwell here, though what kind and how many remains unclear. Few explorers venture into Giantfell, and fewer return. Those who do speak of enormous shapes moving through the peaks, structures built for beings three times human height, and the constant threat of being stepped on by something that doesn't notice you. The settlement of Themopolkrik clings to Giantfell's southern coast—

entries.name: Hills of Insanity
entries.contentPreview: North and east of Blizrynthine, the Hills of Insanity roll across northeastern Pherezi Imnuttut. The name is not metaphorical. Something about this region affects the mind—travelers report auditory hallucinations, paranoid ideation, and in severe cases, complete psychotic breaks. The effect worsens the longer one stays and doesn't fully fade for weeks after leaving. Scholars have proposed various explanations: a curse from the early ages, contamination from the nearby Thermarifts, proximity to s

entries.name: Potalaptuk
entries.contentPreview: The central island of the Northern Isles, forever in the shadow of Bzulakar's Keep. The 2-mile ice tower dominates the landscape so completely that the island barely has an identity beyond "the place where the lich lives." The ice around Potalaptuk never melts, never shifts—Bzulakar's power holds it perfectly frozen, a demonstration of control that extends for hundreds of miles in every direction. No one lives on Potalaptuk who hasn't been permitted by Bzulakar. What that permission requires, an

entries.name: Aknimchuk
entries.contentPreview: Aknimchuk is the largest island in the northwestern Northern Isles, notable for being one of the few places in the archipelago where volcanic activity provides heat in an otherwise frozen realm. The island is divided into two distinct regions: the volcanic south and the frozen north.

entries.name: The Ashy Mountains
entries.contentPreview: The Ashy Mountains are a range of active volcanoes running across central Aknimchuk. Unlike the fire-leyline heat of Blizrynthine far to the east, these are natural volcanoes—mountains of stone and fire that have been erupting for millennia. The peaks constantly emit smoke and ash, giving the range its name and leaving a grey pallor over the southern half of the island. The volcanic activity creates a microclimate where life can survive. Hardy shrubs and mosses grow on the lower slopes, and hot

entries.name: Tomb of Angi
entries.contentPreview: High in the Ashy Mountains, carved into the side of a dormant peak, lies the Tomb of Angi. Angi was a fire mage of tremendous power who lived centuries ago, choosing this volcanic island as her final resting place. The tomb is said to contain her accumulated knowledge of fire magic, along with whatever treasures she gathered in her long life. The tomb is guarded by fire elementals and constructs of living magma—Angi's final creations, still loyal to their dead mistress. Expeditions have attempte

entries.name: Scheyolonae
entries.contentPreview: The northern half of Aknimchuk, beyond the reach of volcanic warmth, is called Scheyolonae—a frozen expanse of tundra and ice that matches the rest of the Northern Isles in its brutality. The contrast between Scheyolonae and the volcanic south is stark; travelers moving north can feel the temperature drop degree by degree as they leave the mountains' influence.

entries.name: Iceburn Lakes
entries.contentPreview: A cluster of lakes in central Scheyolonae, the Iceburn Lakes are named for the peculiar sensation experienced by those who touch their waters—a burning cold that seems to freeze and scald simultaneously. The lakes never fully freeze despite the temperatures, and their waters glow faintly blue on moonless nights. Local legend claims the lakes are the tears of a frost giant who died here in the early ages of the world. Whether true or not, the waters have unusual properties. Alchemists prize Icebu

entries.name: Salamander Cave
entries.contentPreview: Despite its name suggesting fire creatures, Salamander Cave in northern Scheyolonae is home to ice salamanders—pale, cold-adapted amphibians the size of large dogs that breathe frost rather than flame. The caves extend deep into the frozen earth, and the salamanders have carved out an extensive network of tunnels. The ice salamanders are not aggressive unless provoked, but they fiercely defend their territory. Their frost breath can freeze exposed flesh in seconds, and they hunt in packs. Travel

entries.name: Smokey Bay
entries.contentPreview: The southern bay of Aknimchuk, warmed by underwater volcanic vents, is the only reliably ice-free harbor in the Northern Isles. Ships from the south sometimes make the dangerous journey here to trade with the few hardy souls who have made Aknimchuk their home. A small settlement—more trading post than town—clings to the shores of Smokey Bay. The inhabitants are a mix of outcasts, exiles, and those strange enough to prefer the volcanic island's isolation to civilization elsewhere. They trade in v

entries.name: Ash Mountains
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Bastard's Keep
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Bay of Teeth
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Bruthweur Sea
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Friursus
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Iceberg Isles
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Iceburn Lakes
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Iron Strait
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Lightning Strait
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Moon Dog
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Ocean of Azuros
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Passage of Hacul
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Peyleten Peninsula
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Potalaptuk
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Scheyolonae
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Smokey Bay
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Soki
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Soothesong Sound
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Whispering Sea
entries.contentPreview: Completely still water, never any wind, almost completely quiet except for the quiet lapping of waves against your boat. And so, so, so cold. -120 degrees.

entries.name: Zemkach
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Aboyinzu
entries.contentPreview: Aboyinzu stretches like a hooked tail along the southwestern edge of the known world. Temperate states in the northwest give way to vast savannas, humid jungles, and the cold, mist-shrouded Dragon's Spine mountains in the far south. Multiple mountain chains—the Crystal Mountains, the Morygun range, and the Dalizi Highlands—carve the continent into distinct biomes, while the Deadloop inner sea cuts deep into its heart. To the east, the South Sea separates Aboyinzu from the Shacklands, and to the

entries.name: Featured Regions
entries.contentPreview: - **Terrenia** – Northwestern coastal states and gateways to the continent. - **Central Aboyinzu** – The savanna heartlands surrounding the Deadloop and the Crystal Mountains. - **Wanderlands** – A long southern peninsula of plains and rugged hill country. - **Elder Wilds** – The ancient rainforest that dominates the eastern peninsula. - **Dalizi Confederation** – Allied states ringing Lake Tonactlet Chitle and the Dalizi Highlands.

entries.name: Boundaries and Position
entries.contentPreview: - **North**: Coastal waters separating Aboyinzu from the Shacklands; the Free Isles lie further west - **East**: Transitions into Central Aboyinzu and the vast interior - **South**: Bordered by the Crystal Mountains, which separate Terrenia from the southern regions - **West**: Western coastline facing the open ocean

entries.name: States (North to South)
entries.contentPreview: - **Aal Salma**: The northwesternmost state of Terrenia - **Windor**: South of Aal Salma - **Green Mountains**: A small mountain range separating Windor from Poum Titch - **Poum Titch**: South of the Green Mountains - **Chaal Nazaerox**: A massive state stretching from the east coast all the way to the west coast, positioned north of the Crystal Mountains. This is one of the largest political entities in Aboyinzu.

entries.name: Connection to Central Aboyinzu
entries.contentPreview: East of Chaal Nazaerox lie Grustos and Quintas, two more states that serve as the transition zone between Terrenia and the interior regions around the Deadloop inner sea.

entries.name: Climate
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Aal Salma
entries.contentPreview: An old and careful nation on Terrenia's northwestern coast, Aal Salma has survived centuries by trading with everyone and trusting no one. Its people are merchants, sailors, and cartographers—pragmatists who measure wealth in ships and alliances in contracts. Where the Scalawags of Poum Titch throw festivals, the Salmani sign agreements. The nation is shaped by its geography: the sheltered waters of Masaad Takid in the north, the tiered capital overlooking Prison Bay in the south, and the great

entries.name: Hillat Abu Hizam
entries.contentPreview: The capital of Aal Salma, an ancient port city built in concentric tiers above the cliffs of Prison Bay. Its name means "Belt-Town" in the old trade tongue—a reference to the defensive walls that ring the city like bands on a barrel, each built higher than the last as the city grew upward. The lowest tier holds the harbor, shipyards, and warehouses. Middle tiers contain markets, guild halls, and the famous School of Charts—a cartographic academy whose maps command premium prices across Aboyinzu.

entries.name: Zamrat Aqabah
entries.contentPreview: A northern port city on Masaad Takid, Aal Salma's second city and its moral opposite. Where Hillat Abu Hizam is regulated and respectable, Zamrat Aqabah is neither. Deals that can't be done in the capital get done here. Questions aren't asked. Paperwork gets lost. The city's warehouses hold goods of uncertain provenance—salvage from wrecks that may not have been accidents, cargo that changed hands under duress, items that certain parties would prefer not be traced. The harbor masters take bribes

entries.name: Masaad Takid
entries.contentPreview: A broad, sheltered bay or inland sea on Aal Salma's northern coast—warm, shallow, and rich with life. Pearl divers work its sandy bottoms. Fishing boats crisscross its calm waters. Trade ships move between Zamrat Aqabah and smaller coastal towns without risking the open ocean. The bay's inlets and coves have always sheltered smugglers and, occasionally, pirates. Aal Salma's navy patrols when it can, but Masaad Takid has too many hiding places to control completely. The authorities mostly focus o

entries.name: Whisper River
entries.contentPreview: The primary waterway connecting Zamrat Aqabah to Hillat Abu Hizam, flowing south through the Hiska Wissa forest. Named for the way sound carries over its glassy surface—conversations on the water travel farther than they should, a feature that makes the river's boatmen famously tight-lipped. Villages cluster along the Whisper's banks, farming the fertile floodplains and fishing its waters. The river is Aal Salma's internal highway, carrying goods, people, and information between its two cities.

entries.name: Hiska Wissa
entries.contentPreview: The inhabited forest between Zamrat Aqabah and Hillat Abu Hizam, through which the Whisper River flows. Unlike the deeper forests to the south, Hiska Wissa has been tamed—its trees selectively logged, its clearings cultivated, its trails maintained by the villages that shelter beneath its canopy. The forest provides timber, game, and mushrooms to both cities. Its communities are small but prosperous, benefiting from river trade while avoiding the crowding and politics of urban life. In times of

entries.name: Whitewood
entries.contentPreview: A vast forest of silver-barked trees running north-south along Aal Salma's eastern border, forming a natural boundary with Poum Titch. The wood of these trees is pale, almost white, and prized for shipbuilding—light, strong, and resistant to rot. Logging camps work the northern reaches, sending timber down to Zamrat Aqabah's shipyards. The deeper portions of the Whitewood remain wild and largely unexplored. Travelers who stray from the main trails report disorientation, strange silences, and the

entries.name: Ashen Hills
entries.contentPreview: A range of dry, pale hills running through Aal Salma's interior, named for their ash-colored stone and thin, dusty soil. Little grows here except scrub grass and hardy thornbushes. The hills are hot in summer, cold in winter, and unpleasant year-round. Despite their barrenness, the Ashen Hills hold value. Salt deposits in the eastern reaches supply Aal Salma's preserving industry. Ancient caves riddle the rock, used variously by hermits, outlaws, and—allegedly—pre-human cultures whose carvings s

entries.name: Hiska Baatos
entries.contentPreview: A coastal forest in the southern reaches, between the Ashen Hills and the sea. Less dense than the Whitewood, Hiska Baatos is lightly settled by fishing communities and charcoal-burners who supply fuel to Hillat Abu Hizam. The forest has a reputation for unremarkability—it's simply there, neither beautiful nor dangerous, a place people pass through without remembering. Some find this suspicious. Most don't think about it at all.

entries.name: Hiska Sobada
entries.contentPreview: An uninhabited forest south of Hillat Abu Hizam, dense and dark despite its coastal position. Locals avoid it. The official reason is dangerous terrain—ravines, sinkholes, unstable ground. The unofficial reasons are vaguer and more varied. Some say the forest is haunted by the spirits of prisoners who died in Vadu Inat and washed ashore. Others claim something older lives in the Sobada, something that was there before Aal Salma was founded. The capital's authorities dismiss these stories but hav

entries.name: Bonecrunch Hills
entries.contentPreview: A troll-infested range on Aal Salma's western border, home to numerous troll clans who've lived there longer than humans have sailed these coasts. The hills get their name from what happens to travelers who ignore the warnings. Aal Salma maintains an uneasy truce with the trolls—humans don't settle the hills, trolls don't raid the lowlands. The arrangement mostly holds. Occasionally, brave or foolish merchants venture into troll territory to trade for bone-work and hides, commodities the trolls

entries.name: Prison Bay
entries.contentPreview: A southern bay below Hillat Abu Hizam, guarded by the island fortress of Vadu Inat. The bay serves as the primary anchorage for Aal Salma's small but well-maintained navy—enough ships to patrol coastal waters and discourage casual piracy, not enough to project power beyond their own shores. The bay's name comes from its most famous feature, visible from the capital's upper tiers: the dark silhouette of Vadu Inat, where Aal Salma sends those it wants forgotten.

entries.name: Vadu Inat
entries.contentPreview: The prison island at the mouth of Prison Bay, a black rock fortress that has held Aal Salma's most dangerous and valuable captives for over three centuries. Its name translates roughly as "the Final Ledger"—a merchant's term for accounts that will never be settled. Vadu Inat holds three categories of prisoner: pirates captured in Salmani waters, political prisoners whose continued existence serves some purpose, and those whose crimes are too embarrassing for public trial. The categories sometime

entries.name: What Makes Aal Salma Interesting
entries.contentPreview: - **Pragmatic neutrality**: Aal Salma deals with everyone—pirates, slavers, revolutionaries—as long as they pay and don't make trouble in port. - **The refugee crisis**: Scalawag refugees strain resources and test Salmani patience. Some want to help; others want the borders closed. - **Vadu Inat's secrets**: Who's actually in that prison? What deals keep certain prisoners alive? - **Hiska Sobada**: The forest everyone avoids. What's actually in there? - **The troll truce**: It's held for generat

entries.name: Bonecrunch Hills
entries.contentPreview: Home to numerous trolls.

entries.name: Chaal Nazzerox
entries.contentPreview: The largest state in Terrenia and one of its greatest horrors—an undead empire stretching from the western coast to the Crystal Mountains, ruled by the lich king Xynoth Azkonor. What was once a prosperous agricultural heartland is now a land of shambling dead, rotting cities, and the desperate living who serve or hide from their immortal master. The empire is bounded by natural barriers on all sides: the sea to the west, the Crystal Mountains to the south, the Smokey Hills and their Firesworn de

entries.name: Mournful Wood
entries.contentPreview: The largest forest in Chaal Nazzerox, sprawling across the north-central region between Deadman's Lake and the Grave Hills. The Mournful Wood earned its name through a phenomenon no scholar has adequately explained: those who sleep within its boundaries weep uncontrollably through the night. By morning, the tears have crystallized on their faces, sealing their eyes shut. Victims emerge with tear-tracks of pale crystal running from their eyes to their chins—permanent if not carefully removed. Som

entries.name: Spiritwood
entries.contentPreview: A forest in the northeast where something has gone wrong with the natural order of death. Spirits linger here—not undead (those are shadow-bound corpses), but actual spirits, the consciousness and identity that should have faded to Celestia. They didn't. They stayed. The spirits of Spiritwood are not friendly. They remember their deaths, their murderers, their betrayals. Some were killed by Xynoth's forces. Others died in the chaos before the empire consolidated. A few are older still, remnants

entries.name: Frowning Forest
entries.contentPreview: A twisted woodland in the east where the trees grow in downward-curving shapes, their branches drooping like disapproving brows. Local legend claims the forest watched something terrible happen and has worn the expression ever since. The Frowning Forest is not actively hostile like Spiritwood or Mournful Wood—it's simply oppressive. The trees block light. Sound carries strangely. Travelers report the constant sensation of being observed and judged. Most pass through as quickly as possible, thoug

entries.name: Grave Hills
entries.contentPreview: The heart of Chaal Nazzerox's horror—a region of ancient burial grounds, mass graves, and earth that refuses to keep its dead. The Grave Hills are where Xynoth first raised his armies, drawing on centuries of accumulated corpses to build an unstoppable force. The hills still produce. Fresh graves empty themselves within days. Bodies buried elsewhere sometimes claw their way toward the Grave Hills, drawn by whatever power saturates the soil. The living population learned long ago not to bury thei

entries.name: Hills of Deoria
entries.contentPreview: Central highlands named for a kingdom that no longer exists. Deoria fell to Xynoth's first campaigns, its people scattered or enslaved, its cities reduced to ruins now picked over by the undead. The Hills of Deoria are largely empty—depopulated by war and never resettled. Crumbling villages dot the slopes, their inhabitants long dead or fled. Cave systems riddle the rock, used by refugees hiding from undead patrols. The caves connect in ways the empire hasn't fully mapped, allowing the desperate

entries.name: Steed Hills
entries.contentPreview: A rocky highland in the west where the Gray Citadel stands—one of the last holdout fortresses against the undead empire. The hills were once famous for horse-breeding, producing cavalry mounts prized across Terrenia. That tradition is extinct now; the horses were eaten during sieges or taken by the empire. The terrain favors defense. Rocky outcrops, narrow passes, and poor footing make the Steed Hills difficult for shambling undead armies to traverse. The Gray Citadel was built here precisely be

entries.name: Brevldorf Hills
entries.contentPreview: Northeastern hills where scattered settlements still cling to existence by paying tribute to the empire. The people of Brevldorf learned early that resistance meant death—or worse, undeath in the lich king's armies. They chose survival. Tribute takes the form of food, labor, and occasionally slaves. Villages that meet their quotas are left alone. Those that don't are made examples. The population has learned to hide their healthiest members when the collectors come, offering the old and sick ins

entries.name: Prowling Hills
entries.contentPreview: Southern highlands near the Crystal Mountains, where something hunts. Travelers report being stalked through the rocky terrain—not by undead, who are too clumsy for this landscape, but by something faster and more deliberate. The most common theory is mountain predators descended from the Crystal ranges—cats, wolves, or something worse that found easy prey in the refugees trying to cross south. Others believe living resistance fighters use the Prowling Hills as a base, preying on empire supply c

entries.name: Deadman's Lake
entries.contentPreview: A lake in the north-central region, so named for the bodies that fill its depths. The drowned dead of Chaal Nazzerox sink to the bottom of Deadman's Lake and stay there—preserved by the cold, dark water, never rising as undead despite the empire's necromantic saturation. Scholars have theorized about why. Perhaps the water blocks whatever signal animates the dead. Perhaps the lake predates Xynoth's influence and carries older protections. Perhaps the drowned simply can't find their way out of th

entries.name: Sethlund Lake
entries.contentPreview: The largest of the three western lakes near Hagswood, Sethlund has become hag territory. The coven uses its waters for rituals, its shores for camps, and its depths for disposing of victims. Fishing boats haven't worked these waters in decades. The lake's surface often carries an oily sheen—residue from hag magic or something fouler. Locals claim the water itself has become poisonous, that anyone who drinks it falls under the hags' influence. True or not, no one tests the theory voluntarily.

entries.name: Seron Lake
entries.contentPreview: The middle of the three western lakes, smaller than Sethlund but deeper. Something lives in Seron Lake's depths—something large enough to create waves on windless days and old enough that even the hags of Hagswood treat it with respect. The creature (if it is singular) has never been clearly seen. Fishermen in the time before the empire reported glimpses of scaled coils, massive shadows passing beneath their boats. Now, with the lake abandoned, it presumably feeds on whatever falls or is thrown

entries.name: Jabok Lake
entries.contentPreview: The smallest and southernmost of the western lakes, Jabok is nearly dry—a muddy depression that fills only during heavy rains. Before the empire, villages surrounded it; now only their foundations remain, visible when the water level drops. Some say the villages drowned when the lake rose unexpectedly, their populations becoming its first residents. Others claim the empire drained the lake deliberately, exposing the villages to destruction, and that the water has never fully returned. The truth

entries.name: The Rivers
entries.contentPreview: The empire's highways. With no roads and soft ground, all significant travel and transport moves by water. **Melkron River**: The largest river, running roughly north-south through the heart of the empire. Controls access between the capital region and the southern territories. Heavily patrolled by undead barges. **Yephrenzi River**: Northwestern river flowing out of Aal Salma territory. One of the few routes refugees use to escape north—dangerous, but faster than overland. **Tozzelak River**: N

entries.name: Hagswood
entries.contentPreview: A dark forest at the southwest tip of Chaal Nazzerox, home to a coven of hags who terrorize the surrounding waters. The hags were here before the empire—they welcomed Xynoth's rise, seeing opportunity in chaos, and have carved out a domain within his domain. The relationship between the lich king and the Hagswood coven is unclear. They're not his servants; hags answer to no one. But they're not his enemies either. Some arrangement exists—territorial, transactional, or simply mutual disinterest.

entries.name: Nightport
entries.contentPreview: A harbor on the coast of Hagswood, perpetually shrouded in unnatural darkness. The sun doesn't reach Nightport—not because of clouds or canopy, but because darkness has seeped into the air itself. Visitors report a pressure on their eyes, a thickness to the shadows that defies torchlight. The hags of Hagswood use Nightport as their launching point for raids into the Strait of Curses. Their boats—if they can be called that—drift out from the harbor on nights when Nyxara hangs dark, hunting ships

entries.name: Strait of Curses
entries.contentPreview: The waters south of Xabraedia and north of Hagswood are known as the Strait of Curses, named for the hags who prowl these treacherous waters. The strait is also inhabited by large, nasty serpents known as Silkwurms—creatures that can wrap entire ships in silk and knot them to the seafloor, dragging vessels and crews to their doom. The hags of Hagswood maintain an uneasy alliance with these serpents, communicating with them and occasionally working together to claim victims. Ships that must cross

entries.name: Lutuya Sound
entries.contentPreview: A southwestern bay where the empire's attempted shipbuilding efforts have repeatedly failed. Xynoth needs a navy to break free of his geographic containment, and Lutuya Sound has the deep water and sheltered anchorage to support one. The problem is the hags. Every shipyard established in Lutuya Sound has been sabotaged, burned, or simply emptied of workers who vanished in the night. The hags apparently prefer their hunting grounds undisturbed by imperial naval traffic. Xynoth could force the iss

entries.name: Towns and Villages
entries.contentPreview: The empire's smaller settlements—what remains of them. Most were thriving communities before Xynoth's rise; now they're labor camps, tribute stations, or empty ruins. The living population in these places exists to serve the empire's needs, nothing more. **Zornos**: A northeastern town in the Brevldorf Hills, serving as a collection point for tribute from surrounding villages. The living elite here are tax collectors backed by undead enforcers. **Myavis Kaalthox**: An eastern town near the Frown

entries.name: Charmin Bay
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Fields of Winter
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Green Mountains
entries.contentPreview: The Green Mountains form the spine of southern Windor, a rugged barrier separating the halfling lowlands from Poum Titch and the lands beyond. Despite the name, they're not forested—the "green" comes from the thick blankets of moss and lichen that coat the exposed rock faces, giving the peaks an algae-tinged pallor visible from the lowlands below. These are not tall mountains by continental standards, but they're steep, broken, and riddled with caves. The perfect country for trolls.

entries.name: Character
entries.contentPreview: The Green Mountains are more highland than alpine—rocky plateaus broken by sudden ravines, slopes of loose scree, cliff faces bearded with moss. The peaks rarely exceed a mile in height, but the terrain is treacherous. Visibility is poor. Sound carries strangely. And the caves go deep. In summer, the mountains are almost pleasant—wildflowers in the high meadows, clear cold streams, views that stretch to the distant coast. But summer is short. By autumn the first snows come, and the mountains bec

entries.name: Trolls
entries.contentPreview: The Green Mountains are infested. Not everywhere, not constantly, but persistently. Troll warrens honeycomb the deeper cave systems, and every few years a new clan pushes into territory closer to the lowlands. The trolls here are the common variety—large, regenerating, not clever but cunning enough. They raid for food, preferring livestock but taking halflings when they can. A troll can carry off two sheep or one adult Windorf. They hunt at night, in bad weather, when visibility favors their dar

entries.name: Passes
entries.contentPreview: Three main routes cross the Green Mountains into Poum Titch: **The Nylen Pass**: The primary route, relatively well-maintained, starting just south of the capital. Wide enough for wagons in good weather. Warden patrols sweep it regularly. Still dangerous, but the safest option. **The Eastern Stair**: A steeper, narrower path descending toward the Throatslit Mountains and the lands beyond. Less traveled, less patrolled. The name comes from the carved steps—old work, pre-Windorf—that switchback do

entries.name: Clawsnatch Lake
entries.contentPreview: High in the central mountains, Clawsnatch is the largest body of water in the range—a cold, deep lake filling an ancient crater or collapsed cave system. The water is clear but dark, visibility dropping to nothing below thirty feet. Local legend says something lives in the depths. The Wardens neither confirm nor deny, but they don't patrol the lake shore, and they discourage expeditions. Whatever truth the stories hold, the lake is genuinely eerie—unnaturally still, strangely quiet, with a tende

entries.name: The Sulfur Vents
entries.contentPreview: Scattered through the deeper valleys, these thermal vents release steam and sulfurous gases from somewhere far below. The ground around them stays warm year-round, melting snow and supporting patches of unusual vegetation—heat-loving ferns, pale fungi, things that shouldn't grow at this altitude. Some vents are small, barely noticeable. Others form steaming pools or fumaroles that whistle and hiss. The largest cluster sits in a valley the Wardens call the Kettle, which they avoid. Something nest

entries.name: The Old Mines
entries.contentPreview: Before the Windorf, someone else worked these mountains. The evidence remains: abandoned mine shafts, collapsed tunnels, rusted tools of unfamiliar design. The mines sought copper and tin primarily, with traces of silver in the deeper veins. Most are unstable and long-emptied. A few serve as Warden outposts or emergency shelters. Others have been claimed by trolls—the caves suit them. The deepest shafts connect to natural cave systems that no one has fully mapped.

entries.name: Connecting to the Secret Mountains
entries.contentPreview: The Green Mountains blend into the Secret Mountains to the southwest, with no clear boundary between them. The Secret Mountains are smaller, lower, more accessible—but haunted by the legend of the lost halfling goldmine. Prospectors still occasionally venture into the overlap zone, searching for the old workings. Most come back empty-handed. Some don't come back.

entries.name: Travel Advisory
entries.contentPreview: The Windorf don't forbid travel into the Green Mountains, but they don't encourage it either. Anyone heading into the heights should: - Travel in groups of at least four armed individuals - Register their route with the Warden post at Vaken or Nylen - Carry signal flares (the Wardens provide them, for a fee) - Expect the journey to take twice as long as estimated

entries.name: Poum Titch
entries.contentPreview: A Scalawag goblin nation in southeastern Terrenia, wedged between the Green Mountains to the north, Aal Salma to the west, and the coastal waters of Whitefin Bay to the east. For generations, Poum Titch was known for its raucous festivals, its philosopher-poets, and its peculiar dual-capital system—a compromise that kept the peace between the coastal and inland Scalawag factions. That peace is over.

entries.name: The Civil War
entries.contentPreview: A massive civil war has erupted. The northern region has declared independence from the rest of the state, and what began as political grievance has become open slaughter. Armies are assembling. Villages burn. The roads are no longer safe. The causes seem absurd to outsiders: disputes over festival rights, river toll allocations, and which capital gets to host the Philosopher's Congress. But beneath the theatrical grievances lie real fractures—northern Scalawags resent generations of taxation wi

entries.name: Tadinu
entries.contentPreview: The administrative co-capital of Poum Titch, an inland city of limestone warrens and bureaucratic complexity. While Lekia gets the festivals and the glory, Tadinu does the actual work of governance—tax collection, census-keeping, military logistics, and the endless paperwork of running a nation.
