In theory, it's vital to the empire's defense. In practice, nothing ever happens at Ekfusy. The Needle catches everything. Ships that make it past Tarkhetan are already taxed and documented. The eastern fortress exists mostly as insurance against scenarios that never occur.

entries.name: The Worst Posting in Tarkhon
entries.contentPreview: Ekfusy is where careers go to die. The island has nothing. No city, no town, barely any villages—just the fortress, its garrison, and miles of rocky coastline. The nearest entertainment is a fishing hamlet where the locals resent the soldiers. Supply ships come once a month if the weather cooperates. Soldiers assigned to Ekfusy are either being punished, have offended someone powerful, or drew the shortest straw in their regiment. Officers posted here have usually done something to deserve it—th

entries.name: Conditions
entries.contentPreview: The fortress itself is adequate—maintained, defensible, properly supplied. The crown hasn't neglected its physical structure. Everything else is miserable: - No women (the fishing hamlet's daughters learned long ago to stay away from the garrison) - No entertainment beyond gambling and drinking - No advancement opportunities (nothing happens, so there's nothing to distinguish oneself)

entries.name: The Garrison
entries.contentPreview: Roughly 200 soldiers, mostly conscripts and punishment postings. A handful of career soldiers who've resigned themselves to mediocrity. One or two officers hoping to serve their time and escape. The current commander, **Captain Theras Vold**, is a competent man who made enemies in Tarkhetan. He does his job, keeps the fortress functional, and drinks more than is healthy. He'll serve his term and retire, assuming he doesn't drink himself to death first.

entries.name: The One Advantage
entries.contentPreview: Ekfusy is far from politics. No one watches, no one cares, no one interferes. For soldiers who just want to be left alone—for whatever reason—it's oddly peaceful. Some say there are men at Ekfusy with pasts they're running from. The fortress asks no questions. Do your job, keep your head down, and no one from the mainland will bother you.

entries.name: Enymu
entries.contentPreview: The breadbasket of Tarkhon—a farming state that feeds the empire but sees little of the wealth. Bordered by the forbidden Stone Forest to the west and the Wurn Mountains to the north.

entries.name: Position and Borders
entries.contentPreview: Enymu occupies the northeastern portion of Tarkhon's core territory: - **West**: Nektuna (and the Stone Forest on the border) - **North**: The Wurn Mountains (home to the Stone Men) - **East**: Frontier territories, eventually leading to Kerwin - **South**: The Tarkhon Passage (Midton Island and Ekfusy fortress lie offshore)

entries.name: Terrain and Climate
entries.contentPreview: Temperate continental climate—warm summers, cold winters, and reliable rainfall that makes the land excellent for farming. The central lowlands are almost entirely cultivated, a patchwork of grain fields, vegetable plots, and pastures. The terrain rises gradually toward the Wurn Mountains in the north, with rolling hills and sheep pastures in the foothills. The eastern reaches are more forested, providing timber for construction and fuel.

entries.name: Aldrichold
entries.contentPreview: The capital of Enymu, sitting at the junction of the Greenway (the main road to Tarkhetan) and the river that waters the central farmlands. Aldrichold is more large town than true city—perhaps 15,000 people, mostly involved in administration, trade, and supporting the royal household. The palace is a fortified manor house, comfortable but not grand. The Aldric kings have never seen the point of showing off. The town has a central market, several temples (including one to the Evertorch, modestly

entries.name: The Stone Forest
entries.contentPreview: The western border between Enymu and Nektuna is marked by one of Alaria's great mysteries: an entire forest transformed into stone. Every tree stands petrified in perfect detail—bark, branches, leaves, all gray stone. Animals caught in the transformation remain frozen: birds mid-flight, deer mid-leap, a bear eternally rising on its hind legs. The forest is silent except for wind through stone branches. **The Forbidden Zone**: Entry to the Stone Forest is forbidden by ancient pact between Enymu a

entries.name: The Wurn Mountains
entries.contentPreview: The northern border of Enymu is defined by the Wurn Mountains—a range of peaks inhabited by the **Stone Men**, a human subculture with gray, rock-hard skin from generations of elemental exposure. The Stone Men are serious, blunt, and pragmatic. They keep to themselves in their high valleys, herding sheep and goats, trading occasionally with lowland Enymu. Relations are generally peaceful but not warm—the Stone Men find lowlanders soft, and lowlanders find Stone Men unsettling. Occasionally, trou

entries.name: The Greenway
entries.contentPreview: The main road connecting Enymu to Tarkhetan and the rest of Tarkhon. Well-maintained by Enymese standards (which means passable but not paved), the Greenway carries most of the grain, wool, and livestock that flows from Enymu to Nektuna's markets. Traveling the Greenway, you pass through the heart of Enymu's farmland: villages every few miles, fields stretching to the horizon, the occasional fortified manor house where local lords administer their lands.

entries.name: The Craven Communities
entries.contentPreview: Enymu's substantial Craven minority lives throughout the state, but several towns have particularly large populations: - **Stoneheart Vale**: Named for the noble family that rose from Craven commoners, this town in the eastern hills is majority Craven and proud of it. - **Borderwatch**: A town near the Stone Forest staffed largely by Craven Stone Wardens. Unlike in Nektuna, Craven here face no legal discrimination. They farm, trade, serve in the army, and even hold noble titles. Craven from Nekt

entries.name: Relationship with Nektuna
entries.contentPreview: Enymu is loyal to Tarkhon—but that loyalty shouldn't be mistaken for enthusiasm. The relationship is fundamentally exploitative. Enymu produces; Nektuna profits. Enymu's grain feeds Tarkhetan's population, but Nektuna's merchants set the prices. The wealth flows out, and the Enymese see little return. King Aldric IV maintains the relationship because: 1. He genuinely believes King Selron is his friend 2. His ancestors accepted these terms

entries.name: Points of Interest
entries.contentPreview: **The Grain Exchange**: A large warehouse complex in Aldrichold where Enymu's harvest is collected, graded, and sold to Nektuna's merchants. The prices set here determine whether Enymese farmers prosper or merely survive. **The Old Stones**: A ring of standing stones in the northern hills, predating human settlement. The Stone Men consider it sacred. Local Enymese avoid it. **The Warden's Tower**: High Warden Gellert's headquarters, overlooking the Stone Forest from a safe distance. Contains gen

entries.name: Eronia Range
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Fireknife Mountains
entries.contentPreview: Part of the greater Wurmspine range, the Fireknife is a volcanic segment along the northwestern border of Kerwin, marking the boundary between settled Tarkhon territory and the wild lands beyond. Dangerous, unstable, and largely avoided by sensible travelers.

entries.name: Climate and Hazards
entries.contentPreview: The Fireknife creates its own weather. Warm air rising from volcanic vents meets cooler air from the surrounding lands, producing unpredictable fog, sudden rainstorms, and occasionally ash falls when a vent becomes particularly active. Known hazards include: - **Sudden venting**: Fissures can open without warning, releasing superheated gas or magma - **Unstable ground**: What looks like solid rock may be thin crust over hollow chambers - **Toxic air**: Some valleys collect poisonous gases in con

entries.name: The Shrine
entries.contentPreview: Somewhere deep in the Fireknife is a shrine—old, hidden, and hungry. King Ulyas of Kerwin travels there once a year with prisoners and criminals. He returns alone. No one else has found the shrine and returned to speak of it. Whether this is because the shrine is well-hidden or because it doesn't allow witnesses is unclear. The halflings of Kerwin tell stories about the shrine, though they're careful about when and where. Something waits there. Something that predates Tarkhon, predates Kerwin, p

entries.name: Wildlife
entries.contentPreview: The Fireknife supports a harsh ecosystem of creatures adapted to volcanic conditions. Fire-resistant insects, heat-tolerant reptiles, and occasional fire elementals can be found on the slopes. Nothing large survives here—the environment is too hostile for creatures that can't find shelter from sudden venting.

entries.name: Travel
entries.contentPreview: Travel through the Fireknife is possible but inadvisable. A few passes exist that are relatively stable, but "relatively" is doing heavy lifting. Guides who know the current state of the paths can be hired in Kerwin, though they charge substantial fees and refuse to go too deep. No roads cross the Fireknife. Anyone who needs to reach the lands beyond goes around.

entries.name: Relationship to Other Volcanic Ranges
entries.contentPreview: The Fireknife is sometimes confused with the Fleimrut Mountains to the south, which share some volcanic characteristics. However, the Fleimrut is fed by an unstable Yolus leyline and has experienced recent catastrophic eruptions (the Fleimrut Awakening). The Fireknife has no known leyline connection and maintains a more consistent—if still dangerous—level of activity.

entries.name: Fleimrut Mountains
entries.contentPreview: Extremely treacherous. Underground fire-geysers are all over the place. Lots of caves, equally treacherous.

entries.name: The Fleimrut Awakening
entries.contentPreview: The fire-geysers that dominate the mountain range are fed by a Yolus leyline that has never achieved stability. This volatile magical current has made the Fleimrut a zone of perpetual fire hazard, but in 2500 SD, the situation escalated catastrophically. In what scholars and locals call "The Fleimrut Awakening," the geysers erupted with unprecedented violence. Since then, Emberlords and Cinder Swarms pour from the vents with alarming frequency, turning the mountains into an active war zone betwe

entries.name: Fire-Trolls & Elemental Symbiosis
entries.contentPreview: Home to a large population of fire-trolls—trolls attuned to fire and shaped by the mountain's hostile environment. Over generations, these creatures have developed a strange symbiosis with the fire elementals that emerge from the unstable Yolus leyline. Rather than being destroyed by these entities, fire-trolls have learned to coexist with them, developing an unusual cultural and biological relationship. They function as intermediaries between the physical and elemental realms, brokering uneasy

entries.name: Fort Tenze
entries.contentPreview: The cursed ruins of a once-vital fortress on Pyris Island's eastern coast.

entries.name: Position
entries.contentPreview: Fort Tenze guards a secondary chokepoint west of the Needle—not as critical as the main strait, but significant. Ships attempting to bypass Tarkhetan's tariffs by hugging the western coast would pass within range of Fort Tenze's walls. Or they would, if the fortress still functioned.

entries.name: The Curse
entries.contentPreview: Fort Tenze's stones are twisted in ways that shouldn't be possible. Walls that were straight now curve. Stairs lead to nowhere. Rooms that should connect don't. The geometry is subtly, persistently wrong. More disturbing are the effects on people who stay too long: - Workers report whispers in languages they don't understand - Figures appear in peripheral vision—never when looked at directly - Dreams of burning, of being trapped in walls, of fire that doesn't consume but doesn't stop

entries.name: Current State
entries.contentPreview: The fortress is empty of official presence. The Pyrisi avoid it—they tell stories to keep children away. Smugglers use the ruins as a waypoint, taking advantage of the unguarded chokepoint. But even they don't stay long. A few hours to transfer cargo, then gone before nightfall. Nobody sleeps in Fort Tenze. Some say there's a presence in the deepest ruins—where the Neferati commander made his last stand. Treasure hunters occasionally go looking. They rarely come back.

entries.name: Strategic Implications
entries.contentPreview: The absence of Fort Tenze creates a gap in Tarkhon's defenses. Smugglers exploit it. Fast ships can slip through the western passage without paying tariffs. This costs the crown money, but not enough to justify another attempt at rebuilding. Some on the royal council want to try anyway—with priests, exorcists, whatever it takes. Others say the risk isn't worth it. And some whisper that certain parties—smugglers, merchants who profit from contraband, even foreign powers—would prefer Fort Tenze st

entries.name: Gissemari
entries.contentPreview: The artistic heart of the Kingdoms of Fire. Where Yaif preserves tradition and Kabir accumulates wealth, Gissemari creates beauty. The Neferati passion burns here in forges and workshops, producing masterworks that collectors across Alaria pay fortunes to acquire.

entries.name: Position and Borders
entries.contentPreview: Gissemari occupies the southern-central portion of the Neferati peninsula: - **North**: Yaif and Kabir - **South**: Wadiyah - **East and West**: Coastline and the Sea of Merchants The terrain is more varied here than in the other kingdoms—volcanic highlands, fertile valleys, and a coastline of hidden coves and artist retreats.

entries.name: The Flame of the Forge
entries.contentPreview: Gissemari's Eternal Flame burns in the **Great Forge of Gissemari**—not a temple but a working smithy, the largest and oldest in the world. Here, master craftsmen have created legendary works for millennia, their creations heated in fire that has burned since before mortal hands shaped metal. The Great Forge is: - A working facility where master smiths create weapons, jewelry, and art - A sacred site where the flame is tended by priest-smiths who see no distinction between craft and worship - A

entries.name: Terrain and Climate
entries.contentPreview: Moderate by Neferati standards—hot but with reliable rainfall from ocean moisture. The volcanic soil is exceptionally fertile, supporting agriculture that feeds the kingdom's artisan population. The landscape is beautiful: dramatic volcanic peaks, lush valleys, and a coastline that artists have painted for generations. Many believe Gissemari's natural beauty inspires its cultural achievements.

entries.name: Capital: Forgeheart
entries.contentPreview: Built around the Great Forge, Forgeheart is a city of artists, craftsmen, and those who serve them. Every street has workshops. Every plaza has galleries. The air smells of hot metal, exotic woods, and the oils used in painting. **Population**: ~55,000 The city sprawls without plan—buildings added as needed over centuries, creating a maze of streets that locals navigate by landmark and outsiders navigate with difficulty. The architecture ranges from ancient stone structures to experimental desig

entries.name: Prince-Consort Vhelan
entries.contentPreview: Gissemari is technically ruled by **Queen Ishari**, who is seven years old. In practice, her father **Prince-Consort Vhelan** rules as regent—and will continue until Ishari comes of age in a decade. Vhelan is forty-one, an accomplished sculptor in his own right, and utterly uninterested in politics. He married the previous queen for love, not ambition, and found himself regent when she died in childbirth. **Appearance**: Paint-stained hands, distracted expression, horns carved with intricate pat

entries.name: The Artisan Guilds
entries.contentPreview: Real power in Gissemari lies with the guilds that organize its craftsmen: **The Smiths' Brotherhood**: Metalworkers of all kinds, from weaponsmiths to jewelers. The oldest and most prestigious guild, directly connected to the Great Forge. **The Painters' Circle**: Artists working in pigment on any surface. Famous for their fire-portraits that seem to flicker with inner light. **The Sculptors' Academy**: Shapers of stone, metal, and stranger materials. Vhelan rose through their ranks. **The Weave

entries.name: Young Queen Ishari
entries.contentPreview: The nominal ruler of Gissemari is **Queen Ishari**, seven years old and already showing artistic talent—she paints with surprising sophistication for her age. Ishari is bright, curious, and largely unaware of the political complexities surrounding her. Her father shields her from Council matters, wanting her to have a childhood before the burdens of rule. This creates uncertainty. When Ishari comes of age, what kind of ruler will she be? Will she share her father's disinterest in politics? Will

entries.name: The Art Market
entries.contentPreview: Gissemari works command extraordinary prices across Alaria. A Forge-marked blade might cost as much as a small estate. A master painter's portrait might fund a merchant house for a year. This creates economic power of a different kind than Kabir's. Gissemari doesn't trade in volume—it trades in excellence. The wealthy of every kingdom, including Tarkhon's nobility, depend on Gissemari for status symbols. King Selron II has a Gissemari sword. Admiral Kessa Thorn commissioned a Gissemari portrait.

entries.name: Relationship with Other Kingdoms
entries.contentPreview: **With Yaif**: Respectful. Gissemari artists often seek Yaif's blessing for works intended for sacred purposes. The ancient traditions inspire modern creation. **With Kabir**: Mutually beneficial. Kabir's merchants distribute Gissemari works; Kabir's wealth funds Gissemari commissions. Art needs patrons. **With Wadiyah**: Uneasy. Queen Khalira has little patience for art that doesn't serve political ends. Prince-Consort Vhelan finds her intensity exhausting. **With Tarkhon**: Complicated by comm

entries.name: Kabir
entries.contentPreview: The northeastern Kingdom of Fire, facing the Sea of Merchants. The wealthiest of the four kingdoms, built on trade rather than tradition. Where Yaif preserves the past and Gissemari creates beauty, Kabir makes money—and uses that money to maintain Neferati influence in a world that would rather forget them.

entries.name: Position and Borders
entries.contentPreview: Kabir occupies the northeastern portion of the Neferati peninsula: - **West**: Yaif - **South**: Gissemari - **North and East**: The Sea of Merchants, with direct access to major trade routes The coastline is gentler here than in Yaif—natural harbors, sandy beaches between volcanic headlands, and ports that have welcomed traders for millennia.

entries.name: The Flame of the Lighthouse
entries.contentPreview: Kabir's Eternal Flame burns in the **Great Lighthouse of Kabir**—a tower rising from a rocky promontory at the harbor's mouth. The flame has guided ships safely to port since before human memory. It never wavers, never dims, and can be seen from forty miles at sea. The lighthouse is both sacred site and practical infrastructure. The priests who tend it are also harbor pilots, guiding ships through the treacherous approaches. The flame that represents Neferati spirituality also makes Kabir's trad

entries.name: Terrain and Climate
entries.contentPreview: Hot but less arid than Yaif, thanks to sea breezes and more reliable rainfall. The coastal lowlands support intensive agriculture—vegetables, fruits, and the famous Kabiri peppers that burn hotter than any spice known. The interior rises toward volcanic hills shared with Gissemari, but most of Kabir's population clusters along the coast, where the trade is.

entries.name: Capital: Harborflame
entries.contentPreview: The largest city in the Kingdoms of Fire, built around the natural harbor protected by the Great Lighthouse. Harborflame is a bustling commercial center—warehouses, trading houses, shipyards, and markets that never close. **Population**: ~80,000 The city is loud, crowded, and prosperous. Merchants from across Tarkhon and beyond come here to trade, despite the heat that makes non-Neferati miserable. The money is worth the discomfort. Architecture in Harborflame is practical rather than beautiful—

entries.name: King Rashaan
entries.contentPreview: The ruler of Kabir is **King Rashaan**, a merchant-king who built his fortune before inheriting the throne and has continued building it since. Rashaan is fifty-two years old, sharp-minded, and pragmatic to a fault. He believes in profit, stability, and deals that benefit both parties. Ideology bores him. Results matter. **Appearance**: Well-fed but not fat. Expensive clothes in understated styles. Shrewd eyes that calculate the value of everything they see. His horns are decorated with gold cap

entries.name: The Merchant Houses
entries.contentPreview: Kabir's real power lies in its great merchant houses—trading families that have accumulated wealth over generations. The throne can propose, but the merchant houses dispose. No king of Kabir has successfully defied them. Major houses include: **House Emberfin**: Controls shipping and shipbuilding. Their vessels carry goods across the Sea of Merchants. **House Coalgrip**: Dominates the spice trade, particularly Kabiri peppers. Their contracts span continents. **House Ashmarket**: Financiers and m

entries.name: The Money Question
entries.contentPreview: Kabir's wealth creates complicated politics. The kingdom is the most prosperous in the Fire bloc—which means it contributes the most to collective efforts. Kabir funds the Council of Four Flames. Kabir subsidizes Wadiyah when harvests fail. Kabir bankrolls any military buildup the bloc might undertake. This gives Kabir leverage, but also obligation. The other kingdoms resent their dependence on Kabir's money even as they accept it. King Rashaan sometimes wonders if the bloc is alliance or expens

entries.name: Relationship with Tarkhon
entries.contentPreview: Kabir has the closest relationship with Tarkhon of any Fire kingdom—which means the most complicated relationship. The kingdom trades extensively through Tarkhon-controlled ports. Kabiri merchants operate in Tarkhetan. Kabiri ships pay Tarkhon tariffs. The economic ties are deep and profitable for both sides. This makes Kabir reluctant to rock the boat. Any conflict with Tarkhon would devastate Kabiri trade. King Rashaan has worked hard to maintain good relations—so hard that some question where

entries.name: Relationship with Other Kingdoms
entries.contentPreview: **With Yaif**: Distant but respectful. Yaif provides spiritual legitimacy; Kabir provides money. Neither fully approves of the other. **With Gissemari**: Friendly. Kabir funds many Gissemari artists and commissions work for its merchant houses. Art and commerce mix well. **With Wadiyah**: Tense. Queen Khalira calls Rashaan a traitor to Neferati values. Rashaan calls Khalira a fool who will get them all killed. The Council meetings can get heated.

entries.name: The Calculation
entries.contentPreview: King Rashaan is always calculating. Every decision runs through the same analysis: What does this cost? What does it return? What's the risk? He calculates that the Neferati will eventually reclaim Tarkhon—but through economic dominance, not military conquest. In a century, Kabiri money will fund half of Tarkhetan. In two centuries, Kabir might own the throne without ever drawing a sword. Unless Queen Khalira does something stupid first.

entries.name: Kerwin
entries.contentPreview: The northeastern territory of the Tarkhon Empire—though "territory" implies more control than Tarkhon actually exercises. Kerwin is a land of rolling farmland and quiet villages, ruled by an immortal halfling king who predates the empire by centuries.

entries.name: Position and Borders
entries.contentPreview: Kerwin occupies the northeastern corner of Tarkhon's claimed territory, bounded by: - **West**: Enymu and the broader Tarkhon heartland - **Northwest**: The Fireknife Mountains (volcanic, dangerous) - **East and South**: Sparsely populated frontier lands The region sits at the edge of imperial attention—far enough from the strait to be strategically unimportant, close enough to be claimed.

entries.name: Terrain and Climate
entries.contentPreview: Kerwin is semi-arid but fertile enough for farming. The land rolls gently from the Fireknife foothills in the northwest down toward the coastal lowlands. Summers are hot and dry; winters are cold but brief. Rain comes in spring and autumn, enough to sustain wheat, barley, and extensive sheep pastures. The landscape has a faded grandeur—roads too wide for their traffic, bridges built for armies that never came, the bones of imperial ambition overgrown with wildflowers.

entries.name: Tarkha
entries.contentPreview: The capital of Kerwin—an ancient city that predates Tarkhon itself. Tarkha was already old when the Neferati came north. The halflings had built it for their own purposes: wide avenues for their festivals, great plazas for their markets, a palace for kings who expected to rule forever. When Tarkhon absorbed Kerwin five centuries ago, the empire's architects found a city that needed no improvement. Tarkha is grander than most expect from a halfling city. The halflings built it for a king who expe

entries.name: The Fireknife Mountains
entries.contentPreview: A volcanic range along Kerwin's northwestern border, marking the boundary between settled land and wilderness. The Fireknife peaks smoke constantly, their slopes scarred by ancient lava flows and dotted with hot springs. Travel through the mountains is possible but dangerous—paths shift, vents open without warning, and the rock itself is unstable. The halflings avoid the Fireknife. They tell stories of spirits in the peaks, of travelers who entered and never returned, of lights that move against

entries.name: The Copper Hills
entries.contentPreview: Low hills west of Tarkha, their ruddy soil rich with copper ore. The mining town of **Chykum** extracts enough copper to supply Kerwin's modest needs and trade surplus to Tarkhon merchants. The hills are older than the halflings—older than Tarkhon. Ancient mine shafts riddle the deeper hills, their origins unknown. Halfling miners occasionally break through into these old workings. They find strange tools, stranger carvings, and sometimes things best left undisturbed. A sensible miner seals such

entries.name: Da Sharma
entries.contentPreview: The southern region of Kerwin, where farmland gives way to sheep pastures and the influence of Tarkha fades. Da Sharma is insular, traditional, and faintly suspicious of outsiders—including halflings from northern Kerwin. The people here maintain old shrines to spirits that predate Tarkhon, predate Kerwin, predate perhaps the halflings themselves. They light candles on certain nights, leave offerings at certain stones, and speak certain names only in whispers. When asked about these practices, t

entries.name: Relationship to Tarkhon
entries.contentPreview: Kerwin is nominally part of the Tarkhon Empire. In practice, this means: - Kerwin pays modest tribute to Tarkhetan - Tarkhon merchants travel freely through Kerwin - Kerwin acknowledges the emperor's theoretical sovereignty What it does not mean:

entries.name: The Neferati Memory
entries.contentPreview: Ulyas remembers the Neferati founders—the fire-blooded conquerors who came north and built Tarkhetan. He remembers when they negotiated Kerwin's entry into the empire, promising autonomy in exchange for tribute. He remembers their emperors, their court intrigues, their slow dilution into humanity. He also remembers the Severance—the civil war that ended Neferati rule. Kerwin stayed neutral, which is why it still exists. Ulyas watched both sides burn each other while his halflings tended their sh

entries.name: Midton
entries.contentPreview: A small, rocky island in the eastern Tarkhon Passage, home to Ekfusy fortress and little else.

entries.name: Population
entries.contentPreview: Midton has no real population. A fishing hamlet of perhaps fifty souls clings to the southern coast, their ancestors presumably stranded here generations ago and too stubborn to leave. They catch fish, curse the wind, and avoid the soldiers. The fortress garrison adds another 200, but they don't count—they're temporary, rotating in and out on tours of duty, counting the days until they can leave.

entries.name: Strategic Value
entries.contentPreview: Midton's only importance is its position. Ships entering the Tarkhon Passage from the east must pass within sight of the island. Ekfusy fortress watches for hostile fleets, pirates, or smugglers. In practice, this matters less than it should. The Needle catches everything. By the time ships reach Midton's longitude, they've already been taxed and documented at Tarkhetan. Ekfusy exists mostly as insurance—a backup that rarely proves necessary.

entries.name: Conditions
entries.contentPreview: Life on Midton is miserable. The island offers nothing: no entertainment, no women, no opportunities. The fishing hamlet resents the garrison. The garrison resents being here. The wind blows constantly. Supply ships visit monthly, weather permitting. Mail is slow. News from Tarkhetan arrives weeks late. For the soldiers stationed here, Midton might as well be another world.

entries.name: The Blessing in Disguise
entries.contentPreview: Some find Midton's isolation appealing. No politics. No intrigues. No one watching, no one caring. For men with pasts they'd rather forget, Midton offers anonymity. The garrison doesn't ask questions. Do your job, keep your head down, serve your time. Whatever you're running from, it won't follow you here.

entries.name: Murth
entries.contentPreview: A dual-mountain state in the Wurmspine range of western Tarkhon, where Rhea scholar-monks and human merchants share an uneasy but enduring partnership. Two cultures, two capitals, one strange nation bound together by underground tunnels and a shared water source.

entries.name: Position and Borders
entries.contentPreview: Murth occupies two mountains and the valleys between them in western Tarkhon: - **North**: Mt. Disyus, home to Eynmore - **South**: Mt. Arn, home to Vastilin - **Northwest**: The Plains of Oblivion (cursed memory-erasing grasslands) - **East**: Mountains leading toward Vogenfeld

entries.name: Mt. Disyus
entries.contentPreview: The northern mountain, rising to heights where human visitors struggle to breathe. The thin air suits the Rhea perfectly—their air-elemental nature finds the altitude comfortable, even preferable. The mountain's upper reaches are carved with monastery complexes, meditation halls, and the ancient libraries of **Eynmore**. Lower slopes support terraced gardens where Rhea cultivate rare alpine herbs. **Features:** - **Eynmore** (capital): Monastery city of the Rhea, population ~8,000 - **The High H

entries.name: Mt. Arn
entries.contentPreview: The southern mountain, lower and warmer than its twin. Rich in iron and copper, Mt. Arn attracted human miners centuries ago—they stayed, built a city, and eventually discovered they had neighbors. **Vastilin** sprawls across the southern slopes: markets, foundries, warehouses, and all the comfortable chaos of human habitation. The mountain's wealth flows through here—both the metals mined from the rock and the services sold from Eynmore above. **Features:** - **Vastilin** (capital): Merchant ci

entries.name: Lake Stillwater
entries.contentPreview: The heart of Murth—an underground lake lying beneath both mountains, fed by glacial melt and ancient aquifers. The water is unnaturally still, unnaturally clear, and unnaturally cold. Lake Stillwater is why Murth exists. A thousand years ago, both communities dug for water and found the same lake. Rather than fight, they negotiated the **Stillwater Compact**: shared access, shared responsibility, connecting tunnels. The lake's shores—such as they are in the underground darkness—host the **Chambe

entries.name: The Murthian Tunnels
entries.contentPreview: Miles of passages connect Eynmore and Vastilin through the mountains, with Lake Stillwater at the center. The tunnels are Murth's circulatory system—trade, communication, and transport all flow through them. **Key Locations:** - **The Stillwater Shore**: Underground lake access, neutral ground - **The Chamber of the Compact**: Meeting hall carved from stone, where the original treaty is inscribed - **The Waystation**: Midpoint rest stop, perpetually staffed

entries.name: Eynmore
entries.contentPreview: The Rhea capital on Mt. Disyus. A city of contemplation, scholarship, and mastery. Eynmore doesn't feel like a city to human visitors—it's too quiet, too orderly, too empty of the bustle that defines urban life. The Rhea don't crowd together; they space themselves for focus. The result is a settlement that seems half-populated even when everyone is present. **Architecture**: Carved from mountain stone, elegant but austere. Buildings are integrated into the rock rather than imposed upon it. Open

entries.name: Vastilin
entries.contentPreview: The human capital on Mt. Arn. A city of commerce, craft, and comfortable excess. Vastilin is everything Eynmore isn't—loud, crowded, messy, alive. Markets compete for attention. Foundries pour smoke. Taverns overflow. It's a proper city, even if it's built on a mountainside in the middle of nowhere. **Architecture**: Practical construction in local stone, expanded piecemeal over centuries. The city has no plan—buildings were added where needed, creating a maze of streets that locals navigate by

entries.name: The Plains of Oblivion
entries.contentPreview: Northwest of Murth, beyond the mountains' protection, lie cursed grasslands where memory dissolves. Travelers who enter forget—first recent events, then learned skills, then eventually who they are. The plains creep closer to Murth some years, retreat others. No pattern has been found. The cause is unknown—perhaps ancient magic, perhaps something worse. **Satyrn Gray**, the palace of **Queen Eranes**, stands somewhere in those plains. Eranes is a half-titan of immense power who deliberately forg

entries.name: Relationship with Tarkhon
entries.contentPreview: Murth is technically part of the Tarkhon Empire, paying tribute to Tarkhetan. In practice, the relationship is distant. Murth has nothing Tarkhon urgently wants—no strategic position, no vital resources, no threat worth addressing. The tribute payments are modest. The imperial presence is minimal. Tarkhon has bigger concerns. This suits Eynmore perfectly. The Rhea want to be forgotten by empires. This frustrates Vastilin somewhat. The merchants would welcome deeper integration—more trade, more m

entries.name: Points of Interest
entries.contentPreview: **The Breath Gate**: Where Eynmore's thin air meets the tunnel's thicker atmosphere. Human visitors pause here to acclimatize before ascending. Rhea visitors pause to enjoy the last comfortable air before descending. **The Market of Whispers**: A trading post in the tunnel system where Rhea and human merchants meet to negotiate. Named for the Rhea habit of speaking softly—and for the secrets that change hands here. **The Monastery of the Empty Hand**: Where Master Stonefist trains martial monks

entries.name: Nektuna
entries.contentPreview: The imperial heartland of the Tarkhon Empire, controlling both shores of the Needle—the strait's narrowest point and the key to everything.

entries.name: Position and Borders
entries.contentPreview: Nektuna occupies the central position in Tarkhon's territory: - **North**: Enymu (agricultural tributary) - **South**: The strait itself, with Astrelle (vassal) on the opposite shore - **West**: Pyris Island (controlled territory) - **East**: The broader Tarkhon Passage, narrowing toward Eros

entries.name: Terrain and Climate
entries.contentPreview: Warm Mediterranean climate with mild winters and hot, dry summers. The land rises from the harbor in a series of hills, each topped with fortifications or noble estates. Olive groves and vineyards cover the slopes outside the city walls. The coastline alternates between rocky cliffs and protected harbors. Tarkhetan occupies the best natural harbor on the strait, which is why it became the capital.

entries.name: Tarkhetan
entries.contentPreview: The capital of the Tarkhon Empire, built on hills overlooking the Needle. From the palace walls, you can see clear across to Torsnerhun fortress on the Astrelle shore. The city is divided into districts by elevation and wealth: **The Old City** — The highest hills. Noble estates, the royal palace, the great cathedral where the Evertorch burns. Wealth, power, and ancient blood. **The Middle City** — Lower slopes. Merchant houses, guild halls, the homes of successful craftsmen. Where business happ

entries.name: The Evertorch Cathedral
entries.contentPreview: The great cathedral at Tarkhetan's heart, where the Evertorch has burned without interruption for six centuries. The flame is the empire's holiest symbol—rulers are crowned in its light, the most binding oaths are sworn before it. The Neferati founders brought sacred fire north from Yaif and kindled it here when they established Tarkhetan. It has never moved. The cathedral was built around it, growing grander over centuries as the empire grew wealthy. The cathedral is also a center of fire magic

entries.name: The Fire Leyline
entries.contentPreview: A leyline of fire runs beneath Tarkhetan, concentrated under the Old City. Children born here sometimes manifest fire attunement—and those who do are claimed by the Firemage Corps. The Corps' Citadel of Flames sits on the leyline's strongest point, training mages who can burn ships from the city walls.

entries.name: Besnoumeru
entries.contentPreview: Nektuna's second city, built on a **time leyline**. The Oracle Merchants born here can sense market changes before they happen—not prophecy, but an instinct for timing that has made Besnoumeru almost as wealthy as Tarkhetan. The city has an eerie calm. Nobody rushes. The merchants already know what's coming.

entries.name: Pyris Island
entries.contentPreview: A moderate-sized island southwest of the strait. Home to the Pyrisi—stocky, hardy folk descended from human-dwarf interbreeding over centuries. They're farmers and fishers who want to be left alone. The island includes a town and several villages in the north, supporting a modest population that pays taxes and provides sailors for the navy.

entries.name: Fort Tenze (Ruined)
entries.contentPreview: On Pyris's eastern coast stand the ruins of Fort Tenze, guardian of a secondary chokepoint. The fortress has been abandoned for nearly three centuries, ever since the **Severance**—the civil war that ended Neferati rule. During the Severance, Fort Tenze's garrison sided with the Neferati faction. When they lost, something went wrong. The fortress burned with unnatural fire that left the stones themselves twisted. The wrongness never left. Three attempts to rebuild have failed. Workers suffer acc

entries.name: The Harbor
entries.contentPreview: Tarkhetan's harbor is the busiest port in the region. Ships from across Alaria arrive and depart at all hours, their cargoes taxed, inspected, and sent onward. The harbor is protected by both geography (natural breakwaters, defensible approaches) and magic (firemages on the walls can burn any hostile fleet). This combination makes Tarkhetan's harbor essentially unassailable by naval attack.

entries.name: The Needle
entries.contentPreview: The narrowest point of the Tarkhon Passage—perhaps half a mile of water between Tarkhetan's walls and Torsnerhun fortress on the Astrelle shore. Nothing passes the Needle without Tarkhetan's permission. Firemages on both shores can burn ships attempting to run the strait. The navy patrols constantly. Even if a ship somehow slipped through, the fortresses further east would catch it. This chokepoint is everything. Tarkhon's wealth, power, and existence depend on maintaining absolute control of th

entries.name: Relationships
entries.contentPreview: **With Astrelle**: Vassal state across the Needle. Astrelle hosts Torsnerhun fortress, making it strategically vital. The current Duchess Ysmera is also the queen's aunt—family ties complicate the overlord-vassal relationship. **With Enymu**: Loyal tributary to the north. Provides food, conscripts, and access to the Stone Forest border. The honorable kings of Enymu have never given Nektuna trouble. **With Kerwin**: Distant and nominal. King Ulyas pays tribute but effectively governs himself. He

entries.name: Pebble Islands
entries.contentPreview: A group of islands in Tarkhon. TODO

entries.name: Pyris
entries.contentPreview: A moderate-sized island southwest of the Tarkhon Strait, part of Nektuna's territory. Home to the Pyrisi—a hardy, independent folk who want nothing more than to be left alone—and the cursed ruins of Fort Tenze.

entries.name: The Pyrisi
entries.contentPreview: The island's population descends from centuries of interbreeding between humans and dwarves—a mixing that occurred long before anyone thought to record it. The result is a people who are stocky, hardy, and stubborn. The Pyrisi are primarily farmers and fishers. They grow olives and grapes, catch fish, and want to be left alone. They pay their taxes to Tarkhetan, send their young to serve in the navy, and otherwise try not to attract attention. They have little interest in mainland politics. When

entries.name: Fort Tenze
entries.contentPreview: On the island's eastern coast stand the ruins of **Fort Tenze**, once a vital fortress guarding the western approaches to the strait. Fort Tenze has been abandoned for three centuries, ever since the Severance—the civil war that ended Neferati rule. The garrison sided with the losing faction. When the victors came to take the fortress, something went wrong. The place burned with unnatural fire and has been cursed ever since. Three attempts to rebuild have failed. Workers suffer accidents, disapp

entries.name: Strategic Position
entries.contentPreview: Pyris guards a secondary chokepoint—not as critical as the Needle, but significant. Ships hugging the western coast to avoid Tarkhetan's tariffs must pass within range of... well, where Fort Tenze's walls used to be. The fortress's absence creates a gap in Tarkhon's defenses. Smugglers exploit it. The crown knows but hasn't successfully addressed the problem.

entries.name: Relationship with Tarkhetan
entries.contentPreview: Pyris is technically part of Nektuna, governed from Tarkhetan. In practice, the island largely governs itself. A minor noble holds the title of Governor of Pyris—usually someone being quietly exiled from court politics—and the Pyrisi ignore them as much as possible. The island pays taxes, provides sailors, and hosts the cursed ruins of a fortress nobody wants to rebuild. In exchange, Tarkhetan mostly leaves them alone. It's not a bad arrangement. The Pyrisi have survived worse.

entries.name: Sea of Merchants
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Tarkhetan
entries.contentPreview: The capital city of the Tarkhon Empire. TODO

entries.name: Tarkhon Empire
entries.contentPreview: The dominant empire of the Tarkhon region, controlling the critical strait between the Middle Sea and the western ocean.

entries.name: The Evertorch
entries.contentPreview: In Tarkhetan's great cathedral burns the **Evertorch**—an eternally burning flame that has never been extinguished since its lighting centuries ago. The torch is Tarkhon's most sacred symbol, representing the empire's eternal dominion and unbroken continuity. The flame burns without fuel, without maintenance, without apparent source. Scholars have studied it for generations without understanding how it works. Some believe it's fed by a leyline. Others think it's a divine gift. A few whisper that

entries.name: Tarkhetan
entries.contentPreview: The capital of the Tarkhon Empire, built on the northern shore of the strait. Tarkhetan is a city of extremes—fabulous wealth alongside desperate poverty, gleaming palaces beside rotting slums, merchant princes who could buy kingdoms and beggars who will never own anything. The city's power comes from position, not production. Every ship that passes through the strait pays tribute. Every merchant who wants access to Tarkhon markets pays fees. The city produces little itself but takes a cut of ev

entries.name: The Strait
entries.contentPreview: The narrow passage connecting the Middle Sea to the western ocean. Ships can cross it in hours, but those hours pass under the watchful eyes of Tarkhon's navy and the burning gaze of its firemages. The strait is everything. Without it, Tarkhon is just another middling power. With it, Tarkhon controls half the world's trade. This makes the empire both fabulously wealthy and desperately paranoid. Any threat to the strait is an existential threat to the empire itself.

entries.name: Leylines
entries.contentPreview: Tarkhon's territory contains several important leylines: - **Fire Leyline**: Runs through Nektuna and Tarkhetan, producing the firemages who serve as the empire's elite military asset - **Time Leyline**: Runs through Besnoumeru, enabling the city's famous merchants to anticipate market changes before they happen - **Yolus Leyline**: Runs through the Fleimrut Mountains, unstable and dangerous, responsible for the Fleimrut Awakening

entries.name: The Imperial Legacy
entries.contentPreview: The Neferati founders understood from the beginning that controlling the strait meant controlling trade. They built Tarkhetan on the Needle, lit the Evertorch, and established an empire based on commerce rather than conquest. For nearly three centuries, Neferati emperors—or their increasingly diluted descendants—ruled from Tarkhetan. They expanded through trade agreements and tributary arrangements, absorbing states like Kerwin through negotiation rather than war. Then came the Severance, and hu

entries.name: The Rash
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Vogenfeld
entries.contentPreview: The northern shield of Tarkhon—three Uline dwarf settlements in the Wurmspine Mountains between the empire and the orcish hordes of Hedroscobb. For centuries, the dwarves have held the passes. For centuries, they've watched the Wildwood. And for decades now, they've wondered why they bother.

entries.name: Position and Borders
entries.contentPreview: Vogenfeld occupies a stretch of mountains at Tarkhon's northern frontier: - **North**: The Wildwood and the orcish territories of Hedroscobb (Glivornax most directly) - **South**: Open land leading to Tarkhon proper - **East**: The Wurn Mountains and Stone Men territory - **West**: More mountains, eventually leading to Murth

entries.name: Terrain and Climate
entries.contentPreview: The surface is harsh alpine terrain—jagged peaks, narrow passes, treacherous in winter. Snow lies on the highest peaks year-round. The passes are barely navigable even in summer. The dwarves don't live on the surface. They live *in* the mountains, in vast tunnel complexes carved over millennia. The tunnels maintain comfortable temperatures year-round, ventilated by the elaborate chain-operated air systems that give Uline dwarves their nickname.

entries.name: The Three Settlements
entries.contentPreview: **Atlangsow** — Western, largest (~5,000) Built into a mountain overlooking the main pass between Tarkhon and the Wildwood. The great gates of Atlangsow have never fallen to enemy assault. The tunnels extend miles into the mountain, with forges, living quarters, mushroom farms, and endless passages. The Council of Thanes meets here most often. Thane Gorveth, the eldest of the three thanes, makes his home in the deep chambers. **Kaisa** — Central (~4,000) Smaller on the surface, but Kaisa's tunne

entries.name: The Pass of Oaths
entries.contentPreview: The main route through the mountains, overlooked by Atlangsow's gates. This is where the Vogenfeld Pact was sworn five centuries ago—where dwarven thanes and Tarkhon's representatives agreed that Vogenfeld would guard the north in exchange for tribute and honor. Stone monuments line the pass, carved with the names of dwarves who died holding this ground. Thousands of names. Generations of sacrifice. The monuments are maintained perfectly. The dwarves remember, even if Tarkhon has forgotten.

entries.name: The Tunnel Networks
entries.contentPreview: The official maps show the main passages—routes for trade, travel, and defense. These are impressive enough: miles of tunnels connecting the three settlements, forges and armories, living quarters and meeting halls. The unofficial maps show much more. Secret tunnels extend in every direction. Emergency passages connect the settlements through routes no enemy would find. Hidden exits emerge throughout the mountains—some facing south toward Tarkhon, others facing north toward the Wildwood. The nor

entries.name: The Patrols
entries.contentPreview: Every day, Vogenfeld sends patrols into the Wildwood's edge. Small groups of warriors, moving quietly, watching for signs of orcish movement. They look for: - Unusual gatherings of orc warriors - Signs that tribal conflicts have paused - Any indication of coordination between the six great tribes

entries.name: The Council of Thanes
entries.contentPreview: **Thane Gorveth of Atlangsow** (eldest) Over two hundred years old, Gorveth remembers when Tarkhon still paid proper tribute. He remembers his grandfather's stories of the last great invasion. He counsels patience because he's seen what orc armies can do and knows that Vogenfeld's duty is real, regardless of Tarkhon's failures. But patience has limits. Even Gorveth's. **Thane Brunhild of Kaisa** One hundred seventy years old, Brunhild is a warrior-thane who has personally led patrols into the Wi

entries.name: The Orcish Threat
entries.contentPreview: North of Vogenfeld lies **Hedroscobb**—the Wildwood, an endless forest inhabited by six great orcish tribal states and countless smaller bands. The six great tribes: - **Hedroscobb** — Directly north, the black orcs with their corrosive iron armor; the closest and largest threat - **Glivornax** — Beyond Hedroscobb to the northwest, the most diplomatically sophisticated; they guard the healing waters - **Tarn** — North-central, controlling a stretch of the Grand Tolkarsus river; spirit warriors w

entries.name: Relationship with Tarkhon
entries.contentPreview: The relationship is broken but not yet severed. Vogenfeld still receives tribute from Tarkhetan—but the payments are a fraction of what they once were, delivered with contempt rather than gratitude. Young officials in Tarkhetan openly question why the empire pays "those mountain dwarves" at all. The dwarves still patrol, still watch, still maintain the passes. But the question of how long this continues grows louder every year. Three possible futures: 1. Tarkhon remembers its obligations, restor

entries.name: What Lies Beneath
entries.contentPreview: The Uline didn't just fight surface threats. The monsters of the deep—shadereavers and worse—have always threatened the tunnels. Vogenfeld's warriors train against these creatures as much as against orcs. The iron blades and hammers they carry are designed for close-quarters tunnel fighting, for enemies that come from below as well as above. This means Vogenfeld's forces are uniquely versatile. They can fight on the surface in mountain terrain. They can fight underground in absolute darkness. Th

entries.name: Wadiyah
entries.contentPreview: The southernmost and most isolated of the Kingdoms of Fire. While other kingdoms counsel patience, accommodation, or indifference, Wadiyah remembers the Severance with burning anger. Queen Khalira believes the time for waiting has ended. The fire kingdoms should reclaim what is theirs—and if the other monarchs won't act, Wadiyah will.

entries.name: Position and Borders
entries.contentPreview: Wadiyah occupies the southern tip of the Neferati peninsula: - **North**: Gissemari - **South, East, and West**: Open ocean The most isolated of the four kingdoms, separated from the others by mountains and distance. This isolation has bred independence—and resentment.

entries.name: The Flame of the Abyss
entries.contentPreview: Wadiyah's Eternal Flame burns in the **Pit of First Fire**—not a temple or a lighthouse or a forge, but a volcanic vent where fire emerges directly from the earth's molten heart. The Pit is a natural phenomenon that has burned since before life existed on Alaria. The flame rises from a shaft so deep that none have seen its bottom. Priests who tend the Pit say it connects to the world's core—that this is not merely an eternal flame but the source of all fire, the heat that keeps the world alive.

entries.name: Terrain and Climate
entries.contentPreview: The harshest of the four kingdoms—volcanic soil, limited rainfall, and thermal vents that make parts of the landscape literally uninhabitable. The population clusters in the few areas where the earth's heat doesn't seep through. The southern coast is dramatic: black volcanic cliffs dropping into crashing waves, geysers of steam rising from the water where hot rock meets cold ocean, and the ever-present smell of sulfur. Outsiders find Wadiyah uncomfortable at best, dangerous at worst. The Wadiyan

entries.name: Capital: Abyssward
entries.contentPreview: Built on the rim of the volcanic basin that contains the Pit of First Fire, Abyssward is a city that exists in constant awareness of the fire below. **Population**: ~30,000 The city is smaller and poorer than the other Neferati capitals. Resources are scarce; the land doesn't support large populations. What Abyssward lacks in wealth, it makes up in intensity. The architecture is stark—dark volcanic stone, minimal ornamentation, buildings designed to withstand earthquakes and eruptions. Beauty he

entries.name: Queen Khalira
entries.contentPreview: The ruler of Wadiyah is **Queen Khalira**, thirty-four years old and the most dangerous person in the Kingdoms of Fire. Khalira is passionate even by Neferati standards—fierce, impatient, and absolutely convinced that the time for patience has ended. Three centuries of waiting has achieved nothing. The humans still hold the Evertorch. The Severance wounds still fester. Something must be done. **Appearance**: Striking rather than beautiful. Bright red skin that seems to genuinely flicker with inn

entries.name: The Cult of the Abyss
entries.contentPreview: Wadiyah's priesthood differs from other kingdoms. Where Yaif's priests preserve tradition and Gissemari's priest-smiths create, Wadiyah's **Cult of the Abyss** serves a fire they cannot control. The Cult teaches that the Pit's fire is the truest form of flame—wild, untamed, and hungry. Other eternal flames have been domesticated, put to human purposes. The Pit remains pure. To serve it is to accept that some forces cannot be controlled, only honored. This theology shapes Wadiyah's politics. If f

entries.name: The Growing Crisis
entries.contentPreview: Khalira is losing patience with the Council's caution. She's begun making independent moves: - Establishing contacts with Tarkhon's enemies - Stockpiling weapons beyond defensive needs - Sending agents to Tarkhetan to gather intelligence

entries.name: Relationship with Other Kingdoms
entries.contentPreview: **With Yaif**: Strained. Queen Seraphel has spent years trying to moderate Khalira. Khalira has lost respect for what she sees as Yaif's ossified caution. **With Kabir**: Hostile. Khalira openly calls King Rashaan a collaborator and a coward. Rashaan calls her a danger to everyone. They can barely speak civilly. **With Gissemari**: Cold. Prince-Consort Vhelan's artistic focus seems frivolous to Khalira. She has no use for beauty that doesn't serve the cause. **With Tarkhon**: None. Wadiyah has n

entries.name: What Happens Next
entries.contentPreview: Khalira is preparing for something. The signs are unmistakable: - Military buildup beyond defensive needs - Secret contacts with unknown parties - Rhetoric growing more inflammatory - Withdrawal from Council consensus

entries.name: Wurm Tooth Mountain
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Wurn Mountains
entries.contentPreview: Part of the greater Wurmspine range, the Wurn Mountains form Enymu's northern border. Home to the Stone Men—a human subculture whose gray, rock-hard skin marks generations of elemental exposure. Switzerland vibes: alpine meadows, dramatic peaks, isolated valleys, and a people who want to be left alone.

entries.name: Climate
entries.contentPreview: Alpine conditions prevail above the tree line: harsh winters, brief summers, unpredictable weather. Snow can fall any month of the year in the highest reaches. The lower valleys are more temperate—cold in winter but capable of supporting grazing and limited agriculture. This is where most Stone Men settlements are located.

entries.name: The Stone Men
entries.contentPreview: The Stone Men are a human subculture who have lived in the Wurn Mountains for countless generations. Their most distinctive feature is their skin: gray, rough, and hard as rock—a result of prolonged elemental exposure that has become hereditary. **Appearance**: Gray skin with a texture like weathered stone. Otherwise human in form, though often stocky and powerfully built. Their eyes are usually pale—gray, blue, or occasionally colorless. **Culture**: The Stone Men are serious, blunt, and pragma

entries.name: Relations with Enymu
entries.contentPreview: The relationship between the Stone Men and lowland Enymu is... complicated. **Trade**: Regular, though not warm. Stone Men bring wool, cheese, and mountain herbs to lowland markets. They buy metal tools, grain, and the occasional luxury. Both sides benefit, but neither pretends to like each other. **Trouble**: Occasionally, Stone Men bands raid lowland farms—usually young warriors proving themselves, sometimes organized groups seeking wealth. Enymu's army responds, there's fighting, eventually n

entries.name: The Old Stones
entries.contentPreview: A ring of massive standing stones in the central mountains, predating any known civilization. The Stone Men consider this site sacred, gathering here for important ceremonies, dispute resolution, and the election of their informal leaders. Lowland Enymese are not welcome at the Old Stones. Those who have trespassed have been turned back—forcefully if necessary. What exactly happens at Stone Men ceremonies is unknown to outsiders. Some scholars believe the Old Stones are connected to the titan cr

entries.name: What Lies Beyond
entries.contentPreview: The Wurn Mountains form the northern boundary of Tarkhon's sphere of influence. Beyond them lie: - Territories not claimed by any major power - Eventually, the lands leading toward Hedroscobb and the six orcish tribal states - Vogenfeld's dwarven defenders, watching the northern frontier The Stone Men consider themselves the first line of defense against whatever might come from the north. This is partly why they maintain warrior traditions despite their pastoral lifestyle. They remember times w

entries.name: Wildlife
entries.contentPreview: The Wurn Mountains support diverse alpine wildlife: - Mountain sheep and goats (both wild and domesticated) - Eagles and other raptors - Mountain lions and wolves - Bears in the lower forests

entries.name: Yaif
entries.contentPreview: The westernmost of the Kingdoms of Fire, and the oldest. Home to the Flame of First Fire, the Temple of Origins, and the ancient traditions that define Neferati identity. If the other kingdoms are the children of fire, Yaif is the mother.

entries.name: Position and Borders
entries.contentPreview: Yaif occupies the western portion of the Neferati peninsula: - **East**: Kabir - **South**: Gissemari - **North and West**: The Sea of Merchants and open ocean The coastline is dramatic—volcanic cliffs dropping into deep water, with natural harbors carved by ancient lava flows. The interior rises toward a central volcanic plateau where the Temple of First Fire stands.

entries.name: The Flame of First Fire
entries.contentPreview: At Yaif's heart burns the oldest of the Eternal Flames—the **Flame of First Fire**. According to Neferati tradition, this is the original flame from which all others were kindled, burning since before the world had names. The flame burns in the **Temple of First Fire**, a massive structure carved from volcanic rock on the central plateau. The temple complex includes: - The Flame Chamber itself (accessible only to priests and monarchs) - The Hall of Origins (where the founding of Tarkhon is comme

entries.name: Terrain and Climate
entries.contentPreview: Hot and arid, even by Neferati standards. The volcanic soil is rich but water is scarce. Agriculture depends on careful irrigation from the few rivers that flow from the central highlands. The landscape is dominated by dark volcanic rock, ancient lava flows now weathered into strange formations, and the ever-present heat that rises from the ground. Visitors from cooler climates find Yaif nearly unbearable. The Neferati find it comfortable.

entries.name: Capital: Ashenheart
entries.contentPreview: Yaif's capital is built into the slopes of an extinct volcano, its buildings carved from the same dark stone that surrounds it. The architecture is ancient—some structures predate recorded history—and the streets follow paths worn by thousands of years of feet. **Population**: ~40,000 Ashenheart is a city of temples, shrines, and sacred sites. More priests per capita than any other city in Tarkhon. The spiritual heart of Neferati culture. The city is quieter than outsiders expect. Where other Ne

entries.name: Queen Seraphel
entries.contentPreview: The ruler of Yaif is **Queen Seraphel**, who has sat the throne for sixty-three years—longer than any other current Neferati monarch. Seraphel is old by Neferati standards—nearly eighty—but her mind remains sharp and her patience is legendary. She has seen kings rise and fall in Tarkhetan, watched empires rise and fall beyond the sea, and waited while the Kingdoms of Fire debated their future. **Appearance**: Withered but dignified. Her red skin has faded to a deep rust, her horns have grown lon

entries.name: The Priesthood of First Fire
entries.contentPreview: Yaif's most powerful institution isn't the throne—it's the priesthood that tends the Flame of First Fire. The **High Priest of Origins** holds a position nearly equal to the queen's. The priesthood controls access to the flame, interprets sacred traditions, and advises on matters of spiritual significance. No major decision in Yaif is made without their blessing. Current High Priest: **Ashvareth**, an ancient Neferati who claims to have personally witnessed the founding of Tarkhon. Whether this

entries.name: The Question of the Evertorch
entries.contentPreview: More than any other kingdom, Yaif feels the loss of the Evertorch. The flame in Tarkhetan was kindled from Yaif's fire. When Neferati priests visit Tarkhetan, they can tell—the Evertorch burns with the same light as the Flame of First Fire. It's a piece of Yaif, stolen and never returned. Queen Seraphel has never publicly demanded the Evertorch's return. But the priesthood of Yaif holds detailed records of exactly how the flame was taken, exactly who took it, and exactly what promises were made.

entries.name: Relationship with Other Kingdoms
entries.contentPreview: **With Kabir**: Respectful but distant. Yaif finds Kabir's commercial focus vulgar; Kabir finds Yaif's traditionalism stifling. **With Gissemari**: Friendly. The artists of Gissemari often seek Yaif's blessing for their works, and Yaif appreciates beauty that honors tradition. **With Wadiyah**: Tense. Queen Khalira's radicalism alarms Yaif's conservative establishment. Seraphel has spent considerable effort restraining Wadiyah's impulses. **With Tarkhon**: Cold. Yaif remembers everything. They p

entries.name: Boundaries and Position
entries.contentPreview: - **North**: The Eronia Range forms the northern boundary, separating Westrim from the Tarkhon Empire. This mountain range includes several smaller ranges home to dwarven city-states. - **East**: Transitions into the Innerrim jungle basin - **South**: The Ishnit Jungles wrap around the southern edge of the Dunes of Kunagi - **Southwest**: The Agreben Sea and the Greenwater Isles - **West**: The Western Isles lie offshore; the state of Mueras occupies the western coastal region

entries.name: Dunes of Kunagi
entries.contentPreview: The dominant feature of Westrim—a vast, kidney-shaped desert of golden sand stretching across the interior. Home to giant sand wurms reminiscent of *Dune*. The only reliable water source for hundreds of miles is Benshu's Promise, an oasis guarded by a deadly sphinx who demands riddles be answered before any may drink.

entries.name: Ishnit Jungles
entries.contentPreview: Covering the entire southern side of the Dunes of Kunagi, the Ishnit Jungles are among the most dangerous wilderness areas in Alaria. Home to the Naruaghin people and countless deadly monsters. Notable locations include: - **Ekomorn**: A rift extending to the center of the material plane, feared by all - **Demonwatch**: A darkstone palace on the southern cape, overrun by confined but immortal demons

entries.name: Eronia Range
entries.contentPreview: The northern mountain barrier, home to multiple dwarven city-states nestled among the peaks. These mountains catch moisture from the north, contributing to the rain shadow that creates the Dunes of Kunagi.

entries.name: Surrounding Seas
entries.contentPreview: - **Agreben Sea**: Southwest of Westrim, south of Mueras, west of the Ishnit Jungles - **Gulf of Norag**: South of the Ishnit Jungles

entries.name: Husakas
entries.contentPreview: A desert region in the southwest Dunes of Kunagi, roamed by scorpion riders who have adapted to the harsh conditions. The water here carries a terrible curse—drinking causes complete loss of long-term memory. This has shaped the Husakas people's entire culture around memory preservation and scorpion symbiosis. See the full [Husakas](Husakas.md) entry for the scorpion rider culture, the Twice-Born, and notable locations.

entries.name: House of the Scorpion
entries.contentPreview: A half-buried palace in northern Husakas where the Prince of Scorpions dwells—a tragic, transformed figure who maintains all scorpions in the desert. The Husakas make bicentennial pilgrimages here, trading memories for the continued survival of their bonded mounts. See the full [House of the Scorpion](House%20of%20the%20Scorpion.md) entry for the Prince, the pilgrimage ritual, and why killing him would be catastrophic.

entries.name: Gyerekas
entries.contentPreview: The fossil reef hills marking Husakas's southern boundary—ancient coral formations and the bones of creatures from a vanished sea. The Husakas call it the Bone Garden. It serves as neutral trading ground and contains dangerous cave systems leading into unknown depths. See the full [Gyerekas](Gyerekas.md) entry for the reef's resources, the Leviathan's Rest, and the Dwellers Below.

entries.name: Spotted Forest
entries.contentPreview: Where the Dunes of Kunagi surrender to the savanna, the land fractures into scattered oases—the Spotted Forest. A patchwork of verdant islands fed by underground springs, home to the Spotted Ones (mixed Husakas-Chule descent) who serve as intermediaries between desert and grassland cultures. See the full [Spotted Forest](Spotted%20Forest.md) entry for the oasis ecology, trading crossroads, and current tensions.

entries.name: Mueras
entries.contentPreview: The westernmost state of Rimihuica, Mueras occupies a stretch of brutally fragmented coastline where the land has shattered against the sea. Cliff-walled islands, treacherous channels, and hidden harbors define this region—geography that created the merchant-king oligarchy. Those who know the waters control the trade; those who control the trade rule Mueras. The coast runs roughly 400 miles north to south, from the Mueras Highlands and Hammer Coast in the north to the Beak of Mueras peninsula in

entries.name: Atriik
entries.contentPreview: A confederation of four city-states in southwestern Westrim, occupying the territory between the Milras Forest (north), the Dunes of Kunagi (east), the Bloodlands and Ishnit Jungles (south), and Shark Bay (west). The Kor and Sharabha peoples here share a culture of elaborate courtesy that masks constant political maneuvering. Key features include: - **The City-States**: Lupuno, Byonowidi, Shinii, and Wykakas—three Kor monarchies and one Sharabha - **Mykala**: A ruined fortress at the base of a c

entries.name: Atriik
entries.contentPreview: A confederation of four city-states in southwestern Westrim, wedged between the Milras Forest to the north, the Dunes of Kunagi to the east, the Bloodlands and Ishnit Jungles to the south, and Shark Bay to the west. Atriik is not a unified nation but a loose alliance of Kor and Sharabha monarchies bound by shared culture, mutual defense, and elaborate courtesy that masks constant low-grade political maneuvering. The land here transitions from the deep forests of the north through savanna and scr

entries.name: Lupuno
entries.contentPreview: The northwestern city-state, built where the Sha Puniki emerges from the Milras Forest. Lupuno controls the timber trade from the forest edge and the river traffic heading south. The Kor monarchy here has the closest ties to Kura and the northern states. **Population**: ~18,000

entries.name: Byonowidi
entries.contentPreview: The western city-state and Atriik's only Sharabha monarchy. Located on the Sha Ulokoni near the edge of Sprenwood, Byonowidi is the confederation's fur-trading heart. Sharabha cavalry from Byonowidi are renowned across Westrim. **Population**: ~20,000 The Sharabha royal family chafes at being the odd kingdom out—three Kor monarchies united by race against one Sharabha, despite identical cultural values. Political marriages between the houses have done little to ease this tension.

entries.name: Shinii
entries.contentPreview: The eastern city-state, positioned on the Kunagi Hills' western edge as the gateway to desert trade. Shinii handles the caravans coming west from the Dunes of Kunagi, exchanging Atriik's furs and timber for glass, spices, and goods from across the desert. **Population**: ~15,000

entries.name: Wykakas
entries.contentPreview: The southernmost city-state, built on the Sha Sonisst as Atriik's first line of defense against Naruaghin incursions from the Bloodlands. Wykakas is more militarized than its sister cities—less courtly polish, more practical vigilance. **Population**: ~12,000

entries.name: Mykala
entries.contentPreview: At the center of Atriik stands Mykala—a ruined fortress built at the base of the largest tree in all of Alaria. The tree's canopy stretches thirty miles in diameter; its trunk measures two miles across. In its shade, the fortress was constructed in an age now forgotten. Mykala is sacred to all four city-states. Pilgrimages here are common, and the site's neutrality is the one thing all four monarchies agree on. Currently, a druid maintains the grove and accepts pilgrims. An Elnor has arrived wit

entries.name: The Rivers
entries.contentPreview: Atriik's four rivers all bear the prefix "Sha" (meaning "river" or "waters" in the local tongue): - **Sha Puniki**: Flows from Milras Forest past Lupuno toward the eastern scrublands - **Sha Ulokoni**: Flows through Sprenwood past Byonowidi - **Sha Kariki**: Central river through Fatiik Forest - **Sha Sonisst**: Southern river through Wykakas, reaching the Bloodlands

entries.name: Sandskull
entries.contentPreview: East of the settled lands, where the Kunagi Hills meet the desert proper, stand the ruins of Sandskull—a fortress or temple of unknown origin, half-buried in drifting sand. The skull-shaped rock formation that gives it its name is visible for miles across the flat terrain. Sandskull predates Atriik's founding. Local legends connect it to the wyrm-keepers who once controlled the giant sand wurms of the Kunagi, though the ruins show no obvious connection to Urk Noulgas in the Wyrm Teeth. Treasure

entries.name: Baerlüen Mountains
entries.contentPreview: TODO

entries.name: Bloodlands
entries.contentPreview: The scarred buffer zone between Atriik's southern reaches and the Ishnit Jungles, where generations of warfare between the Kor/Sharabha city-states and the Naruaghin tribes have stained the earth red—sometimes metaphorically, sometimes literally.

entries.name: Character
entries.contentPreview: The Bloodlands are not a single terrain type but a transition zone: the thinning southern edge of Fatiik Forest gives way to thornscrub, then to burned grassland, then to the jungle's northern fringe. The soil here is iron-rich and red-brown, which gives the region its name—though the blood that has been spilled across these lands over centuries hasn't hurt the reputation. This is raiding country. Neither side holds it permanently. The Naruaghin push north when they sense weakness; Atriik forces

entries.name: Warfare Pattern
entries.contentPreview: The conflict here isn't a war in any formal sense—there are no declarations, no treaties, no clear objectives beyond "raid what you can, hold what you must." The pattern repeats: 1. **Dry Season**: Naruaghin war parties move north through the Bloodlands, probing Atriik's defenses. Small raids for slaves, food, and prestige. 2. **Early Rains**: Raiding intensifies as both sides try to secure resources before the rivers flood. Major clashes are more common. 3. **Wet Season**: The Sha Sonisst flood

entries.name: Notable Features
entries.contentPreview: **The Bone Field**: A stretch of open ground where a particularly bloody battle occurred generations ago. The dead were never buried properly, and bones still surface after heavy rains. Both sides avoid camping here. **Fort Wykakas-South**: The southernmost permanent Atriik fortification, a stone-and-timber structure overlooking a Sha Sonisst ford. Manned year-round by Wykakas militia, it marks the effective limit of Atriik control. **The Burned Villages**: At least a dozen abandoned settlements

entries.name: Strategic Significance
entries.contentPreview: The Bloodlands exist because neither side can conquer them. Atriik lacks the numbers and the unity to push into the Ishnit Jungles proper. The Naruaghin lack the organization and logistics to hold territory north of the jungle edge. The result is a permanent wound in the landscape—and a constant drain on Atriik's southern city-states. Wykakas bears the brunt of this, which explains why that city-state is the most militarized and least courtly of the four. You don't develop elaborate greeting rit

entries.name: Blvnird
entries.contentPreview: A city-state in Westrim. TODO

entries.name: Byonowidi
entries.contentPreview: A Sharabha city-state in western Atriik, the only non-Kor monarchy in the confederation. Located on the Sha Ulokoni near Sprenwood, Byonowidi is known for its fur trade and renowned cavalry. See [Atriik](Atriik.md#byonowidi) for full details.

entries.name: Dunes of Kunagi
entries.contentPreview: Home to giant sand wurms a'la *Dune*. Well traveled by []()

entries.name: Benshu's Promise
entries.contentPreview: This oasis is located in the Dunes of Kunagi, and is the only source of freshwater for hundreds of miles. It is guarded by Benshu, a large, incredibly deadly sphinx. To drink from the water, you must answer at least one of the sphinx's three questions correctly. If you drink from the oasis before asking the sphinx for permission, the sphinx captures you (all your muscles go limp) and gives you choice for doing maze or being eaten.

entries.name: Shyalaviin (Malasi Karkus)
entries.contentPreview: Hills just south of the Eronia range that poke into the northern edge of the Dunes of Kunagi. This region, also known as Malasi Karkus, is home to the Blitzling—creatures that inhabit these transitional hills between the mountains and the desert sands.

entries.name: Dustwind Plateau
entries.contentPreview: The arid heart of Mueras, a high tableland swept by winds that never cease. The Dustwind Plateau separates the wealthy coastal cities from the eastern reaches—a buffer zone where few settlements survive and fewer prosper. Caravans cross it to avoid the longer sea route around the Beak, but the journey is harsh, and the plateau claims its share of the unprepared. The plateau rises gradually from the coast, reaching its full height some forty miles inland. From there, it stretches east to the edge

entries.name: The Wind
entries.contentPreview: The plateau's namesake wind blows from the northeast, funneled between the Mueras Highlands and the distant Eronia Range. It carries fine dust from the plateau surface—a reddish powder that gets into everything: clothes, food, lungs, eyes. Veteran plateau travelers wrap their faces and accept the grit as part of the journey. The wind never stops. Even on calm days by coastal standards, the plateau wind persists. During storms, it can strip flesh from exposed skin, sandblast wood, and overturn la

entries.name: Crossing the Plateau
entries.contentPreview: Three main routes cross the Dustwind: **The Northern Track**: From the Hammer Coast settlements to the Tarns, skirting the edge of the Mueras Highlands. The shortest crossing, but also the roughest—the track climbs through broken terrain where flash floods cut sudden gullies. House Hammren maintains way stations along this route. **The Central Road**: From Bazz and the Labyrinth Sound ports to the Taflex Forest edge. The most-traveled route, used by timber merchants and those seeking the Yngli t

entries.name: Way Stations
entries.contentPreview: Scattered across the plateau, way stations provide the only shelter between settlements. Most are simple affairs: stone walls, a roof, a cistern to catch what rain falls, and pens for pack animals. Some are maintained by merchant-king houses as part of their caravan operations; others are independent, charging travelers for water, fodder, and protection from the elements. The way stations have their own culture, distinct from either coast or forest. The people who run them are a tough, independe

entries.name: The Highland Commons
entries.contentPreview: Where the plateau meets the Mueras Highlands, the terrain rises into rocky hills with thin soil and sparse vegetation. This is "the commons"—the one part of Mueras no merchant-king has claimed. Yngli herding communities maintain small flocks of hardy goats here, and a few mining operations extract iron and copper from shallow deposits. The commons folk are poor by coastal standards but free in ways the city-dwellers aren't. They owe no harbor fees, swear no pilot oaths, and answer to no house. W

entries.name: Plateau Wildlife
entries.contentPreview: Life on the Dustwind is sparse but persistent. Hardy scrub vegetation clings to ravines where water occasionally collects. Reptiles dominate—lizards, snakes, and the occasional dust drake, a smaller cousin of true dragons that has adapted to the arid environment.
