entries.contentPreview: Three passes are theoretically traversable, though none are safe: **The Shriek Pass** (northern): Named for the constant wind that howls through the gap. Fastest crossing, but fully exposed—cloudwalkers hunt freely here. **Thornback Gap** (central): Lower elevation, but the route passes through swarm territory. Only viable in deep winter when the swarms hibernate. **Frozen Way** (southern): A glacial route that adds weeks to the journey but avoids the worst predator zones. Still dangerous; the i

entries.name: The Giant Question
entries.contentPreview: Balduahr's historical records describe giants in the mountains west of their territory, and expeditions have occasionally reported enormous humanoid figures moving on distant ridgelines. Whether these are true giants, an unknown species, or something else entirely remains unconfirmed—no expedition has gotten close enough to verify and returned. What is confirmed: something very large occasionally descends from the high peaks to drink at the mountain lakes. The tracks are unmistakable.

entries.name: Lean D'Riin
entries.contentPreview: The central and most ancient section of the Eyendra forest. The name means "Forest of the Riin" in the language of the civilization that once flourished here—a people who merged with the land two thousand years ago and now exist only as a diffuse presence throughout the forest. Lean D'Riin is the heart of ancient Riin civilization and the most dangerous part of Eyendra. The Riin built (grew) their largest settlements here, and here the merger between people and land was most complete. The trees

entries.name: Mirror Lakes
entries.contentPreview: A cluster of small lakes in southwestern Wycendeula, tucked into the hills where the Neurian range meets the northwestern edge of Eberri Ygonzi. Unlike the predator-infested waters of Kama Sa'malina or the psychological horror of Trauma Lake, the Mirror Lakes are merely... strange.

entries.name: The Stillness
entries.contentPreview: The Mirror Lakes are unnaturally calm. Even in strong wind, even during storms, the water barely ripples. The surface reflects with near-perfect clarity—sky, trees, and approaching figures reproduced so precisely that travelers sometimes mistake the reflection for a second group of people. This stillness is not magical in any detectable sense. Scholars have tested the water, the local wind patterns, the basin geography. Nothing explains why these particular lakes should be calmer than any others

entries.name: What Lives Here
entries.contentPreview: The Mirror Lakes support normal wildlife—fish, waterfowl, the small mammals that live around any freshwater source. Nothing unusual, nothing threatening. The lakes' proximity to Eberri Ygonzi keeps major predators away; coilwights don't venture this far from dense forest, and the open terrain discourages bristle-wolves. This makes the Mirror Lakes one of the few relatively safe water sources in the region. Travelers crossing the southern wilds often stop here specifically because it's not trying

entries.name: Local Use
entries.contentPreview: Hunters and trappers working the edges of Eberri Ygonzi use the Mirror Lakes as a staging area. It's close enough to the forest to make day-trips viable, far enough to sleep safely. Informal camps get established during peak hunting season, though no one stays permanently. The locals have developed superstitions about the lakes: - Don't look at your reflection for too long (you might see something you shouldn't) - Don't camp directly on the shore (the stillness affects sleep) - Don't fish after

entries.name: Hooks
entries.contentPreview: - **The reflection moved.** A hunter swears his reflection waved at him—a gesture he didn't make. He fled and hasn't returned, but his gear is still at the lake camp. Someone needs to retrieve it. Someone willing to look at the water. - **The perfect map.** A cartographer theorizes that the Mirror Lakes' reflections could map areas the cartographer can't reach directly—showing, perhaps, what lies on the other side of hills, or deeper into Eberri Ygonzi than anyone has safely traveled. He's looki

entries.name: Mylentonuri
entries.contentPreview: A point of interest within the White Wastes. TODO

entries.name: Nabledron
entries.contentPreview: A ruined fortress on Wycendeula's eastern coast, built at the intersection of the force and fire leylines where they cross into God's Bathtub. Once the ambitious project of a Free Isles noble, now a shattered monument to the dangers of leyline experimentation.

entries.name: The Ruins Today
entries.contentPreview: Nabledron's stone walls still stand, blackened and partially collapsed but recognizable as military architecture. The interior is a maze of fused stone, twisted metal, and glass—some of it still dangerously hot centuries later. The leylines continue to pulse through the site, feeding residual fires that burn without fuel in the deepest chambers. The ruins are not uninhabited. Creatures drawn to elemental energy have claimed various sections: **Glass Spawn**: Semi-molten entities that formed from

entries.name: The Surviving Orbs
entries.contentPreview: Not all of Roysann's creations were destroyed. An unknown number of fire orbs survived the catastrophe—some scattered across the surrounding terrain, others buried in the ruins. They remain stable until cracked, at which point they release their compressed contents explosively. Finding an intact orb is worth a fortune. The Free Isles, various military powers, and private collectors all pay premium prices. The catch is extraction: the orbs are scattered through glass spawn territory, often half-b

entries.name: The Leyline Crossing
entries.contentPreview: The force and fire leylines intersect directly beneath the central ruins, creating a zone of amplified and unpredictable magical effects. This is what made Roysann's project possible—and what made his failure so catastrophic. Effects near the crossing include: - Flames that burn in unusual colors and resist extinguishing - Objects that become difficult to move or stop once in motion - Sudden temperature spikes or drops

entries.name: Approaching Nabledron
entries.contentPreview: The ruins are visible from considerable distance—the blackened walls stand out against the pale coastal terrain. No roads lead here anymore; the land route requires crossing either the White Wastes or the coastal scrublands, both difficult terrain. Approach by sea is theoretically possible but complicated by the leyline effects on coastal waters. Ships report unpredictable currents and occasional steam vents. The Pugrai lakes to the south create navigation hazards of their own. Most expeditions

entries.name: Neurian Hills
entries.contentPreview: Hills in Wycendeula. TODO

entries.name: Plains of Wycendeula
entries.contentPreview: A vast grassland stretching across eastern Wycendeula, from the Kilbyurn Mountains in the west to the shores of God's Bathtub in the east. The plains are fertile, well-watered by several river systems, and completely overrun with satyrs.

entries.name: The Satyr Occupation
entries.contentPreview: The plains hold perhaps a hundred thousand satyrs scattered across thousands of temporary camps. Buffalo hide tents dot the landscape; herds of wild cattle and horses provide sustenance. The satyr follow the herds, moving with the seasons, leaving little permanent mark on the land. Despite the fertile soil, no farming exists. The satyr lack the social organization to establish agriculture—or perhaps they simply don't want to. Attempts by outsiders to settle the plains have universally failed, ov

entries.name: What Lies Beneath
entries.contentPreview: The satyr are not the first inhabitants of these plains. Beneath the grass and topsoil lie the remains of a human civilization that flourished here in the distant past—cities, roads, temples, and farms, now buried under centuries of accumulated earth. The satyr ignore these ruins; they have no interest in the past and no use for stone buildings. But the ruins are there, waiting. Evidence of the old civilization surfaces regularly: foundation stones exposed by erosion, metal objects turned up by

entries.name: The Deep Ruins
entries.contentPreview: The surface evidence hints at what lies below. In a few locations, natural features have exposed deeper structures: **River-Cut Foundations**: The Mydruli and its tributaries have carved through the buried city layer in places, revealing walls, floors, and occasionally intact chambers. Most are flooded or collapsed, but some remain accessible. Treasure hunters who brave the satyr occasionally investigate these sites. **Sinkhole Exposures**: The plains have several areas where the ground has coll

entries.name: Archaeological Interest
entries.contentPreview: The buried civilization of Wycendeula represents one of Alaria's great historical mysteries. Who were they? How advanced? Why did they fall? The answers lie beneath the plains, preserved by the same satyr occupation that prevents investigation. Serious archaeological work is effectively impossible. Any expedition large enough to excavate is large enough to attract satyr attention. Small groups can sometimes slip through, but they can't stay long enough to accomplish meaningful study. The few art

entries.name: Traveling the Plains
entries.contentPreview: Crossing the Plains of Wycendeula is possible but risky. The satyr are not uniformly hostile—small groups are often ignored, especially if they avoid camps and keep moving. But large groups, slow-moving caravans, or anyone who appears to be settling will draw attention. The main hazards: - **Satyr bands**: Opportunistic rather than organized, but dangerous in numbers - **Wildlife**: Buffalo herds can trample the unwary; predators follow the herds - **Distance**: The plains are vast, water source

entries.name: The Pugrai Lakes
entries.contentPreview: Three coastal lakes along Wycendeula's eastern shore where the White Wastes meet God's Bathtub. The lakes—Pugrai D'had, Pugrai Shisk, and Pugrai Naihim—share a common characteristic that has puzzled scholars: their waters are unnaturally still.

entries.name: The Stillwater Phenomenon
entries.contentPreview: The Pugrai lakes barely ripple. Wind that should churn the surface produces only faint tremors. Objects dropped into the water sink with dreamlike slowness. Swimming is possible but exhausting—the water resists movement in all directions. This effect intensifies closer to the lakes' centers. Boats attempting to cross report that oars become nearly useless; poling from the shallows is the only reliable propulsion. At the deepest points, the water becomes so resistant that escape requires tremendo

entries.name: The Leyline Connection
entries.contentPreview: The force leyline passes through this region, and most scholars attribute the stillwater phenomenon to its influence. The leyline—associated with kinetic manipulation and motion arrest—appears to bleed into the water table. The effect is strongest in Pugrai Naihim, the largest lake, and weakest in Pugrai Shisk. The fire leyline also crosses nearby (both converge at Nabledron to the north), but fire's influence is less apparent. Water temperature in the lakes is slightly elevated year-round, prev

entries.name: Pugrai D'had
entries.contentPreview: The northernmost lake, where the Krelfassa river meets the coast. D'had is the shallowest of the three and the stillwater effect is relatively mild—boats can cross with effort. The river mouth creates a mixing zone where normal water meets stillwater, producing strange currents that curl back on themselves. Local legend claims D'had was once a harbor in ancient times, before the leylines shifted. No archaeological evidence supports this, though the lakebed is littered with debris too deep to rec

entries.name: Pugrai Shisk
entries.contentPreview: The smallest lake, positioned between D'had and Naihim. Shisk is notable for its clarity—the stillwater effect means sediment never rises, and visibility extends to the bottom in most areas. Fish exist here but move in slow, languid patterns. They're easy to catch but taste faintly metallic. Rumors persist of shapes visible in Shisk's depths—regular geometric forms that don't match natural formations. No one has successfully dived deep enough to investigate; the water's resistance makes descent

entries.name: Pugrai Naihim
entries.contentPreview: The largest and most dangerous lake, fed by the Elmynfrosk river from the north. Naihim's center is effectively impassable—the stillwater effect is so pronounced that even objects thrown in arc slowly rather than splash. Local satyr tribes consider the lake sacred or cursed (the distinction is unclear) and avoid its shores entirely. What makes Naihim unique is the sound. On still nights, those near the shore report a low, constant vibration—not quite a hum, more a pressure in the ears. The sound

entries.name: The Pugrai Name
entries.contentPreview: "Pugrai" appears in no known language spoken in modern Wycendeula. The satyr adopted the name from whoever came before them. Some scholars connect it to ancient human tongues from before the plains fell; others suggest it predates human settlement entirely. The word's meaning is unknown, though its consistent application to stillwater features suggests it was descriptive rather than commemorative.

entries.name: Rivers of Wycendeula
entries.contentPreview: Wycendeula's river systems drain the Kilbyurn Mountains and surrounding highlands, flowing east across the plains toward God's Bathtub. Each river has developed its own character, shaped by the terrain it crosses and—in some cases—the leylines it intersects.

entries.name: The Twilight River
entries.contentPreview: The largest river in western Wycendeula, the Twilight River drains the heart of Fylvrae Sylvrym before emptying into the Bay of Wolves. The river originates somewhere in the central forest—its exact headwaters are unknown, as they lie deep in ulvsjael territory—and flows generally westward for over 200 miles. The Twilight River takes its name from the permanent gloom along its banks. The forest canopy closes over the water for most of its course, creating a tunnel of shadow broken only by occasi

entries.name: The Lilsau
entries.contentPreview: A smaller river draining the southern reaches of Fylvrae Sylvrym, flowing southwest toward the Eceraen foothills. The Lilsau originates in the hills near the Carcass Hills and runs roughly parallel to the Wolfmaw peninsula before reaching the coast south of the bay. The Lilsau is narrow and fast-moving, fed by numerous small tributaries from the surrounding forest. Its waters are clearer than the Twilight River's—the limestone of the Carcass Hills filters the sediment—and support populations of

entries.name: The Voules
entries.contentPreview: A tributary of the Lilsau, flowing south through the Carcass Hills. The Voules is small—barely twenty feet wide at its broadest—but significant as one of the few water sources in the otherwise dry hills. The river runs clear and cold, filtered through the limestone that gives the Carcass Hills their character. The taste is slightly mineral, not unpleasant but distinctive. The Voules passes within a mile of The Citadel ruins, providing water access for anyone attempting to explore the ancient cit

entries.name: The Davred
entries.contentPreview: A forest river in the northern portion of Fylvrae Sylvrym, flowing generally south before joining the Twilight River system. The Davred is notable primarily for the large satyr camps that once existed along its banks—now abandoned after the ulvsjael expanded their territory centuries ago. The river passes through some of the densest old-growth forest in Wycendeula. The trees along its banks are enormous, their root systems intertwined with the river itself. In places, the channel flows through n

entries.name: The Cyatri
entries.contentPreview: A smaller tributary in the eastern forest, flowing south from the Kilbyurn foothills. The Cyatri marks the rough boundary between deep ulvsjael territory and the transition zone approaching Balduahr's patrols. The river is fast and rocky, descending from the mountains through a series of rapids and small waterfalls. The noise of the water can mask approaching threats—or mask your own movement, depending on perspective. Ulvsjael packs hunt along the Cyatri less frequently than along the interior

entries.name: The Syla Mur
entries.contentPreview: A mountain-fed river on the eastern edge of the forest, draining the western Kilbyurn slopes before joining the Shivyll system in Balduahr territory. The Syla Mur is technically outside the main Fylvrae Sylvrym forest, running through the transition zone where trees give way to mountain terrain. Balduahr patrols occasionally follow the Syla Mur upstream, using it as a scouting route into the forest edge. The dwarves don't enter the deep forest, but they monitor the boundary. The ulvsjael, for th

entries.name: The Mydruli
entries.contentPreview: The largest river in eastern Wycendeula, originating in the central Kilbyurn Mountains. The Mydruli flows east-southeast across the Plains of Wycendeula, eventually reaching the coast south of the Cobbled Coast peninsula. The Mydruli is fed by glacial melt and runs cold year-round. Its waters are clean and support abundant fish populations—one of the few reliable food sources on the plains besides the buffalo herds. Satyr camps cluster along its banks more densely than elsewhere, though even her

entries.name: The Shivyll
entries.contentPreview: Balduahr's primary river, flowing southeast from the mountains into the plains. The Shivyll originates near Ironforge, passes east of Graystone through a defended gorge, and emerges onto the lowlands near Plainwatch. For Balduahr, the Shivyll is both lifeline and vulnerability. The river provides water, hydropower for the forges, and a transportation route for ore. It also provides an invasion path. The gorge section is heavily fortified, but the lower Shivyll is difficult to defend. Balduahr pa

entries.name: The Lygrone
entries.contentPreview: A slower, wider river in southeastern Wycendeula, fed by the Shivyll and several minor tributaries. The Lygrone meanders across flat terrain, creating marshland in its lower reaches before emptying into God's Bathtub. The Lygrone valley shows more signs of ancient habitation than anywhere else on the plains—foundation stones, buried roads, and occasional surface ruins are common. The satyr seem to avoid the area more than geography would explain. Whether this is superstition or something they kn

entries.name: The Ilyu
entries.contentPreview: A western tributary system flowing from the lower Kilbyurn range. The Ilyu is smaller than the Mydruli but significant as the primary water source for the western plains. The river crosses terrain that the satyr claim is haunted—camps along the Ilyu report more disturbances than elsewhere, and several tributaries are avoided entirely. The satyr won't explain why. Whatever the cause, the western plains near the Ilyu are less densely occupied than the eastern regions.

entries.name: The Yuforhi
entries.contentPreview: The infamous River Yuforhi flows through the heart of the White Wastes, carrying waters that induce euphoria in those who drink or bathe in them. The effect intensifies during the hottest season, making long-term settlement impossible. See *The White Wastes* entry for full details.

entries.name: The Krelfassa
entries.contentPreview: Flowing east from the Caffas Mountains toward the coast, the Krelfassa passes through the northern White Wastes before emptying into Pugrai D'had. Unlike the Yuforhi, Krelfassa's waters are safe—cold mountain runoff that hasn't absorbed whatever contaminant gives Yuforhi its properties. The Krelfassa marks an informal boundary between the White Wastes proper and the coastal lowlands. North of the river, survival is possible; south of it, the Wastes begin in earnest.

entries.name: The Elmynfrosk
entries.contentPreview: A southeastern drainage from the Caffas range, the Elmynfrosk flows through the eastern White Wastes before reaching Pugrai Naihim. The river's character changes as it approaches the coast—the stillwater effect from the Pugrai lakes extends upstream, slowing the current to an eerie crawl for the final miles. Orc and goblin tribes use the upper Elmynfrosk as a water source but avoid the lower reaches. They claim the slow water is a trap—that things wait in the sluggish current for prey to wade in

entries.name: The Shizander
entries.contentPreview: Originating in the northeastern Kilbyurn Mountains at the Buzagi Wempu headwaters, the Shizander flows east through the northern plains before curving south toward the White Wastes. The river eventually dissipates into the desert sands, though during wet seasons its lower reaches can extend considerably. The Shizander is notable for temperature fluctuations—the water runs warm in some sections and cold in others, with no consistent pattern. Local theory suggests underground thermal vents, but no

entries.name: The Tyerferniin
entries.contentPreview: A southern river draining the lower Kilbyurns toward the Eceraen foothills. The Tyerferniin falls outside the main Wycendeula drainage and eventually joins systems flowing into Venalthier.

entries.name: The Buzagi Wempu
entries.contentPreview: More a mountain torrent than a proper river, the Buzagi Wempu crashes down from the northern Kilbyurns before calming into the Shizander. The name is satyr in origin, meaning roughly "screaming white"—a reference to the rapids that dominate its upper course.

entries.name: Splintercrests
entries.contentPreview: Hills in Wycendeula. TODO

entries.name: Srendar Mountains
entries.contentPreview: A mountain range in Wycendeula. TODO

entries.name: Teardrop Lakes
entries.contentPreview: A cluster of small lakes in eastern Eyendra, marking the northern edge of the Kama Sa'malina lake district. The Teardrop Lakes share some characteristics with their southern neighbors—occasional visual anomalies, a sense of being watched—but the effects are milder here, suggesting the Riin presence is less concentrated. The name is descriptive: from above, the lakes form a rough teardrop pattern, tapering toward the southeast where they merge into Kama Sa'malina proper. Whether this shape is nat

entries.name: The Cairns
entries.contentPreview: Hills in Wycendeula. TODO

entries.name: The Nox
entries.contentPreview: The hills at the heart of Eberri Ygonzi, where the forest grows wrong and light goes to die. The Nox is not simply more dangerous than the surrounding wilderness—it is categorically different. Eberri Ygonzi will kill you with teeth and venom and cold. The Nox will kill you with darkness itself. No one knows how The Nox came to be. It isn't a leyline effect—scholars have checked. It isn't planar bleeding—the usual markers are absent. Whatever makes The Nox what it is predates human presence in Wy

entries.name: The Darkness
entries.contentPreview: The Nox is dark. Not dim, not shadowed—*dark*. The canopy doesn't explain it; other forests have equally thick canopy and still admit light. In The Nox, light sources fail. Torches burn but don't illuminate. Magical light flickers and dies. Even in clearings where sky should be visible, the darkness presses in. The darkness isn't empty. It moves. It pools in places like water, flows around obstacles, rises and falls with a rhythm no one has mapped to any cycle. Travelers who've survived The Nox

entries.name: What Hunts Here
entries.contentPreview: The creatures of Eberri Ygonzi avoid The Nox. Coilwights don't enter. Thornbacks flee from its borders. Even wolves and bears give the hills wide berth. The darkness has its own predators, things that have adapted to hunt in conditions where sight is meaningless. **Hollow Hounds** Eyeless, earless, covered in skin so black it absorbs what little light penetrates The Nox. Hollow hounds hunt by sensing body heat and vibration, tracking prey through the absolute darkness with terrible precision. Th

entries.name: Why The Nox Exists
entries.contentPreview: Unknown. The Nox doesn't correspond to any planar boundary, leyline intersection, or magical event in recorded history. It isn't growing—surveys a century apart showed no expansion. It isn't shrinking. It simply *is*, as if darkness itself decided to pool in one place and stay. Theories exist: - A god died here, and The Nox is the shadow it left behind - The Nox is a wound in reality, a place where Malstaris bleeds through

entries.name: Entry and Exit
entries.contentPreview: The Nox has no fixed boundary. The hills rise gradually from Eberri Ygonzi's forest floor, and the darkness thickens in the same way—incrementally, imperceptibly, until suddenly you're in it. Woodsmen claim they can feel the transition, a pressure in the chest, a dampening of sound, but by the time the feeling is distinct, you've already crossed. Exit is harder. The Nox doesn't keep people in through physical barriers—it keeps them in through disorientation. In the darkness, all directions feel

entries.name: Those Who Enter
entries.contentPreview: No one enters The Nox intentionally. Those who end up there arrived by accident—lost in Eberri Ygonzi, fleeing something worse, or simply unlucky enough to miss the signs. A few have survived to describe it: - A hunter who tied herself to a tree and waited for dawn (dawn doesn't come inside The Nox, but it comes outside, and she was near enough the edge to feel the difference) - A scholar's expedition that entered as fifteen and exited as three, with none able to explain what happened to the res

entries.name: No Reason to Go
entries.contentPreview: The Nox contains nothing worth retrieving. No valuable resources grow there. No ruins hide ancient treasures. No mysteries warrant the risk of investigation. The Nox exists to be avoided, full stop. If you find yourself approaching The Nox—if the light begins to fail without explanation, if sound begins to dampen, if the forest feels suddenly heavier—turn back. Don't investigate. Don't push forward to see how far it extends. Just leave. The darkness doesn't negotiate. It doesn't give second chan

entries.name: Hooks
entries.contentPreview: - **A Fade is walking.** Someone recognized as a woodsman who vanished in The Nox seven years ago has been spotted walking through farmland, heading steadily toward the forest. His family wants to stop him, talk to him, understand what happened. But he won't stop walking, and if they can't reach him before he enters the forest, they want to follow. They're hiring. - **Something came out.** A hollow hound has been found dead outside The Nox—the first time one has ever been seen beyond its borders

entries.name: The White Wastes
entries.contentPreview: A vast white desert in Wycendeula. Miscellaneous orc and goblin tribes ravage the desert. Home to Nashk, the Alchemist

entries.name: River Yuforhi
entries.contentPreview: River of euphoria-inducing substance, most intense during the hottest part of the year. Runs through the White Wastes, so impossible to have long term settlement. However, people will meet at Ay'Nbhad to celebrate for a week straight once every year. The substance also makes pain feel good if you have enough of it, which can result in horrible deaths.

entries.name: Gino's Crypt
entries.contentPreview: A lone crypt in a large wasteland of rot and death. This is where Gino the Terrible is chained. His curse spreads to all the surrounding land, located in the White Wastes north of the plains of wycendeula and south of the Caffas Mountains.

entries.name: Tormlek Lake
entries.contentPreview: A shallow, mist-shrouded lake on the western edge of Fylvrae Sylvrym, where the forest gives way to coastal scrubland south of the Bay of Wolves. The lake sits in a natural depression that floods seasonally, expanding and contracting with the rains.

entries.name: Character
entries.contentPreview: Tormlek Lake exists in a transitional zone between deep forest and coastal scrub. The ulvsjael don't claim it as core territory—the open terrain and shallow water don't suit their hunting tactics—but they do patrol its edges. The lake is safer than the forest interior but not safe. The shallowness and soft bottom make the lake useless for boats of any size. The mud is thick enough to trap waders who venture too far from shore. The mist makes navigation difficult even for those staying on land. T

entries.name: For Travelers
entries.contentPreview: Tormlek Lake offers a potential stopover for those traveling the coastal route around Fylvrae Sylvrym. The southern shore, where the forest thins into scrubland, is the safest approach. Don't attempt to cross the lake directly—the soft bottom will trap you, and the mist will disorient you. Fresh water is readily available but should be filtered; the shallow lake accumulates sediment and organic matter. Game is plentiful along the shores. Stay out of the mist if possible—ulvsjael can navigate by

entries.name: Trauma Lake
entries.contentPreview: A large lake on the eastern edge of Eberri Ygonzi, where the forest gives way to the approaches of Kama Sa'malina. Trauma Lake is not part of the greater lake district—it's older, deeper, and wrong in ways that Kama Sa'malina's gilthrain-infested waters are not. The name is a warning.

entries.name: What Happens Here
entries.contentPreview: People who spend time near Trauma Lake experience their worst memories. Not hallucinations. Not visions. The actual memories, forced to the surface with perfect clarity—every detail preserved, every emotion fresh. Childhood terrors. Losses. Betrayals. The things you've spent years learning to live with come back as if they happened yesterday. Proximity to the water intensifies the effect. Standing on the shore produces discomfort—intrusive thoughts, unwanted recollections. Touching the water tri

entries.name: The Lake's Nature
entries.contentPreview: Theories about Trauma Lake: **The Sponge**: The lake absorbs traumatic experiences from those nearby, then radiates them back. It's accumulated centuries of suffering and now broadcasts it constantly. **The Mirror**: The lake doesn't create the experiences—it reflects what's already in the victim. Everyone carries trauma; the lake simply removes the defenses that keep it buried. **The Predator**: Something lives in the lake (or is the lake) and feeds on psychological pain. The memory-forcing is

entries.name: Documented Effects
entries.contentPreview: **Proximity (within sight of water)** - Intrusive thoughts - General unease - Difficulty concentrating - Mild depressive symptoms

entries.name: The Thing in the Water
entries.contentPreview: Some survivors report seeing something in the lake. Not clearly—Trauma Lake's darkness obscures details—but shapes moving in the depths. Large shapes. Slow-moving. Watching. Whether this is real or an artifact of the lake's psychological effects is debated. The fact that multiple survivors describe similar shapes (elongated, sinuous, roughly humanoid) suggests either a genuine entity or a shared hallucination the lake induces. If something lives in Trauma Lake, no one has successfully identified

entries.name: Why Anyone Goes Near
entries.contentPreview: They don't, if they can avoid it. Trauma Lake sits in a region people already avoid for other reasons. The few who encounter it are usually lost travelers, and they learn quickly to leave. Some seek the lake intentionally. Scholars, obviously—Trauma Lake represents a genuine mystery, and certain researchers consider psychological damage an acceptable cost for understanding. More disturbing: some people come to the lake deliberately, seeking their worst memories. Guilt-ridden, grieving, or simply

entries.name: Hooks
entries.contentPreview: - **The researcher's offer.** A scholar is mounting an expedition to Trauma Lake with experimental protections—mental wards, memory-dampening potions, carefully planned time limits. She needs guards who can function near the water. Payment is excellent. The survival rate for previous expeditions is not mentioned. - **The survivor's request.** Someone emerged from Trauma Lake after extended exposure—unusual enough to warrant attention. They're functional, mostly, but they claim they saw something

entries.name: Wer Azenzi
entries.contentPreview: A cluster of small lakes in northern Eyendra, scattered through the forest between Lean D'Riin and the coast. Unlike the lakes of Kama Sa'malina far to the south, Wer Azenzi's waters are tied to the Riin—the ancient civilization that merged with the Eyendra forest two thousand years ago. The lakes are where the Riin presence pools most densely, and that presence makes itself felt. The name is Riin. No one knows exactly what it means anymore—possibly "gathering waters" or "waters that hold." The

entries.name: The Riin Connection
entries.contentPreview: The Riin built settlements throughout what is now Eyendra, and many of those settlements stood near the Wer Azenzi lakes. When the Riin merged with the forest, their presence didn't distribute evenly—it concentrated in certain places. The lakes are among the densest concentrations. This means the Riin are more *present* at Wer Azenzi than elsewhere in Eyendra. Not conscious. Not communicating. Just... there, in a way that can be felt. Standing at the shore of a Wer Azenzi lake produces a sensati

entries.name: What the Lakes Do
entries.contentPreview: The lakes exhibit phenomena consistent with Riin presence but distinct from anything else in Eyendra. **The showing**: The lakes occasionally display images on their surfaces—not reflections of what's present, but scenes from elsewhere. Scholars believe these are glimpses of Riin life, moments from the civilization's past somehow imprinted on the water. The images are fragmentary, silent, and impossible to summon deliberately. They simply appear, persist for minutes or hours, and fade. **The kno

entries.name: Dangers
entries.contentPreview: Wer Azenzi is dangerous in ways different from Kama Sa'malina's predators or Trauma Lake's psychological assault. The danger is *absorption*. People who spend too much time at Wer Azenzi begin to lose themselves. Not dramatically—no sudden transformations or violent deaths. The change is gradual. Interests shift. Preferences change. Memories blur. The victim begins to feel less like themselves and more like... something else. Something older. Something distributed. Extreme cases result in people

entries.name: The Dragon's Rules
entries.contentPreview: Ezra Olkanis includes Wer Azenzi in her territorial prohibitions, but the rules here are different from elsewhere in Eyendra. Zor's people are permitted limited access—approaching the lakes, drawing water, even camping nearby—but with restrictions: - No contact with the water beyond necessity - No more than three days in the lake region at a time - Immediate departure if symptoms of absorption appear - No attempts to communicate with whatever the lakes contain

entries.name: Hooks
entries.contentPreview: - **The showing keeps recurring.** A specific lake has been displaying the same image repeatedly—a Riin figure doing something with their hands, a gesture that might be ritual or might be communication. A scholar believes this is intentional, that the Riin (or what remains of them) are trying to convey something. She needs assistance documenting the image and possibly attempting response. - **Someone came back changed.** A hunter who spent too long at Wer Azenzi has returned to Zor speaking flue

entries.name: Zor
entries.contentPreview: Zor is the only permanent settlement in the Eyendra forest—a city-state of roughly 15,000 souls perched on the western shore of Moornik Bay, facing outward toward the sea and deliberately turning its back on the forest that surrounds it on three sides. The city exists because a dragon permits it. Eight centuries of survival have taught Zor's people that some bargains, however strange, are worth keeping.

entries.name: Geography and Position
entries.contentPreview: Zor occupies a rocky promontory jutting into Moornik Bay, with the Eyendra forest pressing close on all landward sides. The position is defensible—cliffs to the east, walls to the west—but defense against conventional enemies has never been Zor's concern. The walls face the forest. The harbor is modest but well-protected, capable of handling deep-water vessels that make the journey from Wycendeula's other coastal settlements. Most visitors arrive by sea. The land approaches are technically possi

entries.name: The Dragon Pact
entries.contentPreview: Zor's existence is predicated on an agreement with Ezra Olkanis, the ancient dragon who dwells in the Eyendra interior. The pact predates the current city—the original agreement was made with a fishing village that grew into Zor over eight centuries. **The terms:** **Zor must not disturb the interior.** The dragon's primary demand. Certain ruins are forbidden. Certain lakes—particularly in the Wer Azenzi region—must never be approached. Certain paths must not be walked. The boundaries shift over

entries.name: The Telling
entries.contentPreview: The Telling is Zor's central civic ritual—a public recitation of what the city knows about the Riin, the forest, and why both must be respected. The dragon did not demand this; Zor developed it on their own, a way of ensuring that every citizen understands the dangers that surround them. The Telling occurs on specific calendar days throughout the year, with the largest at midsummer lasting three full days. Children learn the stories before they learn to fish. Participation is expected, though no

entries.name: The Archive
entries.contentPreview: Zor maintains an Archive of Riin materials—documents, artifacts, and records recovered over centuries from the coastal fringe. The collection exists partly from scholarly interest, partly from practical necessity: understanding the Riin might help Zor survive them. The Archive is housed in a fortified building near the council hall, maintained by a small order of scholars. They've pieced together fragments over generations—a rough vocabulary, some grammatical structures, guesses at historical ev

entries.name: Governance
entries.contentPreview: Zor is ruled by a hereditary council—five families whose ancestors negotiated the original pact with Ezra Olkanis. Power rotates among the families on a complex schedule, with one family holding the Speakership (primary executive authority) for fifteen years before passing it to the next. The system is stable but rigid. The pact families derive legitimacy from their role in maintaining the dragon bargain; challenging them means challenging the arrangement that keeps Zor alive. Reform movements e

entries.name: The Council Hall
entries.contentPreview: The heart of Zor's government, a stone building older than the current city walls. The original pact was supposedly affirmed here, though the building has been rebuilt twice. The Hall contains the formal archive of pact records, the speaker's chambers, and the Recitation Court where major Tellings are conducted.

entries.name: The Archive
entries.contentPreview: A fortified structure housing Riin documents and artifacts. Access is restricted; casual visitors are turned away. Serious scholars can petition for limited access, but the council is selective about who gets to study the materials.

entries.name: The Forester's Gate
entries.contentPreview: The only official exit from the city into the forest, controlled by the Foresters' Guild. All extraction expeditions depart and return through the Gate, where they're logged, inspected, and (quietly) checked for signs of corruption or unauthorized contact.

entries.name: The Watchmount
entries.contentPreview: A tower on the city's western wall, the highest point in Zor. The Watchers—a small civic order—maintain continuous observation of the forest edge. They're looking for signs of change: paths that weren't there yesterday, trees that have moved, the subtle wrongness that precedes forest attention. When they see something, the Forester's Guild adjusts boundaries accordingly.

entries.name: The Harbormeet
entries.contentPreview: The commercial district along the waterfront, where trade happens and foreigners are permitted. Inns, taverns, chandlers, and fish markets cluster here. The Harbormeet is the most "normal" part of Zor—the place where the city's isolation is least apparent and the dragon is rarely mentioned.

entries.name: Threats and Tensions
entries.contentPreview: **The Rationalists**: A faction within Zor's merchant class that believes the dragon is dead, gone, or exaggerated. They advocate exploring the interior, exploiting the forest more aggressively, and ending the Telling as superstition. They have never held power, but their numbers grow when trade is poor. **The Interior Dreams**: People in Zor sometimes dream of the forest—of walking paths they've never seen, of faces that feel familiar but aren't. Most recover. Some don't. The Archive scholars t

entries.name: Boundaries and Position
entries.contentPreview: - **North**: The Eceraen Mountains (running east-west) separate Venalthier from Wycendeula; Tundra Oblivio lies between the mountains and the Whitewalls - **East**: The Sea of Daggers and its extension, the Frozen Sea; the impossible boundary with Eyendra forest - **South**: Open polar ocean; the Akratian Plateau extends toward the unexplored pole - **West**: Dismar Deep, the southwestern ocean; the Crystal Coast and Scepter Mountains

entries.name: Northern Transition
entries.contentPreview: **Tundra Oblivio**: The windswept wasteland between the Eceraen Mountains and the Whitewall barrier. Contains the Blerian Hills and the settlement of Morya (~200 souls surviving on Nabuhe-supplied Frostfire). **The Whitewalls**: The great ice cliffs marking Venalthier's northern edge: - **West Whitewall**: Pure glacier, constantly calving into the Dismar Deep - **The Face**: Mysterious cliff formation with a face-like profile, containing the warm Eye pool - **East Whitewall**: Ice over rock, hom

entries.name: Interior Ice Plains
entries.contentPreview: **Morelous**: The western interior plain, punctuated by rocky "teeth" that provide navigation and shelter. Primary overland route between East Whitewall and the Scepter Mountains. **Pale Death**: The central-eastern plain of featureless white, notorious for claiming travelers. Its eastern edge meets the impossible boundary of Eyendra forest, where polar conditions end and living boreal forest begins instantly. **Ekri Towers**: Twin black spires of unknown origin rising from the ice between Morel

entries.name: Southern Plateaus
entries.contentPreview: **Selengreyb Plateau**: The elevated heart of Venalthier at 5,000-6,000 feet, source of the katabatic winds that scour the interior. Contains a mysterious central depression with anomalous properties. **West Selengreyb**: The brutal transition slope where plateau winds accelerate to maximum velocity—the most dangerous leg of east-west travel. **Akratian Plateau**: The southernmost landmass, extending toward the polar ice cap. Gateway to the unreached southern pole, known for the phenomenon of si

entries.name: Coastal Features
entries.contentPreview: **Crystal Coast**: Northwestern shoreline where intricate ice formations refract polar light into spectacular displays. Richest marine ecosystem in Venalthier. **Scepter Mountains**: Western coastal range with the only viable landing points. Contains the fjords (Deepest Reach, Shatter Bay, Ghostwater) and mountain passes (Coldgate, Scepter Gap) that connect Venalthier to the outside world.

entries.name: Climate
entries.contentPreview: Venalthier experiences polar conditions year-round: - **Temperatures**: -20°C to -60°C depending on region and season - **Wind**: Persistent katabatic flows from Selengreyb, 30-60 mph constant, gusting to 100+ - **Polar Night**: 3 months of complete darkness in the south; proportionally less further north - **Polar Day**: Corresponding months of continuous dim light

entries.name: Akratian Plateau
entries.contentPreview: The southernmost landmass of Venalthier—a windswept plateau extending toward the polar ice cap, where the boundary between land and permanent sea ice becomes impossible to determine. The Akratian Plateau represents the end of the world in the most literal sense: beyond it lies only the frozen ocean and the pole itself.

entries.name: The Polar Approach
entries.contentPreview: The Akratian Plateau is the gateway to Alaria's southern pole—or would be, if reaching the pole were possible. The plateau gradually merges with the polar ice sheet, a transition zone of perhaps 100 miles where land-based ice and sea-based ice become indistinguishable. Beyond that transition, the polar ice cap extends to the geographic pole itself, an additional 500+ miles of frozen ocean that no expedition has successfully crossed. Several attempts have been made. All have failed. The furthest

entries.name: Conditions
entries.contentPreview: The Akratian Plateau experiences the most extreme cold in Alaria: **Temperature**: Averaging -50°C to -60°C, with recorded extremes approaching -80°C during polar night. These are temperatures where steel becomes brittle, where exposed flesh freezes in seconds, where survival is measured in minutes rather than hours. **Light**: The plateau experiences true polar night—complete 24-hour darkness—for approximately three months per year. During this period, the only illumination comes from stars, mo

entries.name: Why Anyone Goes
entries.contentPreview: Despite the conditions, expeditions occasionally attempt the Akratian Plateau. Their reasons vary: **Polar Conquest**: Some are driven by the simple desire to reach the pole—to stand at the bottom of the world and return to tell of it. None have succeeded, but the attempts continue. **Scientific Study**: Scholars of climate, geology, and planar physics find the extreme conditions valuable for research. The ice cores from Akratian contain records of Alaria's climate stretching back hundreds of th

entries.name: The Ice Singers
entries.contentPreview: One phenomenon is consistently reported by Akratian expeditions: the ice sings. Not metaphorically. The ice produces sounds—tones that rise and fall, harmonics that shift and layer, something that resembles music but follows no recognizable pattern. The singing is loudest during the coldest periods and disappears entirely during warmer spells. It seems to emanate from deep within the glacier, from far to the south. The singing is a voice. Specifically, it's the voice of Keth-Vorun, a primordial

entries.name: What The Nabuhe Know
entries.contentPreview: The Nabuhe learned about Keth-Vorun from Velkoreth's memories—the titan whose corpse is The Face. Before dying, Velkoreth witnessed the binding, epochs ago, and that memory persists in the Frostfire. Nabuhe who consume unprocessed Frostfire during certain rituals can access fragments of the titan's knowledge, including its understanding of what lies at the pole. The Nabuhe don't go to the Akratian Plateau because they know exactly what's there. They don't share this knowledge because understandi

entries.name: For Travelers
entries.contentPreview: The Akratian Plateau is not a destination. It is a warning. The further south you go, the more coherent the singing becomes. At a certain point—roughly 200 miles onto the polar ice—travelers begin understanding fragments. Words, concepts, fragments of meaning that shouldn't translate but do. This is the point of no return. Those who understand Keth-Vorun's language can never fully stop hearing it. If you go: - **Stop when you start understanding**. The moment the singing starts making sense, tur

entries.name: Crystal Coast
entries.contentPreview: The northwestern shoreline of Venalthier, where the Scepter Mountains descend into the Dismar Deep. The Crystal Coast takes its name from the ice formations that develop along its cliffs—intricate crystalline structures that catch the polar light and scatter it into rainbow fragments visible for miles.

entries.name: The Crystals
entries.contentPreview: The coast's namesake formations grow wherever spray and mist meet the cold rock: **Structure**: The crystals are pure water ice, but their growth patterns create structures unlike normal icicles. They branch and fork repeatedly, building three-dimensional lattices that can extend 20-30 feet from the cliff face. The largest formations resemble frozen chandeliers or inverted ice trees. **Optics**: The crystal structure refracts light with unusual efficiency. On clear days, the coast becomes a disp

entries.name: Wildlife
entries.contentPreview: The Crystal Coast supports Venalthier's richest marine ecosystem: **Seals**: Multiple species haul out on the rocky ledges between crystal formations. Their populations number in the thousands—by far the largest concentration of marine mammals in the region. **Seabirds**: The cliffs provide nesting habitat for millions of birds during breeding season. The guano accumulation is thick enough to be visible as white patches from miles away. **Fish**: The deep, cold water supports abundant fish popul

entries.name: Access and Use
entries.contentPreview: The Crystal Coast is theoretically the most accessible part of Venalthier: **By Sea**: Ships can approach the coast relatively safely, anchoring in the deeper water off the cliff bases. The lack of ice floes (the deep water prevents freeze-up) makes navigation easier than elsewhere in the region. **Fishing**: Small operations occasionally work the Crystal Coast waters, harvesting fish and seals. These are typically based from the Scepter Mountains passes, running fast trips to the coast and back

entries.name: The Nabuhe and the Coast
entries.contentPreview: The Nabuhe don't visit the Crystal Coast frequently, but they value its resources. Occasionally, trading parties make the journey across Morelous to collect items available nowhere else: **Crystal Ice**: Fragments of the optical ice formations are prized for decorative and possibly magical purposes. Properly cut and polished, they retain their light-bending properties indefinitely. **Seal Products**: Seal oil, meat, and hides are valuable in Venalthier's resource-poor environment. A successful h

entries.name: For Travelers
entries.contentPreview: The Crystal Coast is one of Venalthier's few regions that rewards visitors with something other than survival: - **Approach by sea** if possible. The overland route across Morelous is dangerous; the sea approach merely difficult. - **Bring rope and climbing gear**. Ascending the cliffs is the only way to fully experience the crystal formations. - **Time your visit for clear weather**. The optical displays require direct light; overcast conditions render the coast merely dramatic rather than spec

entries.name: East Whitewall
entries.contentPreview: The first major face of cliffs in Venalthier, home to the Nabuhe dwarves who have carved extensive mining operations into the frozen stone.

entries.name: Nabuhe Dwarves
entries.contentPreview: A clan of dwarves adapted to the extreme cold of Venalthier, the Nabuhe have survived in this harsh environment by mining the unique resource that makes life possible in the frozen wastes.

entries.name: Frostfire Mines
entries.contentPreview: Deep within East Whitewall, the Nabuhe mine Frostfire—a miraculous material that burns from within, emitting warmth without consuming fuel. This is the only reliable source of heat for the dwarves in the southern frozen regions, making it more valuable than gold or gems. However, Frostfire possesses a darker property: it has immense power to control people's fear. Those who wield Frostfire can manipulate the primal terror in others' hearts, granting them formidable abilities of psychological man

entries.name: Ekri Towers
entries.contentPreview: Twin spires of dark stone rising from the ice plain between Morelous and the Selengreyb Plateau—the only structures in Venalthier's interior, standing where no structures should be possible. The Ekri Towers have endured for millennia, their purpose unknown, their builders vanished, their presence unexplained.

entries.name: Architecture
entries.contentPreview: The towers are not identical: **The Eastern Tower**: Slightly taller and broader, with a single entrance at ground level. The interior contains a spiral staircase carved from the same black stone, ascending to an empty chamber at the top. Windows pierce the walls at irregular intervals, their openings oriented in directions that correspond to no obvious astronomical alignments. **The Western Tower**: Shorter by perhaps 10 feet, with no visible entrance. The surface is smooth and unbroken, with n

entries.name: Who Built Them
entries.contentPreview: The Riin built the Ekri Towers approximately 2,500 years ago—five centuries before their civilization merged with the Eyendra forest. At that time, the Riin controlled territory stretching from what is now Eyendra westward across Venalthier to the Scepter coast. The towers served as a way station and observation post, monitoring weather patterns and maintaining communication with settlements that no longer exist. The Riin built them from stone imported from the Scepter Mountains, using technique

entries.name: What's Inside the Western Tower
entries.contentPreview: The western tower is sealed because something sealed itself inside. During the Riin merger, one individual refused to join the collective consciousness. A woman named Ekri—the towers' last keeper—chose individual death over dissolution into the group mind. She climbed into the western tower, sealed the entrance with techniques that cannot be undone from outside, and waited to die alone. She's still waiting. Ekri didn't die. The same preservation magic that maintains Eyendra's boundary against th

entries.name: Why The Eastern Tower Is Open
entries.headerText: #### Why The Eastern Tower Is Open
entries.contentPreview: The eastern tower remains accessible because Ekri intended it as a refuge. Before sealing herself away, she left supplies, records, and instructions in the eastern tower for anyone who might need shelter in the frozen waste. The spiral staircase leads to a chamber containing preserved Riin texts—historical records, magical treatises, and Ekri's personal journals describing the merger and why she refused it. The time dilation effects aren't supernatural—they're a side effect of proximity to Ekri'

entries.name: Strange Phenomena
entries.contentPreview: Those who've visited the Ekri Towers report various anomalies: **Time Dilation**: Time seems to pass differently near the towers. Visitors report spending what felt like hours exploring the eastern tower, only to emerge and find days have passed—or the reverse, spending days that registered as minutes. **Dreams**: Sleeping near the towers produces vivid, unsettling dreams. Common themes include drowning, falling through ice, and conversations with entities that speak in languages the dreamer doe

entries.name: For Travelers
entries.contentPreview: The Ekri Towers are the only shelter between Morelous and Selengreyb. This makes them attractive as a waypoint despite the strangeness that surrounds them: - **Use the eastern tower for shelter** if necessary. The interior is warmer than the exterior and provides protection from wind. - **Don't spend more than one night**. The time dilation effects seem to intensify with extended exposure. - **Avoid the western tower**. You can't get in anyway, and the hum intensifies when approached. - **Don't

entries.name: Frozen Sea
entries.contentPreview: A frozen sea in Venalthier. TODO

entries.name: Morelous
entries.contentPreview: The western expanse of Venalthier's frozen interior, stretching from the Crystal Coast in the northwest to the West Selengreyb lowlands in the south. Morelous is marginally more hospitable than Pale Death to the east—not because conditions are better, but because occasional rocky outcrops provide minimal shelter and navigation points.

entries.name: The Teeth
entries.contentPreview: The rocky outcrops that define Morelous serve multiple purposes: **Navigation**: Each tooth is distinctive—different height, different color, different profile. The Nabuhe have named all significant outcrops and use them as waypoints for travel. A journey across Morelous follows a chain of teeth rather than compass bearings alone. **Shelter**: The leeward side of any tooth provides respite from the wind. Snow accumulates in these wind shadows, allowing construction of stable shelters. Expedition

entries.name: The Route to Scepter Mountains
entries.contentPreview: Morelous provides the primary overland route between the Nabuhe settlements in East Whitewall and the coastal passes through the Scepter Mountains. This route sees the most traffic of any in Venalthier—which means perhaps a dozen parties per year in good conditions. The journey covers approximately 150 miles across Morelous proper, following a chain of seven major teeth between the Whitewalls and the mountain foothills. Under optimal conditions, the crossing takes 5-7 days. Under normal conditio

entries.name: Fauna
entries.contentPreview: Morelous supports more life than other parts of Venalthier's interior: **Ice Bears**: Polar bears wander the region, attracted by the slightly warmer conditions near the coast. They're the apex predators of Morelous, capable of bringing down anything they catch. The Nabuhe don't hunt them unless attacked; the risk isn't worth the reward. **Snow Foxes**: Small, cunning, and numerous. They scavenge from bear kills and ambush smaller prey near the teeth. Their pelts are valuable, but trapping takes

entries.name: Weather Patterns
entries.contentPreview: Morelous sits in the path of storms rolling off the Dismar Deep. These storms are different from the interior's dry cold: **Ocean Storms**: Relatively warm, wet air from the sea hits the frozen interior and dumps precipitation as heavy snow. These storms can last days, burying landmarks and making travel impossible. They're also warmer than the ambient cold, creating a paradoxical situation where storm conditions are more survivable than the clear weather that follows. **Clear Periods**: After s

entries.name: For Travelers
entries.contentPreview: Morelous is the least deadly part of Venalthier's interior—but "least deadly" is a relative term. - **Plan for the teeth**. Know where they are before you start. Running out of daylight between teeth means exposure camping, which is often fatal. - **Check caves carefully**. The shelter isn't worth the spider bite. - **Respect the bears**. They own Morelous more than anyone else does. Give them wide berth. - **Watch the wind**. Easterly wind means storm coming; westerly after a storm means plungi

entries.name: Pale Death
entries.contentPreview: The central-eastern expanse of Venalthier's frozen interior—a vast plain of ice and compacted snow stretching from The Face in the north to the Selengreyb Plateau in the south, and from Morelous in the west to where the ice meets the impossible boundary of Eyendra's living forest. Pale Death is named for what it is: featureless white emptiness where those who enter often don't return.

entries.name: The Eastern Boundary
entries.contentPreview: Pale Death's most remarkable feature is what lies at its eastern edge: the Eyendra forest. The transition is instant and impossible. There is no gradual thaw, no treeline creeping forward, no zone of scrub vegetation. One step is frozen wasteland; the next step is living boreal forest, the air ten degrees warmer, the ground bare of snow, the trees ancient and dense. The boundary runs roughly north-south for perhaps 60 miles, marking where the Riin's merged consciousness refuses to let winter ent

entries.name: Kama Sa'malina Proximity
entries.contentPreview: The eastern portion of Pale Death borders not just Eyendra's edge but the Kama Sa'malina lake district—the "dreaming waters" where hundreds of lakes hold fragments of Riin consciousness. The boundary effect intensifies here: travelers on the ice sometimes hear voices from the forest, catch glimpses of faces in their peripheral vision, or dream of places they've never visited. The dreams are the worst part. Travelers who camp near the Eyendra boundary wake with memories that aren't their own—frag

entries.name: Climate
entries.contentPreview: Pale Death experiences the full force of Venalthier's polar climate: **Temperature**: -30°C to -50°C year-round. Brief "warm" periods during high summer might reach -15°C, but such conditions are rare and unpredictable. **Wind**: Constant. The katabatic flow from the Selengreyb Plateau creates persistent winds of 30-40 mph, with gusts exceeding 80 mph during storms. The wind is the primary killer—wind chill pushes effective temperatures to -70°C or colder. **Visibility**: Variable and unreliable

entries.name: Why "Pale Death"
entries.contentPreview: The name is literal. The plain is pale—white ice, white snow, white sky. And it kills—sometimes through exposure, sometimes through something worse.

entries.name: The Glassworms
entries.contentPreview: Beneath Pale Death's ice live the glassworms—massive serpentine creatures, 40-80 feet long, composed of transparent crystalline flesh that makes them nearly invisible against the ice. They sense vibrations through the frozen surface and hunt by ambush, bursting through the snow layer to seize prey before retreating below. The glassworms are ancient—fossils suggest they've existed since before the region froze, adapting as their temperate homeland became polar wasteland. Their crystalline bodies

entries.name: Movement and Survival
entries.contentPreview: Crossing Pale Death is technically possible. The Nabuhe do it occasionally when necessary, using techniques developed over centuries: **Navigation**: Travel only on clear days when celestial navigation is possible. During overcast conditions, remain stationary. Use stakes driven into the ice to mark your trail—without them, you won't know if you're walking forward or in circles. **Shelter**: Carry materials to construct emergency snow shelters. Build them tight against the wind; a poorly oriente

entries.name: For Travelers
entries.contentPreview: Don't cross Pale Death. If you must: - **Hire Nabuhe guides** if any will agree. Their knowledge is the only reliable advantage available. - **Accept that you may die**. Not as pessimism, but as fact. The prepared survive more often than the unprepared, but survival is never guaranteed. - **Stay away from the eastern edge**. The dreams are worse than the cold.

entries.name: Scepter Mountains
entries.contentPreview: A rugged coastal mountain range running along the western edge of Venalthier, from the Eceraen junction in the north to where the peaks disappear beneath the Whitewall glaciers in the south. The Scepter Mountains form a natural barrier between the frozen interior and the Dismar Deep, their summits catching the last warmth from ocean currents before the polar cold consumes everything.

entries.name: Terrain
entries.contentPreview: The Scepter Mountains are geologically young and extremely rugged: **Sharp Ridges**: The peaks haven't eroded into rounded forms; knife-edge ridges and near-vertical faces are common. Climbing is technical and dangerous. **Glacial Valleys**: Deep U-shaped valleys cut between the major peaks, carved by glaciers that have since retreated. These valleys provide the only practical routes through the range. **Unstable Rock**: The volcanic and sedimentary layers are prone to rockfall and avalanche. Th

entries.name: Climate
entries.contentPreview: The Scepter Mountains experience a hybrid climate—coastal influence from the west, polar conditions from the east: **Western Slopes**: Warmer than the interior, with temperatures occasionally reaching just above freezing even in winter. Heavy snowfall creates deep accumulation. Fog is common when warm ocean air meets cold mountain surfaces. **Eastern Slopes**: Full polar conditions. The rain shadow means less precipitation, but what falls stays frozen. Temperatures match Tundra Oblivio levels. W

entries.name: Strategic Value
entries.contentPreview: The Scepter Mountains matter for two reasons: **Coastal Access**: The range contains the only viable landing points on Venalthier's western coast. Several fjords penetrate the mountain wall, providing protected harbors where ships can anchor. These landing points are the primary connection between Venalthier and the outside world—everything that enters or leaves the frozen south by sea passes through the Scepter coast. **Route Through**: The glacial valleys provide the only passable routes betwe

entries.name: The Fjords
entries.contentPreview: Several deep inlets cut into the Scepter coast, remnants of glacial carving: **Deepest Reach**: The largest fjord, extending nearly 15 miles inland. The innermost waters remain ice-free year-round, warmed by currents from the Dismar Deep. This is the primary entry point for ships serving Venalthier. **Shatter Bay**: A wide, shallow inlet where ice calving from the surrounding glaciers fills the water with dangerous bergs. Navigation is treacherous, but the bay provides access to the northern pas

entries.name: Wildlife
entries.contentPreview: The Scepter Mountains support more life than the interior tundra, though not by much: **Seabirds**: Large colonies nest on the coastal cliffs, surviving on fish from the Dismar Deep. Their guano creates distinctive white streaks down the dark rock faces. **Seals and Sea Lions**: Haul out on rocky ledges along the coast. Hunted by anyone who can reach them. **Mountain Goats**: A hardy subspecies adapted to the extreme conditions. Their wool and meat are valuable; reaching them on the steep terrai

entries.name: Passage Through
entries.contentPreview: The Scepter passes are the only overland routes into Venalthier's interior. All are difficult: **Coldgate**: The northernmost pass, connecting to the Eceraen foothills. Highest in elevation but shortest in distance. Impassable in winter due to snow accumulation. **Scepter Gap**: The primary year-round route, lower and longer than Coldgate. Maintained by the Nabuhe as their supply line from the coast. Travelers pay tolls or don't pass. **Southern Route**: No formal name—a difficult climb over the

entries.name: For Travelers
entries.contentPreview: The Scepter Mountains are dangerous but navigable with preparation: - **Use the fjords** for coastal access. Don't attempt to land on open cliffs—the rocks will shred your hull. - **Pay the tolls** at Scepter Gap unless you have compelling reasons to avoid Nabuhe contact. The alternative routes are significantly more dangerous. - **Carry supplies for delays**. Weather can close passes for days. Running out of food while waiting for a storm to clear is a common way to die. - **Respect the glacier

entries.name: Selengreyb Plateau
entries.contentPreview: The elevated heart of Venalthier—a vast icy plateau rising 5,000-6,000 feet above sea level, forming the source region for the glacial flows that define the continent's frozen character. Selengreyb is where the cold is born; the winds that scour Pale Death and Morelous originate here, flowing downhill from this frozen highland.

entries.name: West Selengreyb
entries.contentPreview: The western margin of the plateau descends through a broad transition zone called West Selengreyb. This region—roughly 60 miles wide—represents the slope between the high plateau and the lower Morelous plains. West Selengreyb is where the katabatic winds are born. Cold, dense air pools on the plateau surface, then flows downhill under its own weight. The slope accelerates this flow, creating persistent winds of 40-60 mph that blast westward toward the coast. During cold snaps, these winds can ex

entries.name: Elevation Effects
entries.contentPreview: The plateau's altitude creates conditions more extreme than anywhere else in Venalthier: **Temperature**: Averaging -40°C to -50°C year-round, with extremes reaching -70°C during polar night. The altitude adds perhaps 10°C of additional cold compared to the lowlands. **Pressure**: The thin air at 6,000 feet causes altitude sickness in those not acclimated. Combined with cold and wind, this creates a triple threat that exhausts travelers rapidly. **Isolation**: The plateau is further from help th

entries.name: Why It Matters
entries.contentPreview: Selengreyb's practical importance is minimal—no resources exist, no settlements are viable, no trade routes cross it. But the plateau shapes everything around it: **Climate Control**: The cold air produced here drives Venalthier's weather patterns. Understanding Selengreyb means understanding why Venalthier is what it is. **Glacial Source**: The ice mass of the plateau flows slowly outward in all directions, feeding the glaciers that eventually become the Whitewalls. Selengreyb is a frozen reser

entries.name: The Depression
entries.contentPreview: Near the plateau's center, a shallow depression perhaps 20 miles across marks where a fragment of the lost third moon struck Alaria during the Ezz Rift, 120 million years ago. Before the Rift, Alaria had three moons. The cataclysm that created the planar stack also shattered the third moon, scattering debris across the world. Most pieces burned up or struck the oceans. One major fragment—perhaps a mile across—hit the Selengreyb region when it was still temperate land, burying itself deep in the

entries.name: For Travelers
entries.contentPreview: Don't go to Selengreyb Plateau. This isn't the cautious advice given for other parts of Venalthier. This is simple assessment: the plateau offers nothing worth the certainty of death that attempting to reach it involves. If you find yourself on the plateau despite all reason: - **Watch for mirror ice**. Test the surface with a stake before committing your weight. - **Descend immediately**. Every hour at elevation increases the likelihood of altitude sickness, hypothermia, and death.

entries.name: The Face
entries.contentPreview: A massive cliff formation rising between West Whitewall and East Whitewall, forming the central portion of Venalthier's northern ice barrier. The Face takes its name from a natural rock formation visible in the cliff that resembles a colossal human visage—though whether it is truly natural remains a matter of debate among those few who have seen it.

entries.name: What It Actually Is
entries.contentPreview: The Face is a titan—one of the colossal beings that walked Alaria before the God War, killed in battle and frozen into the cliff where it fell. The Nabuhe know this. Their oral histories describe the final days of the titan called Velkoreth the Watchful, who fled south during the God War's climax, pursued by forces that no longer exist. Velkoreth died here, its body flash-frozen by magical cold that still radiates from its bones millennia later. The "cliff" is its skull and upper torso, petrifie

entries.name: Approach and Access
entries.contentPreview: The Face can be approached from three directions: **From Tundra Oblivio (north)**: The glacier rises gradually until it meets the cliff base. Travelers can walk across the ice to within touching distance of the rock, though the journey across the tundra is dangerous and the cliff offers no shelter once reached. **From Pale Death (south)**: The southern approach requires climbing the glacier that banks against the cliff's southern face. The ice is crevassed and unstable, making this route more da

entries.name: The Eye
entries.contentPreview: Within the face formation, the eye socket—a deep concavity approximately 100 feet across—contains the titan's actual eye, still partially liquid after all these millennia. The Eye is not water. It's vitreous fluid from Velkoreth's preserved ocular globe, mixed with meltwater and titan tears that still seep from ducts in the surrounding bone. The warmth comes from residual life—the same slow decay that produces Frostfire. The Eye is, in a very real sense, still alive. Drinking from the Eye doesn'

entries.name: Wildlife
entries.contentPreview: The Face hosts the largest seabird colonies in Venalthier. Thousands of birds nest in the cliff's horizontal cracks during breeding season, taking advantage of the thermal anomaly that keeps the rock slightly warmer than the surrounding ice. Their guano streaks the dark basalt white in places, creating patterns that some observers claim form writing in unknown scripts. The birds are the only consistent life on The Face. No mammals den in the cliffs; no fish swim in the Eye's waters despite its t

entries.name: For Travelers
entries.contentPreview: The Face is a destination for scholars, mystics, and the deeply curious. It offers no practical resources, no shelter, and no safety. The journey to reach it is dangerous; remaining near it offers no particular benefit beyond satisfying curiosity. If you must visit: - **Approach from the north** if possible. The glacier crossing is brutal but more predictable than the southern crevasse fields. - **Don't drink from the Eye** unless you're prepared for consequences you can't predict. - **Note the

entries.name: Tundra Oblivio
entries.contentPreview: The vast frozen interior of northern Venalthier, stretching from the southern slopes of the Eceraen Mountains to the edge of the Whitewall glacier fields. Tundra Oblivio is perhaps the most inhospitable habitable region in Alaria—a windswept wasteland where nothing grows, nothing shelters, and survival is measured in hours rather than days.

entries.name: Climate
entries.contentPreview: Tundra Oblivio experiences polar conditions year-round: **Winter** (roughly 8 months): Temperatures drop to -40°C or colder. Darkness lasts 20+ hours per day at the solstice. Wind chill makes exposed skin deadly within minutes. The ground is covered in hard-packed snow and ice. **Summer** (roughly 4 months): Temperatures climb to just above freezing on the warmest days. The sun barely dips below the horizon, creating perpetual twilight rather than true darkness. The surface layer of permafrost p

entries.name: The Blerian Hills
entries.contentPreview: Rising from the central tundra, the Blerian Hills provide the only significant elevation change between the Eceraen range and the Whitewall. These are not mountains—the highest peaks reach perhaps 1,500 feet above the surrounding plain—but in a landscape of absolute flatness, they loom large. The hills are composed of ancient volcanic rock, harder than the surrounding sedimentary plain and resistant to glacial erosion. Their presence creates minor wind shadows on their southern slopes, making th

entries.name: Morya
entries.contentPreview: On the northern edge of the Blerian Hills, where the slopes descend toward the Eceraen foothills, sits Morya—the only permanent settlement in Tundra Oblivio. "Settlement" overstates the case. Morya is a collection of ice-block shelters and underground burrows occupied by perhaps 200 souls at peak population. Its residents are outcasts, fugitives, and madmen—people who have chosen to live in conditions that would kill most others rather than face whatever awaited them in civilization. Morya survi

entries.name: Wildlife
entries.contentPreview: Tundra Oblivio supports almost no life: **Migrating Birds**: Some species cross the tundra during seasonal migrations, but none stop. There's nothing to eat. **Arctic Foxes and Wolves**: Small populations exist in the Blerian Hills, surviving on the limited prey available there. They don't venture onto the open tundra. **Polar Bears**: Occasionally wander inland from the coastal ice. Extremely dangerous—a starving polar bear will eat anything it catches, and on the open tundra, it can catch anyt

entries.name: Navigation
entries.contentPreview: Crossing Tundra Oblivio is theoretically possible but practically suicidal. **No Landmarks**: The terrain is featureless. Once you lose sight of the mountains (which happens quickly in poor visibility), there's nothing to navigate by. Compasses work, but magnetic interference near the pole makes them unreliable. **No Shelter**: There's nothing to hide behind, nothing to build with, nothing to burn. Survival requires carrying everything you need—and carrying enough supplies for a multi-day crossi

entries.name: For Travelers
entries.contentPreview: Don't cross Tundra Oblivio unless you have no other choice. If you must: - **Travel along edges only**. The Eceraen foothills and Scepter Mountains provide marginal shelter and navigation references. The open tundra provides nothing. - **Carry Frostfire** if you can obtain it. Magical heat is the only reliable warmth source; conventional fires are impossible in the wind. - **Move fast**. Extended exposure is fatal. Plan to cover ground quickly rather than camping extensively.

entries.name: West Whitewall
entries.contentPreview: The western terminus of the great Whitewall—a continuous ice cliff stretching across southern Venalthier where the continental glaciers meet the sea. West Whitewall marks where the Scepter Mountains disappear beneath the ice sheet, their peaks becoming mere nunataks before vanishing entirely into the frozen mass.

entries.name: Character
entries.contentPreview: West Whitewall has a different character than its eastern counterpart: **No Settlement**: Unlike East Whitewall, where the Nabuhe have carved homes into the frozen rock, West Whitewall is uninhabited. The ice itself provides no stable surface for construction—anything built would eventually calve into the sea. The few rock outcrops that pierce the glacier are too small and exposed to support permanent occupation. **No Resources**: East Whitewall has Frostfire. West Whitewall has only ice—abundan

entries.name: The Ice Shelf
entries.contentPreview: South of the visible wall face, the glacier extends underwater and eventually resurfaces as a floating ice shelf. This shelf extends perhaps 20-30 miles into the Dismar Deep before breaking up into discrete icebergs. The shelf is navigable in theory—flat ice extending over open water, solid enough to walk on in most places. In practice, the shelf is treacherous. Crevasses open without warning. Pressure ridges create impassable barriers. Sections break away and drift, stranding anyone caught on t

entries.name: Approaches
entries.contentPreview: West Whitewall can be approached from three directions: **By Sea (West)**: Ships from the Dismar Deep can view the wall from a safe distance. Approaching closer than a mile is risky—calving events can create waves that swamp small vessels, and underwater ice extensions can damage hulls. The wall is impressive from the water but inaccessible. **From Tundra Oblivio (North)**: The glacier rises gradually from the tundra, transitioning from permafrost to ice sheet over perhaps 10-15 miles. The bound

entries.name: What Lies Beyond
entries.contentPreview: South of West Whitewall—beyond the ice shelf, beyond the icebergs—the Dismar Deep opens toward the polar ocean. No ships have explored these waters extensively. The few that have ventured south report endless ice floes, persistent fog, and magnetic anomalies that make navigation unreliable. Rumors persist of land beyond the ice—islands, or perhaps a southern continent, glimpsed through breaks in the fog. No verified discovery supports these claims. The polar ocean remains largely unknown, its se
