entries.contentPreview: The ancient bargain with the Grayls, known only in fragments: - No fire larger than a candle within Ierya (cooking uses geothermal vents) - No cutting of living wood (construction uses only deadfall and stone) - The springs must remain open to all who come in peace - Once per generation, a pilgrimage reaffirms the agreement

entries.name: Player Hooks
entries.contentPreview: - Seek healing at the Springs of Vyowehr - Hire a guide for the Walking Forest crossing - Learn Stillspeech—the language opens doors across the Westwilds - Investigate a breach of the Compact that threatens Lacire's existence - Participate in the generational pilgrimage to Ierya's heart

entries.name: Maun
entries.contentPreview: A dwarven city-state on the southern coast of SW Urok, where the Maun River empties into Beauty Bay. Maun is home to the most famous school of music and theater in Alaria—an institution that has trained generations of bards, performers, and composers. But unlike most conservatories, Maun demands more than artistic talent from its students. Everyone who enters the School must spend a year fighting in the tunnels below.

entries.name: The Requirement
entries.contentPreview: Every student who enters the School of Music must serve one year in the military. This is non-negotiable. No exceptions for nobles, no exemptions for prodigies, no alternatives for pacifists. You can serve before your studies, during them, or after graduation—but you will serve, or you will not study at Maun. The service isn't ceremonial. Students spend their year in the tunnels beneath the Pearly Mountains, fighting the things that rise from the depths. The Shattered Court—ancient dwarven noble

entries.name: The School of Music
entries.contentPreview: Despite its military requirement—or perhaps because of it—the School of Music produces the finest performers in Alaria. Its graduates are sought by royal courts, theatrical troupes, and wealthy patrons across the continent. A Maun-trained bard commands respect wherever they go. The curriculum is comprehensive. Students study theory and composition, master at least one instrument, train in vocal performance, learn theatrical technique, and develop their own artistic voice. The faculty includes le

entries.name: The Yearly Competition
entries.contentPreview: Each year, the School holds a competition open to all students. The details vary—some years emphasize composition, others performance, others innovation—but the prize is always the same: a magical instrument of extraordinary power. These instruments are created by the School's master craftsmen, incorporating techniques passed down through generations and materials gathered from across Alaria. Past prizes have included a flute that charms any creature that hears it, a drum that can shatter stone,

entries.name: The Ghost
entries.contentPreview: Something haunts the School's halls. Students report encountering a figure in old-fashioned clothing who offers advice, encouragement, and occasionally harsh criticism of their work. The Ghost—as students call it—appears most often to those struggling with their art or their military service. Its advice is invariably useful; those who follow it tend to improve dramatically. No one knows who the Ghost was in life. The most popular theory holds it was one of the School's founders, unable to leave

entries.name: The Martial Tradition
entries.contentPreview: Maun's military isn't just a requirement—it's a culture. The School celebrates its warrior-musicians, maintains memorials to students who died in the tunnels, and incorporates martial themes into its curriculum. Battle songs are as respected as love ballads; percussion students learn to play drums that can coordinate troop movements; graduates often serve as military musicians in armies across Alaria. This tradition connects to something older. Some scholars believe Maun was founded by students

entries.name: Beauty Bay
entries.contentPreview: The bay where Maun meets the sea has earned its name. The mineral-rich waters—runoff from Tyberoskos's limestone sinkholes—create sunsets of impossible color, oranges and purples that painters struggle to reproduce. Maun has embraced this gift; the School holds outdoor performances in a natural amphitheater on the eastern shore, timing finales to coincide with the sunset's peak. The bay also provides Maun's connection to the wider world. Ships arrive carrying would-be students from across Alaria

entries.name: Relations with Wisgarrd
entries.contentPreview: Maun and Wisgarrd need each other and hate that they do. The relationship is simple: Wisgarrd pays, Maun fights. The jewelry school's extraordinary tuition provides the gold that funds Maun's military—weapons, armor, supplies, veteran salaries, compensation for families of the fallen. Without that money, Maun couldn't maintain the force necessary to hold the tunnels. Without Maun's force, Wisgarrd would be overrun within months. The cultural tension is less simple. Wisgarrd's jewelers consider t

entries.name: Government
entries.contentPreview: Maun is governed by the **Chorus**—a council of twelve masters representing different aspects of the School. Four represent the three academic tracks plus the instrument workshops; four represent the military; four are elected by alumni to represent the broader community's interests. The Chorus makes decisions by consensus when possible, by majority vote when necessary. The system is slow but ensures all perspectives are heard. Critics argue Maun is too conservative, too resistant to change; def

entries.name: Player Hooks
entries.contentPreview: - **The Silent Song**: A student has discovered a technique for making music that doesn't resonate into the tunnels—sound that the Shattered Court can't hear. If perfected, it could revolutionize Maun's relationship with the deep. But the student has disappeared, and her notes are missing. - **Tunnel Collapse**: Something has blocked the main defensive tunnel, trapping a patrol on the wrong side. Rescue is possible but dangerous—the route requires passing through territory held by the Court, and

entries.name: Melaia
entries.contentPreview: One of the three leadership city-states of the First Brotherhood—the ancient dwarven coalition formed when the world was far more dangerous. Along with Üod and Blvnird, Melaia's citizens hold the exclusive right to lead the Brotherhood.

entries.name: Government
entries.contentPreview: The city is governed according to First Brotherhood traditions. Only citizens of Üod, Blvnird, or Melaia may hold leadership positions in the Brotherhood's councils. This exclusivity has been a source of tension with dwarven settlements elsewhere, who pay membership fees to a union they can never truly lead.

entries.name: Relations
entries.contentPreview: **Tarkhon Empire**: Tributary but influential. The First Brotherhood's relationship with Tarkhon is complex—they accept imperial authority nominally while maintaining independent diplomatic relationships with dwarven communities worldwide. **Üod and Blvnird**: Sister cities. The three leadership city-states coordinate on Brotherhood policy and present a united front to outside powers. **Other Dwarven Nations**: The Brotherhood claims to represent all dwarves, but not all dwarves agree. Some view

entries.name: Rilyn
entries.contentPreview: A city-state of the Splinkreen — the tree-souled people who dwell in Puma Wood on Petrona Septia Island. Rilyn is less a political entity than a community that happens to occupy the same forest, its "governance" emerging from consensus among beings who've had centuries to learn patience. The Splinkreen are the legacy of an ancient wizard's experiment, their souls transplanted from mighty trees into humanoid forms. They move through their forest home with eerie calm, speaking in slow deliberate t

entries.name: Government
entries.contentPreview: Rilyn has no formal government — no council, no leader, no laws in the conventional sense. Decisions emerge through discussion that can take weeks or months, as the Splinkreen consider all perspectives and gradually reach consensus. Urgent matters are handled by whoever happens to be present and willing; long-term matters are handled by everyone, eventually. This works because the Splinkreen share fundamental values and have centuries to resolve disagreements. It fails when dealing with outsider

entries.name: The Splinkreen
entries.contentPreview: The inhabitants of Rilyn share certain characteristics: bark-like skin ranging from smooth birch white to rough oak brown, a tendency to sprout small leaves or moss in places of rest, and a perspective shaped by their origin as trees. They're not emotionless — they feel joy, sorrow, affection, anger — but they feel these things slowly, deliberately, without the urgency that characterizes shorter-lived peoples. A Splinkreen grieving a death might mourn for a decade, but the grief is genuine. A Sp

entries.name: Relations
entries.contentPreview: **With Ios**: The Splinkreen observe Ios's decline with philosophical interest. A civilization built on artificial servants, now forced to rediscover labor — it's the sort of irony the Splinkreen appreciate. Some have traveled to Todakres to study the stone dolls, curious about the animation techniques and what they might reveal about the nature of transferred souls. **With Moigos**: The Kappa and the Splinkreen have nothing to offer each other. The toad-folk deal in debts, urgency, and leverage

entries.name: Player Hooks
entries.contentPreview: - **The Patient Teacher**: A Splinkreen elder offers to teach something valuable — a skill, a secret, a piece of wisdom. The catch: the teaching will take months, conducted at Splinkreen pace. Is the knowledge worth the time? - **Ancient Memory**: A Splinkreen claims to remember something from their time as a tree — something they witnessed centuries ago, something relevant to current events. But tree-memories are fragmentary and strange. Interpreting what they saw requires patience and lateral

entries.name: Solhalven
entries.contentPreview: Home to the Valkyries - Strict court of law, based on olympus.

entries.name: Sweivyon
entries.contentPreview: A city-state of approximately twelve thousand souls perched in the Silver Slopes, controlling the richest silver deposits in the southern Dragon's Spine. Sweivyon is younger than most city-states—founded only four centuries ago by prospectors who struck a vein so pure it changed the region's economics—but it has accumulated wealth faster than many older polities accumulate history. The city occupies a naturally defensible position: a broad shelf of relatively flat terrain between two peaks, acce

entries.name: Government
entries.contentPreview: **The Silver Council** governs Sweivyon—eleven seats divided among the founding families, the major guild representatives, and two rotating positions elected by property owners. The council elects a Warden from among its members to handle executive functions, but real power lies with the controlling families who vote as blocs. The current Warden is **Helkos Varn**, a third-generation mining magnate who built his family's position by consolidating smaller claims during a price collapse forty year

entries.name: Defenses
entries.contentPreview: Sweivyon's military capacity is modest. The city maintains a professional guard of roughly four hundred, adequate for keeping order and patrolling the passes but not for fighting a war. The mountain geography provides natural protection—the passes can be held by small forces, and the winter closures give the city months of effective isolation. The real defense is economic. Sweivyon trades with everyone and threatens no one. Gondurak values the silver supply. The Dalizi value the trade route. Eve

entries.name: Relations
entries.contentPreview: **Gondurak** is Sweivyon's most important trading partner. Fengruk metalworkers turn slope silver into finished goods of exceptional quality, and the trade benefits both parties. Relations are cordial but not warm—the Fengruk consider Sweivyon nouveau riche, and Sweivyon considers the Fengruk insufferably traditional. **The Splinter Villages** of the Shrapnel Strait theoretically acknowledge Sweivyon's authority, though enforcement is minimal. The city claims tariff rights on strait trade and oc

entries.name: Notable Features
entries.contentPreview: **The Stamp House** certifies all silver exports, applying the famous Sweivyon brand that guarantees purity. The building is heavily fortified and rumored to contain the largest silver reserve in the region—a claim the council neither confirms nor denies. **The Varn Spire** rises from the city's highest point, a tower of silver-inlaid stone that the current Warden's family built as a monument to their success. It serves no practical purpose beyond demonstrating that the Varns can afford a monume

entries.name: Hooks
entries.contentPreview: **The Claim War**: Two founding families dispute a boundary in the deep mines, where a newly-discovered vein runs exactly along the legal division. Both sides are hiring—surveyors, lawyers, thugs, and anyone who might tip the balance. **The Catchment Sabotage**: Someone is damaging the Sunbeam Catchment system, allowing silver-rich runoff to reach the glitter-panners below. The council wants the saboteur found quietly; the panners want them protected; someone is getting very rich. **The Gondurak

entries.name: The Toll Family
entries.contentPreview: The Toll family has ruled Tollgate for three centuries, since the first Gatemaster established the toll system. The name wasn't original—they took it when they claimed the strait, and it's been their identity ever since. **Current Gatemaster**: **Lord Brennan Toll**, age sixty-two. Practical, focused entirely on maintaining revenue, with no ambitions beyond holding what his family built. Succession passes within the family, usually to the most competent candidate. "Most competent" is determined

entries.name: Wisgarrd
entries.contentPreview: A dwarven city-state built into the foothills where the Pearly Mountains descend toward the southern coast of SW Urok. Wisgarrd is home to the most prestigious school of jewelry-making in Alaria—an institution that has produced master craftsmen for over a thousand years and guards secrets of magical enchantment that nobles would kill to possess. But Wisgarrd exists for a darker reason than artistry. The city was built to fund a war that never ends—a war against something that lives beneath the m

entries.name: The Shattered Court
entries.contentPreview: Beneath the Pearly Mountains lies a vast cavern system carved over millennia by underground rivers. The caverns are not empty. Something lives there—many somethings—that were once the ruling class of an Uline Dwarven kingdom that predated Wisgarrd, Maun, and perhaps Xi Chin itself. When that kingdom fell—to invasion, to civil war, to causes now forgotten—the nobles refused to accept death. Through rituals that modern scholars can barely comprehend, they bound themselves to the stone itself, beco

entries.name: The Resonance
entries.contentPreview: The caverns beneath Wisgarrd and Maun *resonate*. Sound carries strangely through the tunnels, amplified and transformed. A song performed in Maun might echo through miles of stone, reaching chambers where the Shattered Court waits. A gem cut in Wisgarrd, when light strikes it, sends reflections rippling through crystal formations that connect to the deep places. The Court responds. When something beautiful enough reaches them—a masterwork composition, a perfectly cut diamond, a performance of t

entries.name: The Arrangement
entries.contentPreview: Wisgarrd and Maun hate each other. The jewelry-makers consider the musicians pretentious dreamers; the musicians consider the jewelers mercenary snobs. They've feuded for centuries over prestige, students, and which art is more essential to civilization. But they need each other to survive. Wisgarrd has wealth. The tuition from noble patrons fills its coffers year after year. What it lacks is warriors—gem-cutters don't make effective soldiers, and the city's guards are barely adequate for peacet

entries.name: The School of Jewelry
entries.contentPreview: The School occupies Wisgarrd's highest terrace, its workshops oriented to catch the best natural light. Students begin with fundamentals—metallurgy, gem identification, basic cutting techniques—and progress over years to increasingly sophisticated work. Competition is fierce; only the top students advance to each subsequent level. The curriculum is divided into the Outer School and the Inner School. **The Outer School** teaches technical mastery. A graduate can cut gems with supernatural precisi

entries.name: The Peonie River
entries.contentPreview: The Peonie flows past Wisgarrd's walls, its banks carpeted with the flowering plants that give the river its name. The blooms—pink, white, and occasionally a deep crimson—have inspired Wisgarrd's jewelers for centuries. Peonie motifs appear in the oldest and most traditional designs, and graduating students traditionally receive a brooch in the peonie pattern. But the flowers serve another purpose. Something in their scent—or perhaps in the mineral content of the water that feeds them—seems to d

entries.name: Government
entries.contentPreview: Wisgarrd is governed by the **Gemcutters' Council**, composed of the school's senior masters. The Council controls both the city and the school, making no distinction between civic and academic authority. All citizens are either students, faculty, or support staff; there is no separate merchant class or nobility. The Council's primary concerns are maintaining the school's reputation, managing the flow of tuition money, and—above all—coordinating with Maun's military for defense. A standing commi

entries.name: Player Hooks
entries.contentPreview: - **The Perfect Piece**: A master jeweler believes she can create something that will satisfy the Shattered Court permanently—a gem so beautiful that they'll retreat to their depths and stay there. She needs rare materials from dangerous places, and she needs someone to protect her while she works. If she's wrong, her masterpiece might trigger the worst incursion in centuries. - **The Book of Gems**: Someone has stolen pages from the Book of Gems. The Council wants them recovered before the thie

entries.name: Zor
entries.contentPreview: A city-state of roughly 15,000 souls on the western shore of Moornik Bay, Zor is the only permanent settlement in the vast Eyendra forest. It exists because a dragon permits it, and eight centuries of survival have taught its people that some bargains are worth keeping. Zor turns its back on the forest. The city faces the sea—economically, culturally, psychologically. The forest behind them is not wilderness to be tamed but a presence to be acknowledged and carefully avoided. Every citizen grows

entries.name: The Dragon Pact
entries.contentPreview: Zor's existence is predicated on an agreement with Ezra Olkanis, an ancient dragon who dwells in the Eyendra interior. The pact was made eight centuries ago with a fishing village that eventually grew into the current city. Every generation, the ruling council formally reaffirms the terms: **Zor must not disturb the interior.** Certain ruins are forbidden. Certain lakes—particularly in the Wer Azenzi region—must never be approached. The boundaries shift over decades as the dragon sends word thro

entries.name: Government
entries.contentPreview: Five hereditary families rule Zor—descendants of those who negotiated the original pact. Power rotates on a complex schedule, with one family holding the Speakership (executive authority) for fifteen years. The system is stable but rigid. Reform movements exist but rarely gain traction; most citizens prefer a functioning arrangement to an exciting collapse. The current Speaker is **Maera Theln**, a practical woman in her sixties known for cautious competence rather than vision. Below the council

entries.name: Relations
entries.contentPreview: Zor trades with other Wycendeula coastal settlements but maintains no close alliances. The city is too isolated, too specialized, too strange. Merchants welcome Zor's timber and herbs; they're less comfortable with Zor's culture. The dragon is not technically a diplomatic entity, but she might as well be. Anything that threatens Zor risks drawing her attention, which means Zor has enjoyed remarkable security for a city its size. No one has seriously attempted to conquer it since the pact was est

entries.name: Threats
entries.contentPreview: **The Rationalists**: A merchant faction arguing the dragon is dead, gone, or exaggerated. They want to explore the interior and exploit resources beyond the current boundaries. Their numbers grow when trade is poor. **Resource Pressure**: Zor's population has grown but the extraction zones haven't. Demand is outpacing sustainable supply. Eventually someone will cross a boundary. **The Interior Dreams**: People in Zor sometimes dream of the forest—walking paths they've never seen, seeing faces t

entries.name: Hooks
entries.contentPreview: See the full **Zor** entry in the Atlas of Alaria (atlas_of_alaria/wycendeula/Zor.md) for additional hooks and location details.

entries.name: Üod
entries.contentPreview: One of the three leadership city-states of the First Brotherhood—the ancient dwarven coalition formed when the world was far more dangerous. Along with Blvnird and Melaia, Üod's citizens hold the exclusive right to lead the Brotherhood.

entries.name: Government
entries.contentPreview: The city is governed according to First Brotherhood traditions. Only citizens of Üod, Blvnird, or Melaia may hold leadership positions in the Brotherhood's councils. This exclusivity has been a source of tension with dwarven settlements elsewhere, who pay membership fees to a union they can never truly lead.

entries.name: Relations
entries.contentPreview: **Tarkhon Empire**: Tributary but influential. The First Brotherhood's relationship with Tarkhon is complex—they accept imperial authority nominally while maintaining independent diplomatic relationships with dwarven communities worldwide. **Blvnird and Melaia**: Sister cities. The three leadership city-states coordinate on Brotherhood policy and present a united front to outside powers. **Other Dwarven Nations**: The Brotherhood claims to represent all dwarves, but not all dwarves agree.
